Adopt and present a resolution recognizing January 2024 as Positive 
Parenting Awareness Month in Solano County (Supervisor Hannigan)
A - Positive Parenting Awareness Month Resolution 2024
Attachments:
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.
Page 3 
Solano County
Printed on 1/4/2024

January 9, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Agenda - Final
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

chunks.text:
Adopt a resolution declaring the former Beverly Hills Elementary School 
site located at 1450 Coronel Ave, Vallejo, California (APN: 0074-195-010) 
as surplus property and transferring the property to Child Start, Inc. subject 
to deed restrictions requiring Child Start, Inc. to use the property as an 
early learning center for at least 25 years; Approve a Funding and 
Construction Agreement with Child Start, Inc. to renovate the existing 
facility for use as an early learning center; and Authorize the County 
Administrator to execute the Funding and Construction Agreement and any

chunks.item_title: Consider the following:
chunks.text:
Consider the following:
A.
Nomination and election of Chair
B.
Nomination and election of Vice-Chair
C.
Nomination and election of Chair Pro Tem
D.
Seating selection at the dais
E.
Presentation to outgoing Chair
F.
Remarks by Supervisors
Chair Vasquez made a motion of Supervisor Hannigan as Chair, Supervisor 
Mashburn as Vice-Chair and Supervisor Williams as Chair Pro-Tem.
Supervisor Hannigan offered an alternate motion of Supervisor Mashburn as 
Chair and Supervisor Williams as Vice-Chair. Supervisor Hannigan then 
Page 1
Solano County

January 9, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
offered to bifurcate the motion.
Supervisor Hannigan made a motion of Supervisor Mashburn as Chair. 
Supervisor Williams seconded the motion.
Supervisor Hannigan nominated Supervisor Williams as Vice-Chair.
Supervisor Mashburn made an alternate motion to nominate Supervisor 
Hannigan as Vice-Chair and Supervisor Williams as Chair Pro Tem.
Supervisor Hannigan thanked staff for their hard work and noted she looks 
forward to a very productive year. 
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board elected Supervisor Mashburn as the Chair for 2024. So ordered by a 4-1 
vote with Supervisor Vasquez voting no.
On motion of Chair Mashburn, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez the Board 
elected Supervisor Hannigan as the Vice-Chair for 2024 and Supervisor 
Williams as Chair Pro Tem. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PRESENTATIONS
2

chunks.item_title: Adopt
chunks.text:
Adopt 
and 
present 
a 
resolution 
recognizing 
January 
2024 as 
Positive 
Parenting Awareness Month in Solano County (Supervisor Hannigan)
A - Positive Parenting Awareness Month Resolution 2024
Attachments:
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board adopted and presented Resolution No. 2024-1 recognizing January 2024 
as Positive Parenting Awareness Month in Solano County. So ordered by a 5-0 
vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-1
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on 
matters not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of 
the Board. The following comments were received:
A) Mindful commented on the need for Mental Health services in Solano
County.
B) Director of Library Services Suzanne Olawski introduced Supervising
Librarian Mychal Threets winner of the American Library Association "I love
my librarian" contest. Mr. Threets commented on his love of working for the
Solano County library.
C) Steve Olry commented on the Flannery "California Forever" project and
various issues.
D) George Guynn, Jr. commented on various issues.
Page 2
Solano County

January 9, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of 
Supervisors' agenda for January 9, 2024.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for 
January 9, 2024 as submitted. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Supervisor Hannigan commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 3, noting it 
should be on Presentation going forward. Supervisor Hannigan commented 
on Consent Calendar Item No. 11, noting this action supports both Solano 
County's children and their families. Supervisor Hannigan commented on 
Consent Calendar Item No. 12, noting she has concerns regarding human 
trafficking especially in the City of Vallejo and requested information from the 
Department of Health and Social Services on what Solano County is doing to 
counter human trafficking. 
Supervisor Brown commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 11, noting early 
learning is a fundamental right for all children regardless of socio-economic 
background and there is a great need for childcare access in Solano County.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board approved the following Consent Calendar items by 5-0 vote:

chunks.item_title: Consider awarding Solano County Housing Trust Fund allocations as a result
chunks.text:
Consider awarding Solano County Housing Trust Fund allocations as a result 
of a Notice of Funding Availability as follows: a $93,000 grant to Solano-Napa 
Habitat for Humanity; and a $3,200,000 loan to The Hampstead Companies 
for 
107 affordable 
housing 
units 
in 
Dixon; 
and 
Authorize 
the 
County 
Administrator to execute any and all documents related to the awards 
A - Notice of Funding Availability
B - Solano-Napa Habitat for Humanity Application
C - The Homestead Companies Application
D - EAH Inc. Application
E - Eden Application
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Anne Putney provided an overview of the 
Solano County Housing Trust Fund allocation and NOFA process.
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the item, noting this provides 
affordable housing to a community that needs the housing.
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding the cost of the 
housing that Habitat for Humanity is building, Executive Director for Habitat 
for Humanity Andrew Killeen stated the higher cost is because the property 
was in the flood plain and Habitat for Humanity elected to raise the property 
out of the flood plain which improved the sustainability and affordability of the 
project as well as avoiding the need for the families to incur the high cost of 
flood insurance. Mr. Killeen further stated the homes will be appraised and will 
be sold at the appraised value. Mr. Killeen noted it will be made affordable 
because the monthly payment on the housing will be no more than 30% of 
their income at the time of loan origination. Mr. Killeen further noted because 
Habitat for Humanity has the first right to purchase when they are sold, the 
homes will remain in as low income housing for at least 45 years.
In response to comments by Supervisor Brown regarding one of the homes 
going to a veteran, Mr. Killeen noted there were no veterans that applied that 
earned enough to meet the lowest 50% to 80% AMI. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) George Guynn, Jr. commented in opposition to the recommended action.
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board: 1) awarded Solano County Housing Trust Fund allocations as a result of 
a Notice of Funding Availability as follows: a $93,000 grant to Solano-Napa 
Page 7
Solano County

January 9, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Habitat for Humanity; and a $3,200,000 loan to The Hampstead Companies for 
107 affordable housing units in Dixon; and 2) authorized the County 
Administrator to execute any and all documents related to the awards. So 
ordered by a 5-0 vote.
19

chunks.item_title: Consider Board of Supervisors’ appointments to various boards,
chunks.text:
Consider Board of Supervisors’ appointments to various boards, 
commissions and committees for 2024
A - BOS Appts Detailed
Attachments:
Chair Mashburn asked the Board Members for their requested committee 
changes.
Supervisor Vasquez requested to become the alternate representative for the 
Marin Clean Energy Board of Directors and to have Supervisor Brown 
become the primary representative. Supervisor Brown stated she was in 
agreement with the requested change.
Supervisor 
Williams 
requested 
to 
be 
added 
to 
the 
Community 
Action 
Partnership (CAP) Solano JPA Board.
Chair Mashburn stated he was ok with stepping down from the CAP Solano; 
however, 
he 
recommended 
Supervisor 
Williams 
become 
the 
alternate 
representative and Supervisor Vasquez, the current alternate representative, 
become the primary representative. Supervisor Vasquez stated he did not 
wish to become the primary representative and recommended Supervisor 
Williams become the primary representative. 
Supervisor Hannigan recommended Supervisor Williams step down from the 
CAP 
Solano 
Tripartite 
Advisory 
Board 
with 
taking 
on 
the 
primary 
representative of the CAP Solano JPA Board. Supervisor Brown stated she 
would be willing to be the primary representative on the CAP Solano Tripartite 
Advisory Board. 
Supervisor Williams requested to be added as the alternate representative to 
the Solano Economic Development Board. 
Supervisor Hannigan stated Chair Mashburn sits on the Solano Economic 
Development Board as a representative of the Solano County Water Agency.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, second by Supervisor Hannigan, the Board

Attachments:
Planning Manager Allan Calder introduced the item.
Senior Planner Eric Wilberg provided an overview of the Solano Landing LLC 
project. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing.
Applicant James Pierson commented in support on the recommended project 
and provided an overview of steps taken to ensure the project is accepted by 
the community.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Ethan Hartsell commented on the need for better studies on left hand turn
pockets for the project.
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding if vineyards are 
going to be planted, Consultant Kathy Pease stated it is a condition of 
Page 5
Solano County

January 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
12

chunks.item_title: approval for the project to plant vineyards.
chunks.text:
approval for the project to plant vineyards. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the project.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the project. 
In response to comments made by Supervisor Williams regarding the use of 
the 2011 traffic study, Mr. Tuggle stated if you have a project's peak traffic 
hour that overlaps the regional peak traffic hour, then the applicant may have 
a requirement to make improvements; noting however that he cautions the 
Board about applying broad standards against the applicant/project for an 
impact that is the result of a more regional issue.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the project.
Chair Mashburn commented in support of the project. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board: 1) adopted Resolution No. 2024-9 approving the Mitigated Negative 
Declaration for the Project, pursuant to the California Environmental Quality 
Act (CEQA); 2) approved reading the proposed ordinance approving Rezone 
Petition Z-22-04 by title only and waived further reading by majority vote; 3) 
adopted Ordinance No. 2024-1851, approving Rezone Petition Z-22-04; and 4) 
adopted Resolution No. 2024-10 approving Use Permit No. U-22-03. So ordered 
by a 5-0 vote.
Enactment No: Ordinance 2024-1851, Resolution No. 2024-9 and Resolution 
No. 2024-10
Conduct a noticed Public Hearing to consider adopting an urgency interim 
ordinance to prohibit new commercial battery energy storage systems within 
the unincorporated areas of the County of Solano (4/5 vote required); the 
proposed 
urgency 
interim 
ordinance 
is 
not 
subject 
to 
the 
California 
Environmental Quality Act pursuant to section 15060 (c)(2) and is exempt 
from sections 15061(b)(3), 15307, and 15308 of the CEQA Guidelines
A - Draft Ordinance
B - Summary of AB 205 Process
C - Public Notice
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item and 
provided an overview of the requested urgency interim ordinance to prohibit 
new commercial battery energy storage systems.
Planning Manager Allan Calder provided an overview of the current battery 
energy storage systems (BESS) proposal in unincorporated Solano County.
A discussion period was held regarding interim prohibition vs. complete 
prohibition. 
Supervisor Vasquez stated he wants it made clear that this is not a 
Page 6
Solano County

January 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
permanent prohibition of BESS facilities, but a interim prohibition to allow staff 
time to identify potential issues.
Supervisor Hannigan recommended staff return to the Board at a later time 
with identified places within the unincorporated areas of the County where 
these types of facilities can be located. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the recommended action. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the recommended action. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding restoration of 
the properties if the site is abandoned, Mr. Calder stated part of what staff will 
be reviewing is how to decommission a facility. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Pam Barringer commented in support of the recommended moratorium.
B) Stephen Ahn commented in opposition to the recommended moratorium.
C) Joel Barrilleaux commented in support of the recommended moratorium.
D) George Guynn, Jr. commented in support of the recommended
moratorium.
E) Scott Mutishaw commented in opposition to the recommended
moratorium.
F) Chris Heise commented in support of the recommended moratorium.
G) Brandon Kline commented in support of the recommended moratorium.
H) Sarah Dunn commented in support of the recommended moratorium.
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.
Chair Mashburn commented that there are numerous areas within the County 
where a facility like this can be placed, further noting the opposition to these 
projects appear to be more about location than an actual opposition to the 
facilities. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding requiring staff 
to return to the Board of Supervisors for approval of new BESS projects, 
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated staff can add the requirement to the 
ordinance when it returns to the Board for approval of a longer moratorium 
period. Ms. Curry further stated in response to Supervisor Vasquez's earlier 
comments regarding complete prohibition vs. a moratorium, the 
Page 7
Solano County

January 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
recommended action should indicate the Board is temporarily prohibiting new 
commercial battery storage facilities within the unincorporated area of the 
County. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board: 1) approved reading the proposed urgency interim ordinance to 
temporarily prohibit new commercial battery energy storage systems within 
the unincorporated areas of the County of Solano by title only and waived 
further reading by a majority vote; and 2) the Board adopted Ordinance No. 
2024-1852-U, an urgency interim ordinance to temporarily prohibit new 
commercial battery energy storage systems within the unincorporated areas of 
the County of Solano So ordered by a 5-0 vote.

chunks.item_title: Receive an update on the proposed Department of Resource Management
chunks.text:
Receive an update on the proposed Department of Resource Management 
Planning Services Division’s 2024/25 Work Plan; and Provide direction on the 
proposed work plan
A - 2024-2025 Work Plan
B - Planning Division Work Plan Duties
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Planning Manager Allan Calder provided an overview of the Planning Division 
Work Plan. 
Supervisor Vasquez stated it is an ambitious work plan, and recommended 
the Land Use and Transportation Committee begin to meet monthly and 
provide a quarterly update to the entire Board of Supervisors. Supervisor 
Vasquez further recommended staff review how the County can coordinate 
with CapSolano should the Bay Area Housing Finance Authority bond be 
passed.
Supervisor Hannigan commented on the need to ensure staff time on the 
California Forever project needs to be covered by California Forever. 
Supervisor Hannigan further stated staff should be looking at placement of 
truck stops within Solano County.
Supervisor Williams commented on the need for a subject matter expert be 
placed on staff for the Suisun Valley Strategic Plan Update.
In response to comments by Supervisor Williams, Mr. Calder stated Senior 
Planner Eric Wilberg is the main contact person for all requests for 
information on the Suisun Valley to ensure the messaging is consistent. 
Supervisor Brown requested staff keep the Board updated on the California 
Forever project.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated the structure of the work plan provides 
Page 8
Solano County

January 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
clarity about how the workloads are being allocated with the department. Mr. 
Emlen further stated the County is going to need to look at the consulting that 
is going to be necessary with regards to the California Forever project, noting 
the County is going to need access to resources quickly to be able to start 
analyzing the proposal as well as providing clear communication to the public 
regarding the proposal as it goes forward. 
Received
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public.

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation providing a progress update on projects funded with
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation providing a progress update on projects funded with 
Solano County American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Coronavirus State and 
Local Fiscal Recovery Funds (SLFRF); Consider approving a re-allocation of 
funding from the category of Revenue Recovery of $1,500,000 to NorthBay 
Health for a total allocation of $6,000,000 to cover unreimbursed costs during 
the COVID-19 pandemic; and Consider providing further direction and take 
possible action on the re-allocation of $2,809,879 in American Rescue Plan 
Act (ARPA) Coronavirus State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds (SLFRF) 
A - ARPA Project Updates
B - Obligation Interim Final Rule Reference Guide
C - ARPA Admin Cost Estimate
Attachments:
Assistant County Administrator Ian Goldberg introduced the item.
Senior Management Analyst Megan Richards provided an overview of American 
Rescue Plan Act spending on previously approved projects. Ms. Richards 
provided an overview of select achievements as of January 31, 2024, the new 
Page 8
Solano County

February 6, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
treasury obligation interim final rule, potential use of revenue recovery funds, and 
completed projects. 
In response to a question by Supervisor Vasquez regarding the upcoming press 
release for agricultural grants, Ms. Richards noted she can provide the press 
release to the Board prior to distribution and at the recommendation of Supervisor 
Vasquez will have the Public Information Officer also review the release. 
In response to a question by Supervisor Brown regarding the time frame for 
distribution and use of obligated funds that are provided by recipients to 
subrecipients, Ms. Richards stated the interim final rule provides additional time 
for subrecipients to use the funds once reallocated by the original recipients.
In response to a question by Supervisor Vasquez regarding at what point the 
Board should begin to look at pulling ARPA funds back to the County for 
reallocation, Mr. Goldberg stated staff is constantly monitoring the projects and 
the goal is for staff to return to the Board early to provide time for the Board to 
make reallocation decisions.
Chair Mashburn stated he wishes to set a hard deadline in the middle of 2024 to 
ensure the funds are expended as they should be.
Supervisor Hannigan stated staff should establish a threshold of confidence for 
project completion, noting there are projects that have already been obligated but 
did not receive full funding and could be brought back before the Board. 
In response to a question by Supervisor Williams regarding if the Tabor 
Commons project will require additional funding should they receive the 
multi-family tax housing credits, Ms. Richards stated that the ARPA funds 
requested represented the local match that was necessary.
Ms. Richards provided the following recommendations for the Board to potentially 
address funding gaps from previous requests: 1) reallocate $1,500,000 in the category 
of Revenue Replacement from the Mankas Corners project to NorthBay Health; 2) 
reallocate 
up 
to 
$600,000 
in 
the 
category 
of 
Negative 
Economic 
Impacts from Parkside Flats to Tabor Commons to expand low-income housing 
opportunities; 3) reallocate up to $213,154 in the category of Revenue 
Replacement from the completed Employee Retention to Emergency Gap 
funding to fully fund the original request from SHELTER Solano of $350,000 to 
provide regional shelter beds at the Beck Avenue Navigation Center; or 4) 
reallocate up to $2,720,000 to the category of Negative Economic Impacts for the 
Vallejo Early Learning Center Community Resource Building.
Supervisor Vasquez made a motion to: 1) reallocate $1,500,000 in funding to 
North Bay Health; and 2) reallocate additional funding to Revenue Recovery in the 
amount of $1,620,929. The motion failed due to lack of a second. 
Supervisor Hannigan made a motion to: 1) reallocate $1,500,000 in funding to 
North Bay Health; 2) reallocate $600,000 to Tabor Commons; 3) reallocate 
Page 9
Solano County

February 6, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
$213,154 to SHELTER Solano; and 4) reallocate $1,996,775 to the Vallejo Early 
Learning Center Community Resource Building. Supervisor Williams seconded 
the motion. 
Chair Mashburn stated the Board has made significant investments in the City of 
Vallejo, noting more funding needs to be spread throughout the County. Chair 
Mashburn further stated he supports: 1) reallocating $1,500,000 in funding to 
North Bay Health; 2) reallocating $600,000 to Tabor Commons; and 
3) 
reallocating $213,154 to SHELTER Solano.
Supervisor Brown commented in support of: 1) reallocating $1,500,000 in funding

and the California Workforce Development Board for Helping Justice-Involved

Receive 
an 
overview 
of 
the 
proposed 
implementation 
plan 
for 
Opioid Settlement Funds awarded to Solano County for the expansion of 
substance use services for the remediation of opioid use disorder and other 
allowable abatement activities
A - Presentation
Attachments:
Assistant Director of Health and Social Services Roger Robinson introduced the 
item. 
Director of Behavioral Health Emery Cowan provided an overview of plans to 
utilize opioid settlement funds awarded to the County. 
Behavioral Health Medical Director Dr. Brent Pottenger, stated substance use 
varies regionally throughout the country, noting methamphetamine use has made 
the opioid epidemic much worse in terms of risks of fatal overdose. 
In response to a question by Supervisor Vasquez regarding reasons why the 
cities have not chosen to divert their opioid settlement funds to the County, Ms. 
Cowan stated there are various reasons why they have not chosen to divert the 
funding; however, they are aware they have the option to divert the funding if they 
want to.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding how to change the 
outlook of communities who do not want rehab facilities in their neighborhoods, 
Ms. Cowan stated the County needs to provide better education and exposure 
within those communities by sharing data on actual results which could dispel the 
misconceptions of what having a facility in their area will be like.
In response to comments by Ms. Cowan and Supervisor Vasquez, Mr. Robinson 
stated there needs to be transparency and community engagement. 
Supervisor Hannigan stated political leaders need to be more courageous and 
open regarding discussing the need for people to seek treatment, noting all 
government agencies need to work together on educating the communities.
Supervisor Brown commented on the need to have those with lived experience 
be part of the community engagement process. Supervisor Brown further 
commented on the need to begin teaching kids and their parents about the 
potential consequences of drug use utilizing school science classes. 
In response to questions from Supervisor Mashburn regarding youth education 
and engagement, Senior Health Services Program Manager Robin Cox stated 
staff has done extensive work with the Solano County Office of Education 
(SCOE) to hold town hall meetings to engage both students and parents, 
provided education materials in English, Spanish and Tagalog, and have done 
Page 12
Solano County

February 6, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
extensive media campaigns.
In response to Ms. Cox’s comments, Chair Mashburn commented on the need to 
work not just with SCOE, but also directly with the various school districts, some 
of which are not affiliated with SCOE, regarding a County-wide change in 
curriculum. 
Supervisor 
Williams 
recommended 
staff 
contact 
the 
Community 
Action 
Committee, noting all of the District Directors are on the committee and 
information could be disseminated for school districts in all 7 cities via the 
committee. 
Supervisor Vasquez stated staff needs to work with the Board of Trustees for the 
various school districts because they are the ones that decide the curriculums.
Co-Chair for Drug Safe Solano Dr. Christina Kinnevey stated Solano County is no 
longer just dealing with fentanyl. Ms. Kinnevey further stated doctors are now 
seeing new novel potent opioids which are up to 20 times more potent than 
fentanyl and unfortunately there are no readily available test strips for the general 
public to use. Dr. Kinevey noted the County can barely keep up with the new 
drugs that are available on the streets. 
Public Health Officer Dr. Bela Matyas stated the risk of dying from fentanyl comes 
from multiple pathways and there are many reasons why the youth are taking 
drugs including depression, anxiety, traumatic home life, peer pressure, or simply 
that it looks fun. Dr. Matyas further stated the County is looking at a bigger 
problem than just substance abuse per se, noting no one thing is going to solve 
this problem because it is a societal issue that cuts across all demographics and 
the County needs to be mindful of how complex the issue is.
In response to a question by Supervisor Hannigan regarding if the COVID 
stay-at-home orders and isolation have had an impact on this issue, Dr. Matyas 
stated how COVID was handled was stressful for many people and closing 
schools had implications for the youth, noting that many individuals came out of 
the pandemic with a form of PTSD. Dr. Matyas further stated while it did not 
cause the opioid crisis in the youth, it certainly exacerbated other underlying 
stresses. 
Supervisor Brown recommended staff reach out to the various teacher’s 
associations.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Ramón Castellblanch commented on places where the opioid settlement
funds should be spent.
Received
Page 13
Solano County

February 6, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing and consider adopting a resolution to
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing and consider adopting a resolution to 
approve 
an 
Addendum 
to 
the 
Solano 
County 
General 
Plan 
Final 
Environmental Impact Report pursuant to the California Environmental Quality 
Act and adopt the 2023-2031 Housing Element
A - BOS Housing Element Resolution
B - Exhibit A to Resolution - Housing Element
C - Links to Addendum and EIR
D - Planning Commission Staff Report
E - Planning Commission Resolution
F - Public Notice
Attachments:
Planning Program Manager Allan Calder introduced the item. 
Principal Planner Matt Walsh provided a brief overview of Solano County’s 
process for updating Solano County’s Housing Element
Consultant Jennifer Gastelum presented the 2023-2031 Solano County Housing 
Element for Board approval and provided the Board with an overview of the public 
outreach that was completed, the submission process with the State of California 
Page 14
Solano County

February 6, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Housing Community Development (HCD), information on how the Regional 
Housing Needs Allocation (RHNA) is determined, and strategies for the County to 
meet its RHNA numbers.
In response to a question by Supervisor Vasquez regarding HCD Program B-1, 
Ms. Gastelum stated when annexations occur the County can require the 
annexing entity to transfer some of the County’s mandated RHNA numbers.
In response to Supervisor Vasquez’s comments, County Counsel Bernadette 
Curry stated when a new MOU is drafted, the County will work with LAFCO for 
the terms of the actual annexation and property tax sharing agreement, noting it 
would be tied to the implementation of the actual construction of the housing 
units.
In response to a question by Supervisor Vasquez regarding how the County can 
enforce requiring the annexing entities to comply with agreements to transfer 
additional RHNA numbers with an annexation, Mr. Walsh stated he is uncertain 
how they can ensure action is taken.
Chair Mashburn stated there needs to be a liquidated damage assessment 
should the annexing entity state it will build low-income housing, but instead 
builds market-rate housing.
Ms. Curry stated staff can address adding a penalty to require the sharing of 
property taxes unless the annexing agency can demonstrate and/or prove they 
have constructed the units transferred by the County.
In response to Supervisor Vasquez’s comments, County Administrator Bill Emlen 
stated larger projects that require annexation will have entitlements that are 
typically 
contingent 
upon 
the 
annexation, 
and 
often 
have 
development 
agreements that are tied to them. Mr. Emlen further stated the County has an 
opportunity to work with the cities to incorporate the County’s requests into the 
development agreements prior to the annexation going to LAFCO. 
In response to a question by Supervisor Hannigan regarding enforcement of 
RHNA numbers, Ms. Gastelum noted the State now has an enforcement division 
that will be tracking the requirements of the approved Housing Element; however. 
Ms. Gastelum stated because the County is not in the business of developing 
housing the State will be monitoring if County is completing the individual program 
requirements. Ms. Gastelum further stated the County will most likely be given 
plenty of opportunity to complete the programs.
In response to a question by Supervisor Williams regarding if the County as a 
part of an annexation approval can require a deed restriction for cities to build 
low-income housing units which will help the County meet its RHNA numbers, 
Ms. Curry stated that type of request would be a part of negotiations for the 
shared property tax agreement, noting it depends on what leverage the County 
has over the jurisdiction and the property owner who would be agreeing to the 
deed restriction.
Page 15
Solano County

February 6, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments from 
the public.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding Community 
Development Block Grant (CDBG) funding, Mr. Walsh stated the County applied 
several years ago for CDBG funding but was not an awarded recipient. Mr. Walsh 
further stated the County does have local housing rehabilitation program funding 
for the Homeacres neighborhood.
Mr. Calder stated included in the scope of work on the home rehabilitation project 
is an agreement that the contractor will help the County apply for three additional 
grants, at least one of which will be for CDBG funding.

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation from the District Attorney’s Office on the military
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation from the District Attorney’s Office on the military 
equipment policy and report of current inventory relative to Assembly Bill (AB) 
481; Read the proposed ordinance by title only and waive further reading of 
the ordinance; and Consider introducing an uncodified ordinance pursuant to 
AB 481 approving a military equipment policy for the Solano County District 
Attorney’s Office
A - Policy 706 - AB 481 Draft
B - Appendix A AB 481 Draft
C - Appendix B AB 481 Draft
D - Link to Assembly Bill 481
E - Ordinance - Draft
Attachments:
District Attorney Krishna Abrams introduced the item.
Chief District Attorney Investigator James Barnes provided an overview of AB481 
and the equipment the District Attorney’s office has. Mr. Barnes stated the two 
Colt M4 rifles are secured in a safe in a controlled room, are not deployed in 
vehicles with any of the District Attorney's investigators, and are strictly to be 
used in case of an active shooter situation. Mr. Barnes further stated the District 
Attorney will be requesting the ability to use asset forfeiture funds to purchase two 
drones to be used for crime scene mapping. 
In response to a question by Supervisor Hannigan regarding why the staff report 
indicates the District Attorney’s office only has only one Colt M4 rifle, Mr. Barnes 
stated there are two listed in Appendix A of the resolution, noting it was an 
oversight that both were not included in the staff report. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board: 1) read the proposed uncodified ordinance adopting the District 
Attorney's Military Equipment Use Policy pursuant to AB 481 by title only and 
waived further reading of the ordinance; and 2) introduced an uncodified 
ordinance pursuant to AB 481 approving a military equipment policy for the 
Solano County District Attorney’s Office. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
16

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed Public Hearing to consider extending interim Ordinance
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed Public Hearing to consider extending interim Ordinance 
No. 2024-1852-U, adopted as an urgency measure on January 23, 2024, 
prohibiting 
new 
commercial 
battery 
energy 
storage 
systems 
within 
the 
unincorporated territory of the County of Solano, for an additional 22 months 
and 15 days (4/5 vote required); the proposed extension is not subject to the 
Page 5
Solano County

February 27, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant to section 15060(c)(2), 
and is exempt under sections 15061(b)(3), 15307, and 15308 of the CEQA 
Guidelines
A - Draft Ordinance 2024-1852-U-E
B - Exhibit A - BESS Ext. 65858(d) 10-Day Progress Report
C - Ordinance No. 2024-1852-U
D - Public Notice
BESS Urgency Ordinance Presentation
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item and 
provided a brief overview of past actions of the Board.
Supervisor Vasquez stated this item was also heard at the Land Use and 
Transportation Committee and the recommendation of the Committee is to 
approve the extension of the ordinance. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public to
address the Board on this matter and the following comments were received:
A)
Stephen Ahn commented in opposition to the recommended action.
B)
Scott Murtishaw commented in opposition to the recommended action as
presented and requested a limited time frame on the moratorium.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the recommended action, noting 
the County does need to find a safe pathway to move forward. Supervisor 
Hannigan further stated the path forward is fully electric and if the County waits 
too long it will run the risk of the State of California imposing or directing where 
the County should place the facilities, noting staff will need to move quickly to 
identify safe storage areas within the County where facilities can be placed. 
Supervisor Vasquez stated the Land Use and Transportation Committee and the 
Board have both already provided similar direction to Supervisor Hannigan’s 
comments 
to 
staff, 
including 
recommending 
staff 
review 
other 
agency 
ordinances, to map out where connections can occur, and where the best 
locations for the facilities will be. 
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.
In response to Supervisor Hannigan’s comments, Planning Manager Allan Calder 
stated it is staff’s intention to expedite the process as much as feasible, noting 
Solano County is in a unique situation with regards to siting criteria for the 
facilities, because of a series of substations throughout the County that are in 
proximity to residential areas and sensitive receptors. Mr. Calder further stated it 
is important that staff takes the time to review for the possibility of displacement 
of agriculture that will take place with approval of these types of facilities.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board: 1) approved reading the proposed extension of the urgency interim 
Page 6
Solano County

February 27, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ordinance prohibiting new commercial battery energy storage systems within 
the unincorporated territory of the County of Solano, adopted as an urgency 
measure, by title only and waived further reading by majority vote; and 2) 
adopted Ordinance No. 2024-1852-U-E approving a 22 month and 15-day 
extension of Interim Ordinance 2024-1852-U. So ordered by a vote of 5-0.
Enactment No: Ordinance 2024-1852-U-E
17

chunks.item_title: Consider approving an amendment to the County Administrator Employment
chunks.text:

Agreement extending the term for one year through March 31, 2025 and 
increasing compensation by $600 per month to reimburse for the cost of 
additional life insurance

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation from the Solano Economic Development Corporation
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation from the Solano Economic Development Corporation 
on the small business Revolving Loan Fund program funded with Solano 
County American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Coronavirus State and Local 
Fiscal Recovery Funds (SLFRF)
Senior Management Analyst Megan Richards introduced the item. 
President of the Solano Economic Development Corporation (EDC) Chris Rico 
introduced EDC Consultant Sean Quinn and EDC Loan Program Manager Wendi 
Reed.
Mr. Quinn provided an overview of the small business Revolving Loan Fund 
program funded with Solano County American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA)
Coronavirus State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds. 
Ms. Reed provided an overview of the Revolving Loan Fund application process 
and an update of the status of applications that have been submitted.
Mr. Quinn provided an overview of the next steps for the Solano EDC with the 
Revolving Loan Fund. 
Page 6
Solano County

March 12, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question by Supervisor Hannigan regarding the definition of small 
business, Mr. Quinn stated most of the applications have been from employers 
with 1 to 5 employees. 
In response to a question by Supervisor Hannigan, regarding the $250 application 
fee, Center Director for the Napa Solano Small Business Development Center 
(Napa Solano SBDC) Tim Murrill provided an overview of the services required by 
the Napa Solano Small Business Development Center for the loan recipient to 
complete in order to receive a rebate on the $250 application fee. 
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the program. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Bijan Nasseripourtowsi commented in support of the Revolving Loan Fund
program.
B) Chairman of the Board for the Solano County Black Chamber of Commerce
Charles Lee commented in opposition to the Revolving Loan Fund program
as it is laid out, stating ARPA funding should be provided in the form of grants
to small businesses who should not be required to take on more debt.
In response to Mr. Lee's comments, Supervisor Vasquez stated the Board also 
offered a $2.3 million grant program which resulted in 265 businesses receiving 
grants in an average amount of $8,000. Supervisor Vasquez further stated the 
Revolving Loan Fund program is designed to a leave a legacy of funding that will 
stay within the community for Solano County for small businesses. 
C) Joseph Joyce submitted a letter on behalf of the Solano Black Chamber of
Commerce and commented on the changing requirements of the program.
Mr. Joyce stated the changes that have been completed have made it a
better program today than when it was launched.
Supervisor Hannigan stated the terms of the loan program were determined on 
April 26, 2022, noting there have been no changes to the program since that time. 
Supervisor 
Hannigan 
further 
stated 
today's 
presentation 
was 
regarding 
clarification of the $250 application fee and the rebate. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the program and on concerns that 
were brought forth, noting she met with multiple agencies both within and outside 
of the County, and all have indicated the Revolving Loan Fund program is a good 
program. Supervisor Williams further stated she and her staff went through the 
program extensively to ensure it was fair and inclusive.
D) Solano County Black Chamber of Commerce President Tamuri Richardson
commented in opposition to ARPA funds being used as a Revolving Loan
Fund program, noting she is not against a revolving loan fund program that is
Page 7
Solano County

March 12, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
funded through private resources, she simply believes the ARPA funds
should be used as grant opportunities. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding how often the Board 
of Supervisors will receive updates on the program, Mr. Quinn stated County staff 
will receive a monthly update. 
Supervisor Brown requested the Board of Supervisors be provided with quarterly 
updates. 
E) President of the Vacaville Chamber of Commerce Debbie Egidio commented
in support of the Revolving Loan Fund program.
F)
K Patrice Williams commented in support of the Revolving Loan Fund
program.
G) Suisun City Mayor Alma Hernandez commented in support of the Revolving
Loan Fund program.
H) Carl Vinson commented in support of the Revolving Loan Fund Program,
noting however the credit score requirement should be lowered to 530 and the
application fee should be waived.
I) Dennis Green commented on various issues.
J) Shawna Gillroy commented in support of the Revolving Loan Fund program.
K) Nikila Gibson commented in support of the Revolving Loan Fund program.
Supervisor Williams commented on the request to lower the required credit score 
to 530, stating lowering the credit score requirement to 530 falls into predatory 
lending practices. Supervisor Williams stated she would never want to put a 
person or small business in a situation where they were overextended. 
Supervisor Vasquez thanked everyone who worked on the Revolving Loan Fund 
program.
Chair Mashburn commented in support of the Revolving Loan Fund program, 
noting it will have in impact for generations.
Received
Page 8
Solano County

March 12, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
18

chunks.item_title: Receive the FY2023/24 Midyear Financial Report and consider taking action
chunks.text:
Receive the FY2023/24 Midyear Financial Report and consider taking action 
on the recommendations contained in the Report
A - Financial Variance Report FY2023/24
B - FY2023/24 Midyear Projection - General Fund
C - FY2023/24 Midyear Projection - Other Funds
D - FY2023/24 Midyear Projection - ISF & Enterprise
E - General Fund Year End Fund Balance Projection
F - FY2023/24 Midyear Appropriation Transfer Requests
G - Position Resolution
H - FY2024/25 Budget Preparation Assumptions
I - Priority Setting Status Update - Midyear
Attachments:
County Administrator Bill Emlen introduced the item.
Budget Officer Emily Combs provided an overview of the Fiscal Year 2023-24 
Midyear Financial Report. 
In response to a question by Chair Mashburn regarding the Court MOE, Assistant 
County Administrator Ian Goldberg stated there is still an allocation split in terms 
of the revenues from the courts to the County based on the activity of the courts 
and the fees that are charged. Mr. Goldberg further stated it goes back to 
legislation that has been adopted, allowing the courts to waive fees and fines 
which will impact the revenue that comes to the County, noting it is a statewide 
issue.
In response to Mr. Goldberg’s comments, Chair Mashburn stated the citizens are 
being forced to carry a cost that is mandated by the State of California (State), 
noting as far as he is aware it is illegal for the State to mandate a program and 
not fund the program. Chair Mashburn asked staff what does the County have to 
do to ensure the State is paying for the services it has mandated the County 
provide.
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn, County Counsel Bernadette 
Curry stated the Court MOE represents the County’s share of responsibility to 
maintain the facilities that the County had when those facilities were transferred 
over to the State. Ms. Curry further stated when the law was adopted that first 
transferred the court employees and then later, transferred the responsibility for 
court facilities, the State notified the counties that, in perpetuity, the counties 
would no longer have the responsibility to provide court facilities. However, 
counties will continue to have a share of the cost to maintain the facilities that 
existed at the time of transfer, also in perpetuity. Ms. Curry further stated staff can 
return to the State and request the laws be changed; however, she does not 
believe the State will agree to any of the Board’s requested changes. 
Chair Mashburn stated it was his desire to emphasize to staff and the members 
of the public of the need for an adjustment. Chair Mashburn further stated the 
County should work with the legislators to make adjustments to ensure the 
County is made whole and the State is meeting its obligations.
Page 9
Solano County

March 12, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding if there is a 
consensus that the counties are willing to come together to push for a change in 
the formula, Ms. Curry stated of the counties she has spoken with, with regards 
to the process of when the court facilities were transferred to the State, yes there 
is a consensus; however, from the State’s perspective, they relieved the County 
of the burden of providing court facilities and this is the cost that the County will 
have to pay to no longer be required to provide court facilities in perpetuity.
A discussion period was held regarding the County’s pension obligation with no 
action taken. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board: 1) approved Appropriation Transfer Requests recognizing revenues and 
transfers in various departments, and approved adjustments to existing 
appropriations in various departments; 2) adopted Resolution No. 2024-23, 
amending the List of Numbers and Classifications of Positions within Solano 
County for a net increase of 15.0 positions; 3) approved fixed asset purchases 
in the amount of $42,000 for the District Attorney, $80,000 for the Library, 
$483,231 for Probation, $178,735 for the Sheriff, $10,700 in the Sheriff Boating

chunks.item_title: Conduct a public hearing to review and consider adopting the updated Solano
chunks.text:
Conduct a public hearing to review and consider adopting the updated Solano 
County 5-Year Capital Facilities Improvement Plan for Fiscal Years 2023/24 
through 2027/28
A - CFIP FY2023/24 FY2027/28
B - Funding Recommendation FY2023-24
C - Project Updates FY2023-24
Attachments:
Director of General Services Megan Greve introduced the item and provided an 
overview of the 2023-2028 Capital Facilities Improvement Plan.
Office Coordinator Stephanie Silva provided an overview of the Capital Facilities 
Improvement Plan website. 
Capital Projects Manager Mark Hummel provided an overview of the progress of 
the various projects currently on the Capital Facilities Improvement Plan and the 
facilities' condition update.
Supervisor Vasquez recommended a workshop be held for the Board regarding a 
County facilities update. Supervisor Vasquez further stated he recommends that 
the LAFCO facility project become a priority.
Page 10
Solano County

March 12, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question by Supervisor Brown regarding the HVAC system for 
the Beck Avenue campus, Ms. Greve stated the Beck Avenue HVAC project is 
complete and the Vallejo Courthouse HVAC project is still in progress, but there 
have been temporary improvements put in place. 
Supervisor Hannigan commented on the need for photos that are more 
representative of what the County does. 
In response to a question by Supervisor Hannigan regarding if the CFIP has been 
linked to the Board Priorities, Ms. Greve stated the Board’s Priorities have been 
introduced into the CFIP, but the projects have not been linked to the priorities as 
of yet. 
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments from
the public. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board adopted the updated Solano County 5-Year Capital Facilities 
Improvement Plan for Fiscal Years 2023/24 through 2027/28. So ordered by a 
5-0 vote.

County Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff has been reviewing maps of the

further stated the situation warrants a coordinated effort among all the 
jurisdictions.
Discussion was held regarding continued homeless issues occurring in the

chunks.item_title: Consider adopting a resolution to approve a Good Neighbor Policy for
chunks.text:
Consider adopting a resolution to approve a Good Neighbor Policy for 
Development Projects in the unincorporated area of Solano County 
A - Good Neighbor Policy Resolution
Good Neighbor Policy Presentation
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item and 
provided a history of the creation of the Good Neighbor Policy (Policy) Mr. 
Bezek further stated staff is requesting a modification to the last page of the 
exhibit attached to the resolution, noting they utilized the acronym for 
Community Involvement Report (CIR) and it needs to be changed to Good 
Neighbor Report (GNR) for consistency of language throughout the 
resolution.
Supervisor Williams stated staff took into account all comments made by the 
Board of Supervisors when this item was previously brought before the 
Board. Supervisor Williams further stated this policy provides the opportunity 
for community engagement before projects are brought before the Planning 
Commission.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
Supervisor Vasquez made the following recommended amendments to the 
policy: 1) staff should provide the policy to all project applicants, including 
neighbor to neighbor situations and not only applicants for large projects; 2) 
instituting a Policy with the cities with regards to encroachment into 
agricultural areas of the unincorporated borders of the County; and 3) adding 
a disclaimer to the policy that following the Policy is not a legal requirement 
and does not imply tacit approval of a project.
Supervisor Brown stated the presentation of the Policy should be considered 
a first reading to accommodate additional recommendations from today's 
Board meeting and made the following recommended amendments to the 
Policy: 1) the Policy should clarify how many days it will take for the Director 
of Resource Management to determine how much community outreach is 
required; 2) after the application has been reviewed to determine how much 
community outreach is needed, no opinion on the project should be given by 
staff to avoid any appearance of prejudging the project; 3) amending the 
required boundary for notifications to 1/2 mile for all projects; 4) public 
outreach must be more than just a website; and 5) timing of the community 
outreach needs to be clarified in the Policy.
In response to Board Member comments Mr. Bezek stated the goal of the 
Policy is to provide as much flexibility as possible. Mr. Bezek further stated 
staff attempted to articulate that community outreach is more than just using 
a website. Mr. Bezek further stated if staff has any concerns regarding a 
project, no matter the size, they will refer the applicant to the policy. Mr. 
Bezek further stated staff can amend the policy to reflect the 1/2 mile radius 
Page 6
Solano County

March 26, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
for notification.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the Policy, noting she agrees 
that it is a recommendation and not a requirement and supports the 
recommendation to amend the policy to include completion of community 
outreach does not imply tacit approval of the project. Supervisor Hannigan 
further stated she appreciates the use of electronic notification as well as 
paper. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the following recommended 
amendments to the Policy: 1) the addition of a disclaimer to the Policy that 
completion of community outreach does not imply approval of the project; 2) 
expansion of the radius of neighborhood outreach to 1/2 mile for all projects; 
and 3) providing the Policy for all applicants no matter the size of the project.
Chair Mashburn commented in opposition to adopting a policy for the sake of 
having a policy. Chair Mashburn commented in support of the recommended 
amendments to the Policy; noting however he has concerns with the Policy 
adding additional time requirements for projects, which could deter 
development within the County. Chair Mashburn further commented in 
support of treating today as a first reading of the Policy and recommended 
staff take the comments provided by the Board today and return to the Board 
at a later date for approval with the amendments included. 
Mr. Bezek stated he does understand the concerns laid out by Chair 
Mashburn; however the creation of this policy has helped to streamline the 
process for staff and will provide a reference tool that staff can give to 
applicants. Mr. Bezek further stated additional community outreach actually 
minimizes project timelines, noting addressing community concerns ahead of 
time, should reduce potential appeals of Planning Commission decisions.
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff will return on April 23, 2024, with 
the amended policy for approval by the Board. 
Continued
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public. 
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
There were no reports from the Board.

ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing on the proposed FY2024/25 user fee
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing on the proposed FY2024/25 user fee 
schedules; and Consider adopting 20 revised fee schedules by separate 
resolutions amending the exhibits in Chapters 
2.4 and 11 of the Solano 
County Code, revising and establishing various fees, to become effective 
July 1, 2024
A - Summary of Proposed FY2024-25 Fee Changes by Department
B - Resolutions and Fee Schedules
C - Notice of Public Hearing FY24-25
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Anne Putney introduced the item and provided an 
overview of the FY2024-25 department fee update. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public to
address the Board on this matter and the following comments were received:
A) Joseph Joyce commented on the recommended fee increases, noting it
should not be a blanket approval and department fees should be required to be
reviewed 
and 
adopted 
individually. 
Mr. 
Joyce 
further 
commented 
on
Environmental Health fees for events, noting that if both non-profit and for-profit
groups are working together to create an event, the Environmental fees are not
reduced for the event hosts.
In response to public comment, Supervisor Vasquez stated each department fee 
goes through an annual review. Supervisor Vasquez further stated the fees are 
for cost recovery. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding payment of 
applications where there are both non-profit and for-profit applicants, Director of 
Resource Management James Bezek stated he will review the application 
process as it pertains to group led events.
B) George Guynn, Jr. commented on the cost of photocopies at the Recorder’s
office.
In response to public comment, Chair Mashburn commented on the process for 
producing certified documents for the public, noting the process is much more 
than simply a photocopy. 
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board adopted Resolution No. 2024-48 through Resolution 2024-67 amending 
the exhibits to Chapters 2.4 and 11 of the Solano County Code, modifying and 
establishing various fees, to become effective July 1, 2024. So ordered by a 5-0 
vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-48 thorugh Resolution No. 2024-67
Page 8
Solano County

April 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
22

chunks.item_title: Receive an update on the April 15, 2024 Legislative Committee meeting,
chunks.text:
Receive an update on the April 15, 2024 Legislative Committee meeting, 
including a verbal update from Paragon Government Relations, the County’s 
Federal 
Legislative 
Advocates 
and 
Karen 
Lange, 
the 
County’s 
State 
Legislative Advocate on legislative matters of interest to the County including 
AB 2265, AB 2561, and AB 3259 and consider taking a position; and 
Receive an update from staff on SB 1057, SB 1124, SB 1159, AB 2079 and 
AB 2882 and consider taking a position
Principal Management Analyst Matthew Davis introduced the item. 
Federal legislative advocates Joe Krahn and Hassan Sarsour provided an 
update on information on federal legislation of interest to the County. 
Chair Mashburn thanked Congressman Thomson and Congressman Garamendi 
for their continued efforts in opposition to the delta tunnel project. Chair 
Mashburn further stated he believes the County should support the Disaster 
Resiliency and Coverage Act. 
State legislative advocate Karen Lange provided an update on information on 
state legislation of interest to the County.
Supervisor Hannigan made a motion to approve a letter of support for AB 3259 - 
Increase the Sales Tax Cap in Solano County to 9.75 percent.
Discussion was held regarding AB 3259, with Supervisor Vasquez stating the 
County needs head space for a potential county-wide tax. 
Chair Mashburn requested an amendment to the legislation that provides the 
additional headspace, specifically for the County to do a regional or county-wide 
tax 1/2% tax.
Ms. Lange stated she will follow up on this request. 
Supervisor Hannigan stated she will amend her motion to include the request for 
the additional 1/2% tax.
In response to a question from Ms. Lange regarding how much head room is 
being requested, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated it will be a total of 1% 
above the 2%.
Discussion was held regarding ACA1 - Local Government Financing: Affordable 
Housing 
and 
Public 
Infrastructure: 
Voter 
Approval, 
 
ACA13 - 
Voting 
Thresholds, and the Tax Payer Government Accountability Act with no action 
taken. 
Chair Mashburn requested staff review the proposed state budget cuts and 
return to the Board with a list of those mandates that will now be unfunded due 
to a reduction in the State budget. 
Page 9
Solano County

April 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Discussion 
was 
held 
regarding 
the 
Delta 
Counties 
Coalition, 
the 
Delta 
Stewardship Council, and the Delta Tunnel project, with no action taken. 
Discussion was held regarding Assembly Bill 2319 with no action taken. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board approved a letter of opposition for AB 2265 – Animals, Spaying, 
Neutering and Euthanasia. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. 
On motion of Supervisor Brown, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the Board 
approved a letter of opposition for AB 2561 – Local Public Employees, Vacant 
Positions. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. 
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board approved a letter of support for AB 3259 – Increase the Sales Tax Cap in 
Solano County to 9.75 percent with an amendment for an additional 1%. So 
ordered by a 5-0 vote. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board 
approved a letter of opposition for SB 1057 – Juvenile Justice Coordinating 
Council. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. 
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board approved a letter of support for SB 1124 – Deceptive Practices, Service 
Members and Veterans. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. 
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board approved a letter of support for SB 1159 – California Environmental 
Quality Act, Roadside Wildfire Risk Reduction Projects. So ordered by a 5-0 
vote. 
On motion of Supervisor , seconded by Supervisor , the Board approved a 
letter of opposition for AB 2079 – Groundwater Extraction, Large-Diameter, 
High-Capacity Water Wells, Permits. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. 
On motion of Supervisor, seconded by Supervisor , the Board approved a letter 
of opposition for AB 2882 – California Community Corrections Performance 
Incentives. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
23

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation providing an update on the Early Learning Center in
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation providing an update on the Early Learning Center in 
Vallejo 
Executive Director of the First Five Children and Families Commission Michele 
Harris introduced the item and provided an overview of the need for additional 
Head Start classes and the purchase of the Beverly Hills Elementary School site.
Executive Director for Child Start, Inc. Juan Cisneros provided an overview of 
the Vallejo Early Learning Center and Community Resource Building programs. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the addition of a 
Page 10
Solano County

April 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ride-sharing location, Mr. Cisneros stated this would be the perfect example of 
peer-to-peer support, noting staff can look at creating a location for ride-sharing 
and carpooling parents. 
Solano County Superintendent of Schools Lisette Estrella-Henderson provided 
an overview of the financial commitments for the project made by various 
agencies, the project timeline, and support options that will be available to the 
community after the completion of the Community Resource Building. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding 
learning 
disabilities assessments, Ms. Estrella-Henderson stated there will be multiple 
opportunities for assessments to happen, noting it is critically important to focus 
on prevention and intervention.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the project and thanked the Syar 
Foundation for their contributions to the project.

chunks.item_title: Receive an overview of changes impacting Solano County Behavioral Health
chunks.text:
Receive an overview of changes impacting Solano County Behavioral Health 
related to new mandates and statewide directives for the delivery of services
A - Behavioral Health Presentation
Attachments:
Director of Health and Social Services Gerald Huber introduced the item.
Chief Deputy Director of Behavioral Health Emery Cowan provided an overview 
of the California Behavioral Health changes impacting counties. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the expense of housing individuals, noting 
people are going to want their own space.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding producing 
housing for individuals, Ms. Cowan stated staff tries to find different types of 
housing opportunities for people. 
A discussion period regarding the need for additional housing was held with no 
action taken. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Dennis Green commented on services provided by Solano County Behavioral
Health and on the need for more low-income housing.
B)
Tracee Stacy commented on the potential impacts of the adoption of
Page 11
Solano County

April 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Proposition 1 for the senior population.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding whether the 24/7 
Crisis Mobile Unit is operating in the City of Vallejo, Ms. Cowan stated it is 
operating and provided an explanation of the IHART program. 
Chair Mashburn commented on unfunded mandates from the State, noting that 
Solano County’s residents are going to see impacts to services that are not 
mandated by the State as Solano County has to adjust budgets to compensate 
for the unfunded mandates required by the State. Supervisor Mashburn 
requested staff provide the Board with a list of funded and unfunded mandated 
programs and a list of programs that are offered by Solano County but not 
mandated.
A discussion period was held regarding unfunded mandates with no action 
taken. 
Received
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional items from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports on
meetings. The following comments were received:
Chair Mashburn requested the Board schedule a study session in July, for status
updates on completion of the Board’s priorities list.
County Administrator Bill Emlen recommended scheduling the study session for
August 2024 due to the timing of several issues facing Solano County. 
A) Supervisor Hannigan requested that this meeting of the Solano County Board
of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Maria Macasieb and commented on
the CSAC Legislative Conference which she attended.
B)
Supervisor Williams thanked Supervisor Brown for talking her place on
ABAG, commented on her attendance at the CSAC Legislative Conference, and
announced she is the incoming President for the Black Elected Officials of
California.
C) Supervisor Brown requested that this meeting of the Solano County Board of
Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Michael Garrity and Calvin Fisk.
D) Chair Mashburn requested that this meeting of the Solano County Board of
Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Bob Powell.

ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.
