chunks.item_title: Consider introducing an ordinance repealing section
chunks.text:
Consider introducing an ordinance repealing section 
2.2-60 and amending 
section 
10-15 of 
the 
Solano 
County 
Code, 
dissolving 
the 
Agricultural 
Grievance 
Committee 
and 
clarifying 
the 
enforcement 
process 
related 
to 
agricultural grievances as a public nuisance
A - Ordinance
B - Chapter 10
Attachments:
Agricultural Commissioner/Sealer of Weights Ed King introduced the item and 
provided an overview of the proposed amendments to sections 2.2-60 and 10-15 
of the Solano County Code. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding future grievances, 
Mr. King stated after an investigation staff would follow the recommended 
process laid out in Chapter 10 of the Solano County Code. 
Supervisor Williams commented on the need to notify members of committees 
when a committee is going to be dissolved.
Supervisor Vasquez clarified that the Agricultural Grievance Committee is ad hoc 
only and there are no current members. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board: 1) read the proposed ordinance by title only and waived further reading 
by majority vote; and 2) introduced an ordinance repealing section 2.2-60 and 
amending section 10-15 of the Solano County Code, dissolving the Agricultural 
Grievance Committee and clarifying the enforcement process related to 
agricultural grievances as a public nuisance. So ordered by a vote of 5-0.
25

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation of accomplishments from recipients of American
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation of accomplishments from recipients of American 
Rescue Plan Act funds to provide and increase the capacity to provide 
emergency food services
Principal Management Analyst Anne Putney introduced the item.
Food and Nutrition Program Manager for Catholic Charities Yolo Solano Whitney 
Galindo provided an overview of the work completed by Catholic Charities Yolo 
Solano with the previously awarded American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) funding.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding EBT registrations, 
Ms. Galindo stated they have received 33 completed applications; however, she 
is uncertain of the number of individuals that have been approved. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the Client Choice 
pantry, Ms. Galindo stated the program allows clients to take time and shop the 
pantry as if it was a grocery store. 
Page 8
Solano County

May 7, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Vasquez requested staff provide information to the Board on the sites 
where the popup pantries are located.
Executive Director for Food Bank of Contra Costa and Solano Caitlin Sly provided 
an overview of the work completed by the Food Bank of Contra Costa and Solano 
with the previously awarded ARPA funding.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding local sourcing of 
produce, Ms. Sly stated ARPA funding has provided the ability to work with local 
farmers and source different produce such as multiple types of squash, beets, 
and mushrooms. 
Executive Director for Food is Free Bay Area Heather Pierini provided an 
overview of the work completed by Food is Free with the previously awarded 
ARPA funding.
In response to comments from Supervisor Williams, Ms. Pierini stated the only 
thing keeping Food is Free Bay Area from expanding is the need for more funding 
and more staffing .
Supervisor Brown commented on the need for feeding students meals for free 
during the summer.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the various food pantry programs 
offered in Solano County. 
In response to comments from Supervisor Hannigan regarding community 
gleaning, Ms. Pierini provided an overview of the Food is Free Bay Area gleaning 
program that works with local growers to provide overstock of private gardens to 
those who utilize the Food is Free Bay Area pantry.
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the various food pantry programs 
in Solano County, noting there will continue to be food insecurity until we have a 
national program for food services. 
Development Assistant for Meals on Wheels Tyler Dorman provided an overview 
of the work completed by Meals on Wheels with the previously awarded ARPA 
funding.
Chair Mashburn commented in support of the various food bank programs, noting 
food programs provide seniors in particular with not only food but a human 
connection.
Received
Page 9
Solano County

May 7, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
26

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation providing a progress update on projects funded with
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation providing a progress update on projects funded with 
Solano County American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Coronavirus State and 
Local Fiscal Recovery Funds (SLFRF); Consider providing further direction 
and take possible action on the reallocation of $2,308,628 in ARPA SLFRF;
and Delegate authority to the County administrator to sign amendments and 
other 
contractual 
agreements 
related 
to 
reallocations 
and 
ARPA 
project 
implementation for all projects 
A - ARPA Project Updates
B - ARPA Projects Not Fully Obligated
C - ARPA Funds for Realloction
Attachments:
Assistant County Administrator Ian Goldberg introduced the item.
Principal Management Analyst Megan Richards provided a status update on 
projects with allocated ARPA funding including projects that are fully obligated, 
projects that are partially obligated, and projects that will be returning funding for 
reallocation.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding how the County 
will request agencies return the unobligated funds if staff believes a specific 
project will not meet the completion deadlines, Ms. Richards stated staff will 
inquire how each agency will obtain additional funding to complete their projects 
on time, and will then return to the Board with that information for the Board to 
make a final decision.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if the broadband 
development expansion funding can be reallocated to radio interoperability if the 
allocated funding is not able to be utilized, Mr. Goldberg stated staff is focused on 
radio interoperability/broadband programs, noting if the State is not able to timely 
provide a decision, staff is ready to address the Board on the ongoing programs. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Michelle Chavez made a request for ARPA funding for the City of Suisun City
Senior Center to provide funding to make the building ADA compliant.
B) Steve Olry commented in support of the various projects and commented on
government spending.
C) George Guynn, Jr. commented on the City of Suisun City’s allocation of
ARPA funding.
D) City of Suisun City Council Member Marlon Osum made a request for an
ARPA funding allocation for the City of Suisun City Senior Center.
E) Ruth Forney commented on issues with internet services at the health clinics,
noting it causes patients to need to be rescheduled.
Page 10
Solano County

May 7, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
F) Joseph Joyce commented on the need for funding for the City of Suisun City
Senior Center and made a request for an allocation of ARPA funding for the
Solano County Fairgrounds.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding a potential 
reallocation of funding for homeless prevention, Ms. Richards stated the RFP for 
homeless prevention will be returned to the Board June 4, 2024 for an award of 
funding, noting that the Board could choose to reallocate unspent funds toward 
this homeless prevention program. 
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of reallocating funding to projects 
that are already approved by the Board such as the Vallejo Early Learning Center 
and radio interoperability as well as looking at the programs that deal with 
homeless prevention and food distributions that have proven successful. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of reallocating funding to broadband, 
radio interoperability, and central dispatch projects. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need to reallocate funding specifically to 
agencies or businesses that have been directly impacted by COVID and 
recommended staff put out a Request for Qualifications for Solano County 
Non-Profit agencies.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Chair Mashburn’s statements and 
requested funding for homeless prevention. 
On motion of Supervisor Brown, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board: 
1) approved reallocation of $100,000 from Workforce Development Board
Training Services to the Work Force Development Board Technical Assistance
Contractor and Grants for Non-Profits to Improve Business Infrastructure and
Technology; 2) approved reallocation of $150,000 from the Work-Based Mental
Health Services program to the Small Business Technical Assistance SBDC
program; 3) approved reallocation of $29,882 from the Sandy Beach
Community Water Improvements – Potable Water project to the State Small
Water System – Muni Water Connection, Rio Vista project; and 4) delegated
authority to the County Administrator to sign amendments and other
contractual agreements related to reallocations and ARPA project
implementation for all projects. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public.
Page 11
Solano County

May 7, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Vasquez invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Hannigan requested that this meeting of the Solano County
Board of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Rica Ramirez.

of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Jazmin Smith, Cassandra Summers

ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.

The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on matters
not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board.
The following comments were received:

City Manager for the City of Suisun City Bret Prebula commented on

funding.
Page 3
Solano County

May 14, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of
Supervisors' agenda for May 14, 2024.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for 
May 14, 2024. So ordered by a 4-0 vote with Supervisor Hannigan absent.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Supervisor Williams commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 12, noting she 
believes staffing could be reduced from 6 employees to 4 employees.
Chair Mashburn commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 13, noting the Board 
takes the County's unfunded pension liability seriously, and the County is 
working to pay down the pension debt.
County Administrator Bill Emlen commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 13, 
noting the Treasurer has worked diligently to pay down the County’s pension 
debt. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the creation of the PARS 115 
Policy.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board approved the following Consent Calendar items by a 4-0 vote with 
Supervisor Hannigan absent:

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing; Determine that the vacation and parcel
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing; Determine that the vacation and parcel 
transfer of a portion of Liberty Island Road (County Road No. 1490) is 
consistent with the Solano County General Plan; and Adopt a Resolution of 
Conditional Vacation to authorize the Director of Resource Management to 
execute all necessary documents to conditionally vacate a portion of Liberty 
Island Road including the transfer of properties to the State of California (4/5 
vote required)
Page 7
Solano County

May 14, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
A - Vacation Petition
B - Site Map
C - General Plan Consistency Memo
D - Public Hearing Resolution 2024-47
E - Resolution to Conditionally Vacate Liberty Island Road
F - DWR Letter of Succession and Support
G - PUBLIC NOTICE for Liberty Island Rd Vacation
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item. 
Engineering Manager Mathew Tuggle provided an overview of the proposed 
vacation of Liberty Island Road. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if the federal 
funding that will be returned to the County when the Shag Slough Bridge is 
decommissioned could be used to repair the Main Prairie Bridge, Mr. Tuggle 
stated yes it could be. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding what happens after 
the vacation of Liberty Island Road, Mr. Tuggle stated the projects that will result 
from the vacation of Liberty Island Road will provide flood control benefits to the 
County. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated there are certain requirements under the 
current State water project, where the State is required to provide thousands of 
acres of habitat restoration. Mr. Emlen further stated that this is an area that 
they have identified as a good candidate based on the physical geography. Mr. 
Emlen further stated, staff in the past has not been in favor of projects like this 
one, particularly if they impact agriculture; however, staff determined this was a 
project that is beneficial to the County.
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the recommended action, noting it 
will benefit the County with additional habitat areas.
Supervisor Mashburn commented in support of the recommended action, noting 
it is a good project for Solano County’s ecosystem as well as flood control.
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments from
the public.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board: 1) determined that the vacation and parcel transfer of a portion of 
Liberty Island Road (County Road No. 1490) is consistent with the Solano 
County General Plan; and 2) adopted Resolution No. 2024-90, a Resolution of 
Conditional Vacation which authorizes the Director of Resource Management 
to execute all necessary documents to conditionally vacate a portion of Liberty 
Island Road, including the transfer of property to the State of California (4/5 
vote required). So ordered by a 4-0 vote with Supervisor Hannigan absent. (see 
Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-90
Page 8
Solano County

May 14, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
22

provided an overview of the reorganization of the Treasurer’s Department. Mr. 
Lomeli introduced Denise Dix as the new Assistant Treasurer, Tax Collector, 
County Clerk. Mr. Lomeli further stated he plans to hire a financial advisor for 
the County to review the Treasurer's processes and procedures, provide

Supervisor Brown commented in support of the recommended action.

On motion of Supervisor Brown, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board:

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation; and Adopt a resolution to accept and adopt the new
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation; and Adopt a resolution to accept and adopt the new 
Solano County Emergency Operations Plan, superseding the Solano County 
2017 Emergency Operations Plan
A - Operational Area Emergency Operations Plan Resolution
B - Links to Solano County EOP Files
Attachments:
Emergency Services Manager Robyn Rains introduced the item.
Emergency Services Coordinator Christina De Leon provided an overview of the 
2024 Solano County Emergency Operations Plan.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the implementation 
of the Access and Functional Needs portion of the plan, Ms. Rains stated this 
portion of the plan will take into consideration the social equity needs of Solano 
County, noting from the beginning of a disaster to full recovery the County is 
considering its Access and Functional needs populations as well as cultural 
competencies and the differences in cultural populations in the County. Ms. 
Page 9
Solano County

May 14, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Rains further noted this is to ensure the County represents all communities 
during event responses and builds relationships with all community leaders. 
A discussion was held regarding the various populations under Access and 
Functional Needs. Ms. Rains stated it includes the elderly, foster communities, 
people of color, populations where English is the second language, schools, and 
the physically disabled. 
Supervisor Williams thanked staff for including cultural competencies in the 
program noting this will help break down barriers. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the hazard appendices and requested staff 
include plans for the following potential issues in future updates: a possible 
derailment of a train, potential grid failure, and Travis Air Force Base (Travis 
AFB) wartime mobilization. 
In response to Chair Mashburn’s comments, Ms. Rains stated the County has a 
separate Hazardous Materials plan, noting staff participated in a training 
exercise with Amtrak for potential train derailment and terrorism responses. Ms. 
Rains commented that a power grid failure would be under utility disruptions, 
noting if there is not a section dealing with power grid failure already in the plan, 
then one will be added during updates as the Emergency Operations Plan is a 
living document that is reviewed and updated regularly. Ms. Rains further stated 
she would contact Travis AFB to see if the base would provide any information 
on their plans. Ms. Rains further stated planning for multi-casualty incidents is 
already occurring through Travis AFB. 
In response to comments from Supervisor Vasquez regarding mass-casualty 
incidents, Ms. Rains stated the Coroner’s office is already doing mass fatality 
planning, and the County is working with the mortuaries and hospitals on plans 
to house the deceased if needed. Ms. Rains further stated additionally the 
County has a mobile morgue refrigerated trailer. 
Chair Mashburn requested staff please include the State-run correctional 
facilities in future tabletop exercise scenarios.
In response to comments from Supervisor Brown regarding a total shutdown of 
technology, Ms. Rains stated the in the event that the County is facing a total 
shutdown of technology, it would be working with the State and federal 
government; noting however that the County also does have its own plans in 
place for these types of incidents. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board adopted Resolution No. 2024-93 accepting and adopting the new Solano 
County Emergency Operations Plan, superseding the 2017 Solano County 
Emergency Operations Plan. So ordered by a 4-0 vote with Supervisor 
Hannigan absent. (see Resolution Book)
Page 10
Solano County

May 14, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-93
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional items from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports on
meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Williams requested that this meeting of the Solano County Board
of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Patricia Lucky.
B) Supervisor Brown commented on her daughter’s graduation from college.
C)
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the Solano County Arts Council
appointments. Supervisor Vasquez further stated he and Supervisor Brown will
continue to review the County's Boards and Commissions.
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the Solano County Arts Council is a
separate nonprofit that the Board of Supervisors did not form; therefore,
appointments to its Board of Directors are no longer under the Board of
Supervisors’ jurisdiction. 
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 11:31 
A.M. Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be June 4,
2024, at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, Fairfield, California.
________________________________
MITCH H. MASHBURN, Chair
Solano County Board of Supervisors
BILL EMLEN, Clerk
Solano County Board of Supervisors
By ______________________________
Alicia Draves, Chief Deputy Clerk

ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider adopting a resolution to approve
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider adopting a resolution to approve 
Lot Line Adjustment application LLA-24-01 by Darlene Lum & Charles F. Lum 
Family Limited Partnership and Bains Farms LLC to transfer 19.72 acres of 
property from Lum to Bains and to rescind and replace Land Conservation 
Contract Nos. 838 and 1199, located along Rockville Road, one-mile west of 
the City of Fairfield, within the Suisun Valley Agriculture “A-SV-20” zoning 
district, APN’s 0027-030-150, 0027-251-280, and 0027-030-030; the Project is 
exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act pursuant to CEQA 
Guidelines 
§15268 and 
§15317 relating 
to 
ministerial 
projects 
and 
the 
establishment of land conservation contracts
A - Resolution LLA-24-01 (Lum and Bains)
B - Maps
C - Williamson Act Contract No. 1386
D - Williamson Act Contract No. 1387
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Senior Planner Eric Wilberg provided an overview of the recommended action to 
approve a lot line adjustment application. 
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments from
the public.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding why this item 
wasn’t able to be heard at the Planning Commission level, Mr. Wilberg stated 
items like this would typically go before the Zoning Administrator; however, 
because this particular item involves Williamson Act contracts, it is required to go 
before the Board of Supervisors for approval.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2024-105 to approve Lot Line Adjustment Application 
LLA-24-01, rescind Land Conservation Contract Nos. 838 and 1199, and approve 
replacement Land Conservation Contract Nos. 1386 and 1387. So ordered by a 
5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-105
Page 9

Board of Supervisors

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on the progress of the Fairground Channel project
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on the progress of the Fairground Channel project 
and other infrastructure projects funded with American Rescue Plan Act 
funds 
A - Fairgrounds Channel
B - Infrastructure Project Status
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Water and Natural Resources Manager Misty Kaltreider provided an overview of 
the progress and completion of water infrastructure projects funded by American 
Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) funding. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding who will be 
monitoring the habitat for the Fairgrounds Channel Drainage Improvement 
project, Ms. Kaltreider stated it will depend on what the regulatory agencies 
require and how the requirements can be incorporated into maintenance plan. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the projects that are being 
completed with ARPA funds. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding why the County 
cannot dig a ditch going straight across the property directly to Lake Chabot, Mr . 
Bezek stated Resource Management did study that as part of the Specific Plan; 
however, connectivity would create a bifurcation of the site. Mr. Bezek further 
stated by separating the two, Solano County will be able to capture the multiple 
inundations to the site and additionally, it will create an amenity for the site while 
also solving a problem.
Received
31

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on funding related to the Community Investment
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on funding related to the Community Investment 
Fund; Consider approval of a recommendation to allocate up to $1,400,000 
from the Community Investment Fund Deep Programming category and 
$1,200,000 from All Home for a total contract amount of $2,600,000 for a term 
of July 1, 2024 through June 30, 2026 to United Way California Capital Region 
for 
homelessness 
prevention 
services; 
Consider 
approval 
of 
a 
recommendation to allocate up to $365,000 from the Community Investment 
Fund One-Time Investments to six agencies for a term of July 1, 2024-June 
30, 2025 for annual grants to address the top six human services need in the 
County; 
and 
Delegate 
authority 
to 
the 
County 
Administrator, 
with 
the 
concurrence of County Counsel, to sign resulting contracts
Executive Director of First Five Solano Michele Harris introduced the item. 
Deputy Director for First Five Solano Denise Winters provided an overview of the 
Community Investment Fund Homelessness Prevention Services proposals.
Contract and Program Specialist Gene Ibe provided an overview of the annual 
grant funding recommendations for programs that meet the top 6 priorities in the 
County’s Health Services Needs Assessment. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the low funding 
amount of $25,000, Ms. Ibe stated the majority of the requesting agencies have 
requested more than $25,000 and most of the agencies are also leveraging 
funding from other sources. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding updates on the 
programs, Ms. Winters stated staff will provide annual updates.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Senior Counsel for Public Policy and Advocacy for the United Way California
Capitol Region Ejiro Okoro, commented in support of the recommended action.
B) George Guynn, Jr. commented in opposition to the recommended action.
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board: 1) approved an allocation of up to $1,400,000 from the Community 
Investment Fund Deep Programming category and $1,200,000 from All Home 
for a total contract amount of $2,600,000 for a term of July 1, 2024 through June 
30, 2026 to United Way California Capital Region for homelessness prevention 
services; 2) approved an allocation of up to $365,000 from the Community 
Page 11
Solano County

June 4, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Investment Fund One-Time Investments to the following six agencies for a term 
of July 1, 2024-June 30, 2025: The Children’s Network in the amount of $75,000, 
Bay Area Community Resources in the amount of $25,000, Parents by Choice in 
the amount of $50,000, Touro University in the amount of $75,000, Food is Free 
in the amount of $75,000, and Fighting Back Partnership in the amount of 
$65,000; and 3) delegated authority to the County Administrator, with the 
concurrence of County Counsel, to sign resulting contracts. So ordered by a 
5-0 vote.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Hannigan requested that this meeting of the Solano County
Board of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Dennis Clemente and Vicky
Scopesi.
B) Supervisor Vasquez requested that this meeting of the Solano County
Board of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Albert Klotz, Julia
Carrington, Angelina King, Elisa Reyes, and Frank Molina.
Supervisor Vasquez thanked Supervisor Hannigan for bringing forth the Gun 
Violence Awareness Month resolution.
Chair Mashburn commented on the need for elected officials to learn to work 
together for the betterment of all of our communities. 
Supervisor Williams commented on a family tragedy related to gun violence. 
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 11:49 
A.M. Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be June
11, 2024 at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, Fairfield,
California.

and

a 
resolution 
recognizing 
June 
2024 as 
National

Attachments:
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board adopted and presented Resolution No. 2024-107, recognizing June 2024 
as National Homeownership Month in Solano County. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. 
(see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-107
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on matters
not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board.
The following comments were received:
A)
George Guynn, Jr. commented on the protection of 2nd Amendment rights
and the June 4, 2024, presentation of a resolution for Gun Violence Awareness
Month.
Supervisor Hannigan commented on the Gun Violence Awareness Month
resolution that the Board presented on June 4, 2024, noting that she did not at
any time advocate for the removal of the right to own a firearm. 
B) Solano County Veteran Resource Center Coordinator Amy Kennedy provided
an invitation to the Solano Community College Student Women Veterans
Recognition Day Open House on June 12, 2024.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated due to timing issues for Metropolitan
Transportation Commission Commissioner Jim Spering, staff is requesting the
Board hear Agenda Item No. 15 , as the first item on the Regular Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for 
June 11, 2024, as amended. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items
listed on the Consent Calendar. The following comments were received:
Supervisor Hannigan commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 5, stating she
has concerns about the term of the agreement being too short.
Page 2
Solano County

Board of Supervisors

ready to be signed; however, due to the fair taking place next week, they will be
unable to get it finalized before the end of the contract term which is June 30,
2024.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of Consent Calendar Item No. 9. 
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR

Board approved the following Consent Calendar items by 5-0 vote:

chunks.item_title: Receive
chunks.text:
Receive 
a 
verbal 
update 
from 
Metropolitan 
Transportation 
Commission 
(MTC) Commissioner Jim Spering on MTC, including the Bay Area Housing 
Finance Authority, which is considering placing the Bay Area Affordable 
Housing Bond on the November 2024 ballot; and Receive a verbal update 
from 
Paragon 
Government 
Relations, 
the 
County’s 
federal 
legislative 
advocates, and from Shaw Yoder Antwih Schmelzer & Lange (SYASL) the 
County’s State legislative advocate, on legislative matters of interest to the 
County; and Receive an overview from staff and SYASL on California 
Initiative 1935, the Taxpayer Protection and Government Accountability Act
(2024) (21-0042A1) and provide staff with direction
A - BAHFA Bond Summary
B - BAHFA Solano Bond Estimate
C - CCCCs BAHFA Presentation Slides
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Matthew Davis introduced the item.
Metropolitan Transportation Commission 
(MTC) Commissioner Jim Spering 
provided an overview of the Bay Area Housing Finance Authority (BAHFA) Bay 
Area Affordable Housing Bond measure. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the BAHFA Bay Area Affordable 
Housing Bond measure. Supervisor Williams requested staff return with a 
presentation to the Board from BAHFA regarding this program.
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the BAHFA Bay Area Affordable 
Housing Bond measure.
Chair Mashburn commented in support of the BAHFA Bay Area Affordable 
Housing Bond measure.
Commissioner Spering provided a brief overview of the MTC review of Plan Bay 
Area 2050, the withdrawal of Senate Bill 1031, and funding issues for 
transportation throughout the Bay Area. 
Federal legislative advocates Joe Krahn and Hassan Sarsour provided an 
update on information on federal legislation of interest to the County. 
Page 5
Solano County

June 11, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding a requested earmark 
for Markley Lane, Mr. Krahn stated the earmark for the Markley Lane Extension 
Project has been submitted by Congressman Garamendi in the amount of 
$5,000,000 and 
it 
is 
currently 
with 
the 
Transportation 
and 
Appropriation 
Committee. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the current Farm Bill, noting there needs to 
be a bipartisan solution to issues states are facing in agriculture. 
Chair Mashburn thanked Congressman Garamendi and the City of Fairfield for 
putting forward the earmark request for the Markley Lane Extension Project. 
State legislative advocate Paul Yoder provided an update on information on 
state legislation of interest to the County.
Mr. Davis provided an overview of CA Initiative 1935.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding what agency would 
be responsible for paying for elections that might be required as a result of CA 
Initiative 1935, Mr. Yoder stated the local agencies would be responsible for the 
required elections. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the case before 
the Supreme Court on impact fees, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the 
Supreme Court has already ruled on that case issuing a decision requiring a 
certain level of analysis with regard to the impacts, noting local agencies will 
have to show the true impact of the nexus of what they are collecting as to the 
impact of the services provided. 
Ms. Curry further stated CA Initiative 1935 is still pending before the Supreme 
Court which has not yet made a decision on the argument of constitutional 
overreach. Ms. Curry further stated it is appropriate that the Board take action 
on the item today; however, there is a possibility it will not actually make it to the 
ballot.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in opposition to CA Initiative 
1935 and 
recommended the Board send a letter of opposition to the initiative. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) George Guynn, Jr. commented on various pieces of legislation related to
increased taxes.
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board approved a letter of opposition for California Initiative 1935, the 
Taxpayer Protection and Government Accountability Act (2024) (21-0042A1). So 
ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Page 6
Solano County

June 11, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
13

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider the Planning Commission’s
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider the Planning Commission’s 
recommendation of approval of Zone Text amendment ZT-20-01 and Minor 
Use 
Permit 
application 
MU-20-05 by 
Rakesh 
and 
Priya 
Vij 
to 
include 
Automobile, Mobile Home, Recreational Vehicle, Truck or Boat Sales Lots as 
a 
conditionally 
permitted 
land 
use 
within 
the 
Residential-Traditional 
Community Mixed Use (R-TC-MU) zoning district and establish a Vehicle 
Sales Lot located at 4912 Central Way, adjacent to the City of Fairfield within 
the R-TC-MU zoning district; APN’s 0044-080-040, 410, and 420; Adopt an 
ordinance to approve Zone Text amendment ZT-20-01; Adopt a resolution to 
approve Minor Use Permit MU-20-05; The project is exempt from the 
California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant to CEQA Guidelines 
§15301 and §15304
A - Zone Text Ordinance
B - BOS Resolution MU-20-05
C - Planning Commission Resolution 4732
D - Vij Project Maps
E - Land Use Consistency Analysis
F - ALUC Resolution 24-05
G - Public Notice
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Senior Planner Eric Willberg provided an overview of the recommended action 
to approve a lot line adjustment application. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding why this item 
wasn’t able to be heard at the Planning Commission level, Mr. Wilberg stated 
items like this would typically go before the Zoning Administrator; however, 
because this particular item involves Williamson Act contracts, it is required to 
go before the Board of Supervisors for approval.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding the division of 
sales tax when a portion of the property resides within the unincorporated 
County and a portion of the property resides in the city, Mr. Emlen stated taxes 
are decided based on the point of sale which would be on the parcel that is 
within the unincorporated County. 
In response to comments from Supervisor Hannigan regarding the need for 
information on the division of taxes when a property is in both a city and the 
unincorporated County, Mr. Emlen stated staff can add that information to future 
reports. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding if this project will 
impact any of the current projects for Hwy 680, Hwy 80 and Hwy 12, Mr. Wilberg 
stated he will look into it and provide information to the Board. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding landscaping 
requirements, Mr. Wilberg stated a landscaping plan was submitted with the 
Page 7
Solano County

June 11, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
application, noting drought tolerant and native species plants are in the 
landscaping plan.
Supervisor Hannigan recommended staff create a plan for the future regarding 
landscaping on County properties. 
In response to comments from Supervisor Vasquez, Mr. Emlen stated based on 
comments by the Board staff will work with the applicant on putting in drought 
resistant landscaping. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing.
A)
Representative 
for 
the 
applicant 
Robert 
Karn 
commented 
on 
the
recommended action, noting it is a relocation of a current facility. Mr. Karn stated
the applicant will be selling trucks only and all sales will take place on the parcel
that is within the unincorporated County boundaries. Mr. Karn further stated the
property within the City of Fairfield is for stormwater management only.
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on signage along the highway and the potential 
for revenue from advertising, recommending staff look into if there is a 
prohibition on signage along the highways in Solano County. 
In response to Supervisor Vasquez’s comments, Mr. Calder stated a proposal 
for a series electronic billboards along Highway 80 and Highway 505 was 
recently before the Airport Land Use Committee. 
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board: 1) read the proposed ordinance by title only: An ordinance amending 
Chapter 28 Section 28.32 of the Solano County Code (Zoning Regulations) to 
include automobile, mobile home, recreational vehicle, truck, or boat sales lot 
as a conditionally permitted land use within the Residential-Traditional 
Community Mixed Use Zoning District Application No. Zt-20-01; 2) waived 
further reading by majority vote; 3) adopted Ordinance No. 2024-1855 to 
approve Zone Text amendment ZT-20-01; and 4) adopted Resolution No. 
2024-109 approving Minor Use Permit MU-20-05. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Enactment No: Ordinance 2024-1855 and Resolution No. 2024-109
14

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on the P25 public safety radio expansion project;
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on the P25 public safety radio expansion project; 
Consider approval of a contract with Motorola Solutions for $5,547,613 for a 
term of July 1, 2024 through June 30, 2027 to complete the Solano South 
Simulcast 
P25 public 
safety 
radio 
expansion; 
Consider 
approval 
of 
an 
agreement with CellSite Solutions, LLC, for $172,446 for purchase of a 
public safety radio shelter for the Benicia Southampton tower site; and 
Delegate authority to the County Administrator to sign the contracts and any 
subsequent amendments, with County Counsel concurrence, up to $74,999 
of the contract amount within annual appropriations
A - Motorola Contract
B - Cellsite Contract
Attachments:
Page 8
Solano County

June 11, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Chief Information Officer/Registrar of Voters Tim Flanagan introduced the item 
and provided an overview of the importance of modernizing the current radio 
system, the County’s VHF system, and the state of the County’s current P25 
solution. 
Regional Services IT Manager Stuart Bruce provided an overview of the future 
of the P25 public safety radio expansion project.
In 
response 
to 
a 
question 
from 
Supervisor 
Vasquez 
regarding 
if 
the 
Southhampton Radio Shelter is anchored down with a foundation, Mr. Bruce 
stated he is uncertain; however, it would take hurricane force winds to move it. 
Mr. Flanagan provided an overview of the opportunities that will be afforded to 
the County once all agencies are on a single network. Mr. Flanagan provided 
overview of potential future phases of the P25 public safety radio expansion 
project.
Supervisor Vasquez thanked staff for their efforts on the completion of the 
project, noting investment in this project is critical to making the system work.
Supervisor Hannigan stated this is a great step forward to the creation of a 
consolidated dispatch.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding coverage of 
Hiddenbrook and Lake Herman Road at Columbus Parkway Mr. Bruce stated 
the Hiddenbrook area is covered by the current system. Mr. Bruce further stated 
there are possible gaps in coverage in the area along Lake Herman Road. Mr. 
Bruce noted that some areas might have limited coverage, but will not show up 
on the map because they don’t meet the 95% success rate that is required for 
an area to be considered as having full coverage. Mr. Bruce stated he will 
provide the Board with maps that specifically show the Hiddenbrook area 
coverage.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board: 1) approved a contract with Motorola Solutions for $5,547,613 for a term 
of July 1, 2024 through June 30, 2027 to complete the Solano South Simulcast 
P-25 public safety radio expansion; 2) approved an agreement with CellSite
Solutions, LLC, for $172,446 for purchase of a public safety radio shelter for
the Benicia Southampton tower site; and 3) delegated authority to the County

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation from recipients of American Rescue Plan Act funds
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation from recipients of American Rescue Plan Act funds 
to increase capacity to serve people experiencing homelessness
Principal Management Analyst Megan Richards introduced the item.
Assistant to the City Manager for the City of Vallejo Natalie Peterson thanked 
the Board for the allocation of funding for the two City of Vallejo projects. Ms. 
Peterson provided a progress update on the Broadway Homekey project.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the disbursement of 
funding for the Broadway Homekey project, Ms. Peterson stated with the current 
funding projection, the additional funding provided by the City of Vallejo was an 
overestimate to provide a buffer for any potential time delays, noting the City of 
Vallejo wanted to make sure that there was more funding allocated than what 
was needed, with the intention of returning any unspent Measure P funds. Ms. 
Peterson further stated that all allocated ARPA funds will be expended by 
December 30, 2026. Ms. Peterson stated staff will continue to communicate with 
the Board if there are any issues or delays with the project. 
Homeless Services Manager for the City of Fairfield Samantha Burrows thanked 
the Board for the allocation of funding for the Beck Avenue Navigation Center. 
Ms. Burrows provided a progress update on the Beck Avenue Navigation 
Center.
Ms. Richards provided an update on the progress and purchase of a house for 
My Friend’s House, noting the goal of this project was to purchase the house, 
which has been met. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if there was a 
deed restriction on the purchase of the house, Ms. Richards stated she does not 
know if there was a deed restriction placed on the house; however, she does 
know there was a contract restriction to be a shelter for a certain period of time. 
Supervisor Hannigan thanked the agencies for bringing forward updates on the 
projects, noting that they will provide housing and services to those who need it 
most. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the Beck Avenue Navigation Center Culinary 
Institute and requested updates be provided to the Board on services that are 
provided. 
Supervisor Mashburn thanked the County’s partners for bringing the projects 
forward, staff for ensuring the projects are moving forward, and the Board for 
approving investments in the community that will help people.
Supervisor Williams requested updates on the progress of the Beck Avenue 
Navigation Center. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
Page 10
Solano County

June 11, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
matter. There was no public comment.
Received
17

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation providing a progress update on projects funded with
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation providing a progress update on projects funded with 
Solano County American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Coronavirus State and 
Local Fiscal Recovery Funds (SLFRF); Consider providing further direction 
and take possible action on the reallocation of $7,116,747 in ARPA SLFRF;
and Delegate authority to the County administrator to sign amendments and 
other contractual agreements related to the reallocations 
A - Draft Terms for Possible RFQ
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Megan Richards introduced the item and 
provided an update on projects with pending obligation deadlines. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the Housing Trust Fund 
agricultural housing project. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the eligibility of 
non-profit agencies that have already received funding, Ms. Richards stated the 
Board will be able to provide direction on the Request for Qualifications/Request 
for Proposals (RFQ/RFP) guidelines. 
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of all non-profits being eligible for 
funding but noted that she has concerns regarding the $500,000 amount of 
funding that is being recommended. 
In 
response 
to 
Supervisor 
Hannigan’s 
comments, 
Assistant 
County 
Administrator Ian Goldberg stated it was intended to be up to $500,000 awards, 
depending on the applicants and the projects proposed, noting there may be 
several smaller requests or one large request.
In response to Mr. Goldberg’s comments, Ms. Richards stated the reason why 
the amount of $500,000 was chosen was because staff was aware of several 
projects that had been previously submitted that would be large one-time funded 
projects. 
Supervisor 
Mashburn 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
releasing 
an 
RFQ/RFP.
Supervisor Mashburn further stated he would like to see preference given for 
proposals that have public/private partnerships to leverage funding.
Supervisor Brown commented in support of allocating additional funding toward 
food security or rental assistance programs.
Supervisor 
Vasquez 
requested 
a 
spreadsheet 
at 
future 
presentations. 
Supervisor Vasquez requested the discussion be continued to June 25, 2024 so 
the Board has more information.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if the funding that 
Page 11
Solano County

June 11, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
has been allocated to the Tabor Commons project must have Board approval to 
be reallocated, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the Board will 
eventually need to take action on the funding because the Board did allocate 
those funds specifically to the Tabor Commons project. Ms. Curry further stated 
today staff is asking for Board direction on where to reallocate those funds, 
noting that staff will then bring back an item for the Board to take action on.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of allocating funding to nonprofit 
agencies, rental assistance programs and for the purchase of the Parkrose 
Gardens project. 
Supervisor Mashburn made a motion to allocate $1,000,000 to an RFP/RFQ for 
nonprofit agencies with no cap for the project amount. 
Supervisor Hannigan made an alternate motion to allocate $500,000 to an 
RFP/RFQ for nonprofit agencies with no cap for the project amount per the 
recommended action.
Ms. Richards stated the recommended action was for up to $500,000 per project 
allocation over 2 years, with no recommendation on the amount of funding 
allocated by the Board for the RFP/RFQ.
A discussion period was held with no action taken. 
Ms. Richards provided information on potential homeless prevention programs 
and on a potential permanent supportive housing project called Parkrose 
Gardens.
Deputy Director of Behavioral Health Emery Cowan provided an overview of the 
current mandates that will require the County to provide residential and 
permanent supportive housing. Ms. Cowan stated the Parkrose Gardens project 
will provide 52 single unites or 104 double occupancy units. Ms. Cowan noted 
that ongoing costs will be covered by Prop 1 funding, noting that they are now 
required to use 30% of the Prop 1 funding for housing which will help sustain 
residential beds. 
Chair Mashburn commented on potential staffing and funding issues with the 
purchase of Parkrose Gardens, requesting staff provide more information to the 
Board.
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn’s comments, Ms. Cowan 
provided an overview of potential funding options to pay for ongoing expenses of 
the facility should the County purchase it. 
Discussion was held with no action taken. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding potential fines if the 
County does not have residential housing, Ms. Cowan provided a list of 
mandates that will be going into affect that will require the County to provide 
Page 12
Solano County

June 11, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
housing. 
Supervisor Hannigan and Supervisor Williams commented in support of staff 
returning with more information on the ongoing costs of purchasing the Parkrose 
Gardens facility.
County Administrator Bill Emlen provided options that the Board could vote on 
today, noting the Board could vote on reallocating funding into Revenue 
Recovery and provide direction to staff regarding the RFP/RFQ for nonprofits.
A discussion period was held. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) George Guynn, Jr. commented in opposition to the use of funds for homeless
housing.
B) City of Suisun City City Manager Bret Prebula made a request for ARPA
funding for the refurbishment of the City of Suisun City Senior Center to be
potentially used as a navigation center.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Mr. Prebula’s request noting that 
the City of Suisun City has not previously requested any ARPA funding from the 
County.
Supervisor Hannigan and Chair Mashburn withdrew their previous motions.

chunks.text:

Tulabut as “Employee of the Month” for July 2024
Received
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on 
matters not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of 
the Board. The following comments were received:
A) Mindful commented on the need for more behavioral health services and
Rescue Plan Service funding.
B) George Guynn, Jr. commented on various issues.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of 
Supervisors' agenda for June 25, 2024.
Page 2
Solano County

June 25, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board 
approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for June 25, 
2024 as submitted. So ordered by a 4-0 vote with Supervisor Williams absent.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items 
listed on the Consent Calendar. The following comments were received:
A) George Guynn, Jr. commented on Consent Calendar Items Nos. 16 and
33.
County Administrator Bill Emlen commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 
33, noting that the amount requested to be written off is a culmination of 12 
years of attempting to collect the unpaid fees. Mr. Emlen stated the County 
has exhausted all means of being able to collect this debt.
Chair Mashburn commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 30 and presented 
Renee Gutierrez with a retirement resolution.
Supervisor Hannigan thanked Ms. Gutierrez for her hard work with the feral 
cat community in Solano County.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board approved the following Consent Calendar items by 4-0 vote with 
Supervisor Williams absent:

chunks.item_title: Receive a report on the Solano County
chunks.text:
Receive a report on the Solano County 
2023 Index of Economic and 
Community Progress
A - 2023 Index Report
B - 2023 Index Presentation
Attachments:
Principle Management Analyst Matthew Davis introduced the item.
Dr. Robert Eyler provided an overview of the Solano County 2023 Index of 
Economic and Community progress.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on advances in technology for agricultural 
uses and how this change over will relate to the agricultural labor industry.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding labor concerns in 
the construction industry, Dr. Eyler stated construction labor numbers are a 
mystery because of multiple factors including a generational turnover in 
general contractors as well as a lack of more people going into the field. 
Discussion was held regarding how agricultural workers will be able to obtain 
technological training in the future with Dr. Eyler stating there will need to be 
additional trainings offered at trade schools.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding the potential 
loss of the middle class specifically within the BIPOC community, Dr. Eyler 
stated inflation has impacted all households, but not all BIPOC households 
the same way, noting Hispanic households saw an increase in the median 
household income. 
Discussion was held regarding how technology will affect job loss and how to 
retain both a population of workers living in Solano County.
Discussion was held regarding housing prices in Solano County and the 
market for investors.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding building only 
affordable housing, Dr. Eyler stated without additional high-end housing being 
built Solano County will not be able to attract high-wage earners who work in 
fields such as medicine. 
Discussion was held regarding how low birth rates are affecting Solano 
County. Dr. Eyler stated Solano County has a better forecast in terms of 
population growth, which means the birth rates will probably pick up a little bit 
over the next 15 years. Dr. Eyler noted, however, that the effects of overall 
lower birth rates will begin to show itself in having fewer high school 
graduates, further stating this means fewer individuals entering the job market 
and fewer people to support those on Social Security.
Chair Mashburn stated the Board needs to look at how it can generate 
general fund dollars and how it does business going forward.
Page 12
Solano County

June 25, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding requesting a 
presentation from the Solano Economic Development Corporation, County 
Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff will follow up on the request for a 
presentation.
Received
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Hannigan requested that this meeting of the Solano County
Board of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Suzanne Connelly and
provided an overview of the CSAC Regional Conference she attended.

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation from the Registrar of Voters on the results of the
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation from the Registrar of Voters on the results of the 
signature verification process as set forth in the Elections Code for the 
“Rezoning of 17,500 acres of land in East Solano to allow the Development of 
a New Community” (also known as California Forever) initiative petition and 
the certified statement of sufficiency of the petition; and Take one of the 
following actions: (1) adopt the ordinance without alteration, (2) submit the 
ordinance without alteration to voters at the November 
5, 2024 general 
election, or (3) order a report on the initiative petition to be submitted within 30 
days
A - Certificate of Sufficiency and Calculation Worksheet
B - Resolution Calling for Special Election
C - Notice of Intent and Request for Summary
D - Link to Full Initiative
E - Ballot Title and Summary
F - Proof of Publication
Attachments:
County Administrator Bill Emlen introduced the item. 
Assistant Registrar of Voters John Gardner provided an overview of the 
Registrar of Voters methodology of certifying the results of the signature 
examination. 
Mr. Emlen provided an overview of the Board’s options including adopting the 
initiative as is, adopting a resolution to place a measure on the November 
2024 ballot, and ordering a report assessing the impacts of the initiative 
before placing it on the ballot. Mr. Emlen further provided an overview of what 
information the impact report will provide and why an impact report is 
important. 
Chair Mashburn commented in support of ordering an impact report.
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of ordering an impact report.
Supervisor Brown commented in support of ordering an impact report.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of ordering an impact report and

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on options for the potential consolidation of the
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on options for the potential consolidation of the 
County’s financial management structure into an appointed Office of Director 
of Finance pursuant to Government Code section 26980 and provide policy 
direction on potential next steps
Minute Order
Attachments:
County Administrator Bill Emlem introduced the item and provided and overview 
of the recommended options. 
Treasurer/Tax Collector/County Clerk Charles Lomeli commented in support of 
Option No. 1. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Retired Auditor-Controller Phyllis Taynton commented in support of Option
No. 1.
B) George Guynn, Jr. commented in support of Option No. 1.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Option No. 1.
Supervisor Brown commented in support of Option No. 1. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of Option No. 1.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of Option No. 2, noting no one has 
asked the voters previously if they would prefer the positions of Auditor-Controller 
and Treasurer/Tax Collector to be appointed or elected. Supervisor Hannigan 
made a motion for the Board to approve Option 2.
Chair Mashburn commented in support of Option 2 and seconded Supervisor 
Hannigan’s motion.
Page 8
Solano County

July 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Williams submitted a substitute motion for the Board to approve 
Option 1. Supervisor Brown seconded the motion. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez on if Option 2 is an advisory 
question, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated all the Board would be doing 
with Option 2 is putting the question on the ballot, and not actually making a 
decision. Ms. Curry further stated once direction is given, whether it be Option 
No. 2 or Option No. 3, staff would return to the Board on August 6, 2024 with a 
resolution to place the question on the ballot, noting it would not be advisory and 
the voters would be making the decision on if it is to be elected or appointed. Ms. 
Curry further stated if either option gets approved, then the Board would need to 
adopt an ordinance and at that point whatever change was approved would go 
into effect at the end of the current Treasurer/Tax Collector/County Clerk’s term. 
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board 
voted to maintain the separately elected offices of the Auditor-Controller and 
Treasurer/Tax Collector/County Clerk. So ordered by a 3-2 vote with Supervisor 
Hannigan and Supervisor Mashburn voting no.
18

Chair Mahshburn opened the public hearing and the following comments were

B) Harold Helbock commented in opposition to the item because he is against
the County selling a property because of an unpaid garbage bill.

stated the County does not sell properties who have a lein for unpaid garbage

time.

staff in accordance with the resolution; 2) adopted Resolution No. 2024-130,

in accordance with the resolution; 3) adopted Resolution 2024-131, confirming

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider General Plan Amendment
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider General Plan Amendment 
Application G-23-02 and Rezoning Petition No. Z-23-01 by Chei Chen and 
Regina 
Yin 
for 
property 
located 
at 
6319 Pleasants 
Valley 
Road 
(APN
121-180-150 and -160) to change the General Plan land use designation for 
the Yin Ranch from Agriculture to Parks and Recreation; Rezone the property 
from Exclusive Agriculture (A-40) to Park (P) District to allow for the future 
siting of an Asian Pacific Islander Cultural Center and Museum; The proposed 
action is exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act 
(CEQA)
pursuant to CEQA Guidelines §15061(b)(3) (Common Sense Exemption) and 
§15301 (Existing Facilities)
Page 10
Solano County

July 23, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
A - General Plan Resolution
B - Rezone Ordinance
C - Yin Ranch Aerial
D - General Plan and Zoning Consistency
E - Planning Commission Resolution
F - Planning Commission Staff Report
G - Planning Commission Minutes
Adopted Resolution
Adopted Ordinance
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item. 
Principle Planner Mathew Walsh provided an overview of the project and 
recommended action. 
Chair Mahshburn opened the public hearing and the following comments were
received:
A) George Guynn, Jr. commented in support of the recommended action..
B) Herald Helbock commented in support of the recommended action..
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.
Speaking on behalf of the applicants, Mary Yen Liu provided her family's history 
and noted that this project is a legacy they want to provide to the Solano 
community.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the recommended action.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding current 
unpermitted buildings, Mr. Bezek stated recent construction does have current 
shell permits, noting the goal as they work through this process is that all 
buildings on the site will be permitted. Mr. Bezek further stated there are no public 
events being held at the site, noting that one private family event had taken place.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding hours of operation 
for the future facility, Consultant Kathy Pease stated it would be a reservation 
system and would have different types of uses including field trips. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the recommended action.
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the recommended action.

Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Principal Planner Matt Walsh provided a brief history of the Green Valley Open 
Space Maintenance District program and an overview of the recommended 
action.
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing inviting members of the public to
address the Board on this item. Hearing no comments, Chair Mashburn closed
the public hearing. 
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board: 1) adopted Resolution No. 2024-137, setting the Green Valley Open 
Space Maintenance District Levy of Assessment for FY2024/25; 2) approved the 
Engineer’s Report; 3) confirmed the Diagram and Assessment; and 4) ordered 
the Levy of Assessment for the Landscape and Lighting Maintenance 
Assessment District.

chunks.item_title: Receive
chunks.text:
Receive 
the 
2023 Solano 
County 
Crop 
and 
Livestock 
Report 
from 
the 
Agricultural Commissioner/Sealer of Weights and Measures 
A - 2023 Crop and Livestock Report
B - PowerPoint Presentation Crop and Livestock Report
Attachments:
Agricultural Commissioner/Sealer of Weights and Measures Ed King introduced 
the item and provided an overview of the 2023 Crop and Livestock Report.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need for the County to create 
infrastructure and protection of Solano County’s agricultural assets. 
Supervisor Vasquez requested the Board provide direction to the CAO for the use 
of staff time to work on the creation of agricultural infrastructure. 
Page 5
Solano County

August 6, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
All Board members commented in support of Supervisor Vasquez’s request.
In response to a question by Supervisor Hannigan regarding possible deterrents 
to the geese migration and its effects on crops, Mr. King stated growers have 
tried just about everything, but their efforts have had a negligible effect, noting 
farmers are trying to do their best.
Supervisor Hannigan commented on the need to protect agricultural resources 
from urban sprawl.
Supervisor Brown thanked Supervisor Vasquez for bringing up the Board's 
strategic plan as it relates to agriculture and feeding Solano County's citizens. 
Chair Mashburn thanked Mr. King and his staff for their hard work and stated his 
appreciation for the continued hard work of the agricultural community. Chair 
Mashburn further stated the Board will continue to work to protect Solano 
County’s vital agricultural production. 
In response to a question by Supervisor Williams regarding the reduction in 
indoor nursery production, Mr. King stated it is more of a year over year 
fluctuation, than an actual issue, noting there is no one thing in particular to blame 
for the reduction. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
Received
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public. 
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports on
meetings. The following comments were received:

of Supervisors be adjourned in memory Dennis Kittelson, David Ingersoll, and
Tawny Dep.
B) Supervisor Williams stated she was recently appointed to the NACo Healthy
Counties Advisory Board.
C) Supervisor Brown thanked Food is Free Bay Area for coming to the Benicia
Library with meals for the community of Benicia and commented on the school
year beginning.
E) Chair Mashburn reminded everyone that tonight is National Night Out.

Bogue, Office Supervisor, upon her retirement from Solano County with 23

A - Retirement Resolution

retirement from Solano County with 23 years of dedicated service in the

ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-139
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on matters
not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board.
There was no public comment.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of
Supervisors' agenda for August 13, 2024.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for 
August 13, 2024. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items
listed on the Consent Calendar. There was no public comment.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams on Consent Calendar Item 
No. 4, regarding response times, County Administrator Bill Emlen stated the 
response time varies based on geography, noting that the fire fighters are all 
volunteers. Mr. Emlen further stated that the addition of compensation is a 
proactive measure and is an incentive to continue to move toward a 
reorganization of the districts. 
Suisun Fire Protection District Fire Chief Fred Abruzzini stated the response 
times the districts are trying to improve are for wild land fires; therefore they are 
attempting to staff districts during peak fire times to minimize the response times. 
Page 2
Solano County

August 13, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Chief Abruzzini further stated with the current model that the agencies are using, 
most of the fire fighter volunteers respond from work or home. Chief Abruzzini 
noted that this pilot program should greatly reduce response times and provide 
data for how the County and the Districts should move forward. 
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board approved the following Consent Calendar items by a 5-0 vote:
