chunks.item_title: Consider adopting Administrative Policy A-4 on the use of County Electric
chunks.text:
Consider adopting Administrative Policy A-4 on the use of County Electric 
Vehicle (EV) Charger Stations; Conduct a noticed public hearing on a 
proposed fee schedule for the General Services Department - Fleet for EV 
charging and consider adopting an EV charger station fee schedule by 
resolution adding Exhibit XXII to Chapter 11 of the Solano County Code; and 
Consider adopting a resolution to rescind Traffic Order 147, Amendment No. 
7 and replace it with Traffic Order No. 147, Amendment No. 8
A - Solano County EV Charger Station Use Policy
B.1 - EV Charging Fee Resolution
B.2 - EXHIBIT XXII - Fleet Fee Schedule FY2024-25
C - Traffic Order 147 Amendment No 8 Resolution
D - EV Charging Port Locations
Attachments:
Director of General Services Megan Greve introduced the item and provided an 
overview of the Solano County Electric Vehicle (EV) Charger Stations Use Policy.
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing inviting members of the public to
address the Board on this item. Hearing no comments, Chair Mashburn closed
the public hearing.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding how to keep the 
EV chargers safe from vandalism, Ms. Greve stated the only thing the County 
can do is patrol the areas where the chargers are located, noting EVCS is 
responsible to fix and maintain the chargers, including if they are vandalized. Ms. 
Greve further stated two of the campuses either are or will be fenced in; however, 
the County is unable to fence in the majority of the chargers. Ms. Greve noted 
there are limitations within the grants that require the chargers to be available to 
the public.
Discussion was held regarding placement of chargers, particularly at the Beck 
campus and in the City of Vallejo with Ms. Greve noting that the department has 
plans to install additional charging stations; however, they will need additional 
funding for infrastructure. Ms. Greve further stated the department is looking for 
grants and has plans to use tax credits from the existing Engie energy project to 
apply those savings to the County's EV Charger programs. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding the difference 
between the average cost of $0.1545 per kw/h and the $0.39 per kw/h charged by 
EVCS, Ms. Greve stated the cost charged by EVCS includes the $.07 that is 
returned to the County, coverage for the cost of the electricity used, and to 
recoup the cost of installing the infrastructure. 
Discussion was held regarding plans for future installation of additional charging 
stations with Supervisor Hannigan recommending staff include the planned 
number of additional charging stations to the Capital Improvement Plan. 
Supervisor Hannigan recommended once EVCS has set up the system to 
charge an idling fee, that the time allowed for a vehicle to remain at the charging 
Page 6
Solano County

August 13, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
station be changed based on the type of charger, using the example of a limit of 
two hours for Level II chargers and a limit of one hour for Level III chargers. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the lack of 
placement or future planned placement of EV chargers in the City of Dixon, Ms. 
Greve stated EVCS chose the current placements based on what they believe 
they can afford to put in. Ms. Greve further stated General Services is looking at 
future installations in all of the cities; however, additional funding is needed. 
Supervisor Williams commented on allowing employees to charge their vehicles 
at discounted rates as an incentive for employee retention and new hires. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding the number of electric 
vehicles in Solano County’s fleet, Facilities Operations Manager Jason Alvarez 
stated the County currently has only one electric vehicle; however, three 
additional Ford Lighting Trucks have been ordered as well as an electric 
passenger vehicle. Mr. Alvarez further stated there was an issue of where to 
charge the vehicles, noting that the EV chargers that are being replaced at the 
William Carol site will be installed at the Fleet facility.
Supervisor Mashburn commented on the potential additional soft costs of the 
mandate to move all vehicles to electric by 2035, noting it is going to take 
additional employees in fleet to move around and charge 800 to 900 vehicles as 
well as additional employees for the Sheriff’s department for enforcement and to 
keep vandalism from happening. Supervisor Mashburn further stated there are 
many questions that still need to be answered regarding the cost of converting 
over to electric vehicles. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff recognizes there is a need for 
periodic updates on these efforts, noting this is going to continue to evolve over 
time. Mr. Emlen further stated staff is looking at placing additional security in the 
garage as well as increased camera surveillance.
Supervisor Hannigan stated all the various angles that will need to be considered 
such as a new Fleet Facility should be included in the Capitol Improvement Plan. 
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams , the 
Board: 1) adopted Administrative Policy A-4 on the use of County Electric 
Vehicle (EV) Charger Stations; 2) adopted Resolution No. 2024-141, adopting a 
fee schedule for the General Services Department - Fleet for EV charging 
adding Exhibit XXII to Chapter 11 of the Solano County Code; and 3) adopted 
Resolution No. 2024-142 rescinding Traffic Order 147, Amendment No. 7 and 
replacing it with Traffic Order No. 147, Amendment No. 8. So ordered by a 5-0 
vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-141 and Resolution 2024-142
Page 7
Solano County

August 13, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
17

chunks.item_title: Receive an update on the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Broadband
chunks.text:
Receive an update on the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Broadband 
Infrastructure 
project 
and 
consider 
providing 
further 
direction 
on 
project 
options 
Chief Information Officer/Registrar of Voters Tim Flanagan introduced the item 
and provided an overview of the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Broadband 
Infrastructure project and provided an overview of recommended project options.
In response to a question from Supervisor Mashburn regarding if the placement 
of cable in the ground for fixed wireless will help build additional capacity and 
infrastructure, Mr. Flanagan stated it will, noting as part of the contract with 
Cal.net, the County has requested they first connect with existing homes and if 
there are not enough customers able or willing to connect, that they instead make 
use the funding to improve existing services or build in additional capacity. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding what the County is 
now unable to do because the California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC) has 
not awarded the matching funding timely, Mr. Flanagan stated the AT&T project 
will not be funded by ARPA dollars; however, AT&T has indicated as long as they 
eventually receive the funding from the CPUC they still intend to complete the 
project in Solano County. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board: 1) directed staff to withdraw the $1 million match funding letter of 
support commitment for a possible FFA award to ATT; 2) approved a contract 
with Comcast in the amount of $400,000 to deploy fiber to the home for up to 
108 locations in Elmira, with a clause that if the CPUC awards FFA funding for 
Elmira, these funds would be allocated to another unincorporated area of 
Solano County to provide improved broadband services; 3) approved a 
contract with Valley Internet in the amount of $856,540 for fixed wireless 
broadband for up to 570 locations in Pleasants Valley, Suisun Valley, and 
Green Valley; 4) approved a contract with Cal.net in the amount of $943,460 for 
fixed wireless broadband in various unincorporated Solano County locations 
serving up to 837 locations to provide additional transmitters focused on 
non-CAFII funded areas as well as to offset connection charges for individual 
locations.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public. 
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports on
meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Hannigan requested that this meeting of the Solano County Board
Page 8
Solano County

August 13, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Jamie Carol McDougall.
B) Supervisor Brown requested staff have the Solano Transportation Authority
come and make a presentation to the Board about the Vallejo Passenger Rail
Study.
C)
Supervisor Williams stated she is the current representative on the
Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG) and appointee to the committee
that is reviewing the Plan Bay Area 2050, noting she will bring a report back to the
next meeting.
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff will follow up with ABAG as well. 
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 10:22 A.M.
to the Patwino Worrtla Kodoi Dihi Open Space Park Ribbon Cutting at 4075 
Green Valley Road in Fairfield, CA on August 21, 2024 at 9:30 A.M.; the
Vacaville Cultural Center Library Groundbreaking Ceremony at 1020 Ulatis
Drive, Vacaville, CA on August 21, 2024 at 5:00 P.M.; and to the next Board of
Supervisors meeting of August 27, 2024 at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 
Texas Street, Fairfield, CA

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on the Solano County Library Adult Literacy Program
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on the Solano County Library Adult Literacy Program
Senior Literacy Program Assistant David Lewis introduced the item and provided 
an overview of adult literacy statistics for Solano County.
Literacy Program Assistant Shauntel Jacob provided an overview of the Adult 
Basic Literacy and Family Literacy Services - Libraries Leading to Reading 
programs.
Literacy Program Assistant Katie Cordova provided an overview of the Adult 
Literacy - English as a Second Language and Career Online High School 
programs.
Literacy Program Assistant Teresa Lavell provided an overview of the Family 
Literacy Services and Reach Out and Read programs.
In response to questions from Supervisor Williams regarding the sustainability of 
the literacy program and regarding how the Library’s community partners are 
disseminating information on the literacy programs being offered by the Solano 
County Library to the community, Ms. Jacob stated 127 parents registered their 
children within 3 days of opening the pilot program. Ms. Jacob further stated for 
the program to continue to be successful, the community will need to come 
together. Ms. Jacob further stated staff has applied for ARPA funding from the 
Matt Garcia Partnership to sustain the program for the next two summers, which 
will allow staff time to look for other funding to both keep the program going and to 
expand the program within Vallejo and to offer it in Fairfield and Dixon. 
Supervisor Williams commented on the need for the Board of Supervisors to 
provide financial support for the various Solano County Library Literacy programs. 
Supervisor Brown commented in support of the Library’s literacy programs and 
on other needs of the community including TK classes, extended schedules for 
summer school, and extended food programs.
Page 7
Solano County

August 27, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Kitty Hammer commented on the successes of the various Library literacy
programs.
B) Ginny Lee commented in support of the Library literacy programs.
C) Patricia Hunter commented in support of the Library’s literacy programs and
commented on Vallejo NAACP and Kyle's Temple AME Zion Vallejo Church's
contributions to the literacy programs.
D)
Teresa Courtemanche commented in support of the Library’s literacy
programs and contributions by the Matt Garcia Foundation to the literacy
programs.
Supervisor Brown commented on the need for literacy services at Jesse Bethel 
Elementary school.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding Solano County's 
participation in the Dolly Parton Imagination Library literacy foundation, Deputy 
Director of Library Services Megan Wong stated the County is not a participant in 
that program, noting she will follow up with Supervisor Brown regarding the 
reasons why. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the Library’s literacy programs and 
shared a personal story about her own struggles with literacy.
Chair Mashburn commented in support of the Library’s literacy programs and 
shared a personal story of his time working in the Sheriff Custody Unit literacy 
programs and the impacts the program made on individuals who were in the 
program. Chair Mashburn commented in support of the recommendation made 
by Supervisor Williams. 
Received
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports on
meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Williams requested that this meeting of the Solano County Board
of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Candy Pierce.
Page 8
Solano County

August 27, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
B) Chair Mashburn requested that this meeting of the Solano County Board of
Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Candace Pierce.
C)Supervisor Brown commented on the importance of the upcoming Labor Day
holiday.

Page 2
Solano County

September 10, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of 
Supervisors' agenda for September 10, 2024.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for 
September 10, 2024. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Supervisor Brown requested Consent Calendar Item No. 17 be removed for 
further discussion.
Supervisor Williams commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 5, and 
requested information on the retirement practices for the Sheriff's K-9s.
Undersherrif Brad Dewall provided an overview of the adoption process for 
retired K-9s, noting in almost all situations that he is aware of the K-9s 
handler adopts the K-9 upon retirement. Undersheriff Dewall further stated the 
handlers pay an adoption fee and are then responsible for paying for any 
medical care the K-9 needs, as is the case when you adopt any pet from the 
shelter. Undersheriff Dewall further stated there is a non-profit organization 
within Solano County that helps pay for medical care for retired K-9s.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
approved the following Consent Calendar items by a 5-0 vote with Consent 
Calendar Item No 17 removed for further discussion:

chunks.text:

Act of 1982 (TEFRA) and consider adopting a resolution approving the 
issuance of revenue bonds by the California Municipal Finance Authority 
(CMFA), in an amount not to exceed $61,000,000 for the purpose of financing 
the

for 
approximately

September 24, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
$10,000,000 for facilities within Solano County
A - Resolution
B - Public Notice Affidavits
Attachments:
Treasurer-Tax Collector/County Clerk Charles Lomeli introduced the item and 
provided an overview of the request for the issuance of revenue bonds by the 
California Municipal Finance Authority on behalf of Recology, Inc.
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments from
the public. 
On motion of Supervisor Brown, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2024-156, approving the issuance of revenue bonds by 
the California Municipal Finance Authority (CMFA), in an amount not to exceed 
$61,000,000 for the purpose of financing the acquisition, construction, 
rehabilitation, renovation, installation, improvement and/or equipping of land, 
buildings, facilities and/or equipment, including but not limited to an 
expanded capacity for transfer and processing of municipal solid waste and 
rolling stock, for the collection, transfer and processing of municipal solid 
waste, including associated equipment and appurtenances thereto by 
Recology Incorporated for approximately $10,000,000 for facilities within 
Solano County. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-156
18

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on preparations and logistics for the upcoming
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on preparations and logistics for the upcoming 
November 5, 2024 General Election
A - Presentation
Attachments:
Chief Information Officer/Registrar of Voters Tim Flanagan introduced the item.
Assistant Registrar of Voters John Gardner provided an overview of the 
preparations and logistics for the upcoming November 5, 2024, General Election.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown, regarding the requirements of 
AB 3184, Mr. Gardner stated AB 3184 requires all counties to certify the election 
on the same day, which is 28 days after election day.
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding signature verification 
requirements for dropping off a ballot, Mr. Flanagan stated per Government 
Code, the County is required to have the signature verification box on the 
ballot envelope; however, there is no mechanism for enforcement of the 
signature verification for ballots that are dropped off. Mr. Flanagan stated all 
ballots will still go through the verification process of the Registrar of Voters office.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the cost of the 
election, Mr. Gardner stated the budgeted request is $2.4 million.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding security at the 
polling places and drop boxes, Mr. Flanagan stated there will not be security at 
any particular spot; however, both the Sheriff and city police will be briefed on the 
Page 7
Solano County

September 24, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
locations of the polling places and ballot drop off spaces to ensure they are able 
to respond quickly should there be an issue that those who are working are 
unable to deescalate. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Denise Ceccato commented on statewide election database.
B) Leigh Sutherland read a portion of a draft resolution pertaining to the 2024
election.
C) Charlene Phipps read a portion of a draft resolution pertaining to the 2024
election.
D) Paul Troxell read a portion of a draft resolution pertaining to the 2024 election.
Received
19

chunks.text:

of the code is no longer relevant.

Code concerning Underground Storage of Hazardous Substances by title only 
and waived further reading of the ordinance. So ordered by a 5/0 vote.

chunks.text:

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation from Rural County Representatives of California
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation from Rural County Representatives of California 
(RCRC) on their updated Strategic Plan and the work of RCRC affiliate 
entities
A - Memo for Solano County Board of Supervisors
B - Presentation
Minute Order
Attachments:
Rural County Representatives of California (RCRC) President and CEO Patrick 
Page 4
Solano County

October 1, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Blacklock introduced the item and provided an overview of the services and 
programs provided by RCRC.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding an RCRC 
initiative that aims to collect funding from the State of California for unfunded 
mandates, Mr. Blacklock stated the organization is getting ready to submit its 
first claims dealing with multiple unfunded mandates that counties are facing 
from the State of California. 
Supervisor Brown requested RCRC consider working on the creationg of more 
Curriculum and Technical Education (CTE) programs for both high school and 
community college students, as well as helping to institute student housing for 
community college students. 
In response to comments from Supervisor Brown, Mr. Blacklock stated RCRC 
has already begun looking at CTE programs through its partnerships with 
multiple community college districts, particularly in the rural counties. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the possibility of 
RCRC holding a meeting with Solano County employees to inform them of the 
benefits of the Golden State Finance Authority Assist to Own program, Mr. 
Blacklock stated he is happy to meet with Solano County’s employees and will 
work with County Administrator Bill Emlen and his staff to get a meeting 
scheduled. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the County’s 
availability to take advantage of the Golden State Connect Authority FFA Last 
Mile Awards, Mr. Blacklock stated the current period to submit applications has 
passed; however, if Solano County needs additional funding in the future, there 
will be more grant opportunities to apply for. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the lack of 
biomass facilities in California, Mr. Blacklock stated RCRC has partnered with 
Drax US, noting that the goal is to begin using pellets to create carbon-negative 
energy production in California. 
A discussion period was held regarding potential biomass programs using 
agricultural waste.
In response to comments made by Chair Mashburn regarding future possibilities 
of biomass facilities/energy production using agricultural waste in California, Mr. 
Blacklock stated Drax US is trying to get a better sense of how much 
agricultural-related biomass is available and requested information on who he 
should speak with to obtain that information for Drax US.
In response to comments from Chair Mashburn requesting RCRC look into 
introducing legislation that closes loopholes in current State legislation that 
enables large urban counties to bypass local land use policies of rural counties 
concerning water and power; Mr. Blacklock stated RCRC is looking at options, 
Page 5
Solano County

October 1, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
and part of the purpose of the Rural Advancement Institute is to help RCRC 
create relationships with members of the legislature that represent larger urban 
counties so that when proposals come forward that affect rural counties RCRC 
will be more successful in supporting local control. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
Received
9

chunks.item_title: Receive
chunks.text:
Receive 
a 
presentation 
and 
consider 
adopting 
a 
resolution 
recognizing 
October 2024 as National Cybersecurity Awareness Month
A - National Cyber Security Awareness Month Resolution
Minute Order
Adopted Resolution
Attachments:
Chief Information Officer/Registrar of Voters Tim Flanagan introduced the item 
and provided a brief overview of AI related cybersecurity threats and 
preparations.
Senior IT Security Manager Jaime Fontelera provided an overview of the 
programs being used by the Department of Information Technology (DoIT) to 
protect Solano County’s network against emerging threats.
Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Advisor Mario Garcia provided 
an overview of cybersecurity threats to state and local governments, mitigation, 
best practices, and generative AI.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding possible threats to 
the County’s computer system, Mr. Garcia stated staff should be aware of how 
their computer typically works and report if they are witnessing changes or 
receive ransom requests for files.
Supervisor Hannigan thanked Mr. Flanagan and DoIT staff for their continued 
work to keep the County’s system safe, noting everyone needs to stay vigilant.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding if there are 
classes that members of the public can take to learn how to stay technologically 
safe, Mr. Flanagan stated his department will provide information to the Board 
that they can provide for their constituents. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding the expansion of 
Solano County’s IT infrastructure and data centers for additional cyber security, 
Mr. Flanagan stated his department has already begun working with General 
Services on infrastructure projects and capital projects for the County’s main 
data center to make it more resilient.
Discussion was held regarding cybersecurity at the federal and local level with 
no action taken. 
Page 6
Solano County

October 1, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board adopted and presented Resolution No. 2024-recognizing October 2024 
as National Cybersecurity Awareness Month. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see 
Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-159
10

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation providing an update on the Solano County website
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation providing an update on the Solano County website 
redesign; Approve a contract with Interpersonal Frequency for $946,545 for 
the period of October 1, 2024 through June 30, 2028, to build, implement, 
and support the redesigned website and backend platform; and Delegate 
authority to the County Administrator to execute the contract and any 
subsequent 
amendments, 
with 
County 
Counsel 
concurrence, 
up 
to 
an 
annual aggregate of $74,999 
A - Interpersonal Frequency Contract
Minute Order
Executed Agreement
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Megan Richards introduced the item and 
provided an overview of the redevelopment of Solano County’s new website. 
Discussion was held regarding external visitors to the County’s website and on 
how the project was able to obtain feedback from the general public about 
website uses.
Project Manager Monique Shaifer provided an overview of completed and 
upcoming project phases for the new website as well as improvements to user 
access for the website. 
Ms. Richards provided an overview of new and/or improved features on the new 
website.
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the upcoming changes to the 
website and thanked staff for the time and effort that has gone into the project. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding the use of 
open-source software being used by the County, Ms. Richards stated staff 
worked closely with Interpersonal Frequency to understand how Interpersonal 
Frequency secures the software. Ms. Richards further stated Interpersonal 
Frequency adds their own layer of security to the open-source software. Ms. 
Richards further stated Druple is the software that a majority of government 
agencies are using. 
Mr. Flanagan stated open source software is not inherently more open to a 
security breach than a closed-source system, noting however it is not without its 
own set of risks. Mr. Flanagan further stated open source software is more 
transparent 
regarding 
software 
capabilities, 
noting 
as 
a 
result 
of 
that 
Page 7
Solano County

October 1, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
transparency the County will get more rapid security patches than they would 
with a closed-source system. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding the timeline for 
completion of the website project, Ms. Richards stated although the original plan 
was to have a fully functioning website at the end of 2024, the current estimated 
launch is now May 2025. Ms. Richarads further stated it took more time that was 
hoped for to get through the various security components that were required. 
Supervisor Williams commented on the need for a centralized location stemming 
from the Health and Social Services webpage for a lisitng of non-profit 
organizations. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the community 
focus on the website, Ms. Richards stated that individuals will be able to filter the 
website to locate the services that they need. 
Supervisor Hannigan requested dates for the board-appointed Advisory Boards, 
Committees, and Commissions meetings be placed on the County’s main 
calendar. Additionally, Supervisor Hannigan requested dates for the meeting 
dates of the Boards, Committees, and Commissions that the Board Members 
are appointed to be placed on the main calendar. 
Supervisor Vasquez stated he agrees with Supervisor Hannigan’s request, 
noting county government is the silent government, and the citizens need a 
better representation of what their county government does. 
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded y Supervisor Williams the Board: 
1) approved a contract with Interpersonal Frequency for $946,545 for the period
of October 1, 2024 through June 30, 2028, to build, implement, and support the
redesigned website and backend platform; and 2) delegated authority to the
County Administrator to execute the contract and any subsequent
amendments, with County Counsel concurrence, up to an annual aggregate of
$74,999. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
11

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation describing a potential affordable workforce housing
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation describing a potential affordable workforce housing 
project on a 1.3 acre parcel owned by the County located at 580 North 1st 
Street (APN 0115-060-140); Consider allocating up to $1.5 million from the 
current balance of the Solano County Housing Trust Fund for initial site 
preparation and engineering costs necessary to make the site “shovel ready” 
for 
development 
(4/5 vote 
required); 
and 
Provide 
further 
comment 
and 
direction on the project concept as appropriate
A - Draft Conceptual Drawing
Minute Order
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Anne Putney introduced the item and provided an 
overview of the recommended workforce housing project.
Director of Resource Management James Bezek provided an overview of the 
various housing options and surrounding amenities. 
Page 8
Solano County

October 1, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to comments from Supervisor Williams regarding the need for 
transit services, Ms. Putney stated the City of Dixon offers door-to-door service 
at a cost of $2.75 per ride.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the safety of 
children walking to school, Mr. Bezek stated the train tracks are gated, so it is as 
safe as it can be. 
In response to comments from Supervisor Hannigan regarding the number of 
people per unit requirement, Ms. Putney stated while the County would not want 
to put more than 6 people in a three-bedroom unit, there is nothing that states it 
can’t be fewer people per unit; however, the income limit can’t exceed their 
household size. 
In response to comments by Supervisor Hannigan’s the need to review the 
needs of the community to see if there is a need for smaller units, County 
Administrator Bill Emlen stated this is only conceptual to show the Board 
possibilities; however, when the building commences staff will review the 
community needs. 
A discussion period was held regarding various housing needs as it relates to 
family size.
In 
response 
to 
Supervisor 
Brown’s 
comments 
on 
the 
need 
for 
wheelchair-accessible bathrooms and showers, Mr. Bezek stated staff can look 
at a mix of accessible and non-accessible units, as well as universal designs to 
meet the needs. 
Discusion was held regarding the placement of the housing project in a more 
industrial area. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need to work with the City of Dixon 
regarding what is surrounding the potential housing project, noting that the 
County can help the City of Dixon with cleaning up the area. 
A discussion and question and answer period was held regarding environmental 
and quality of life concerns with the project. 
In response to Board Member comments, Water and Natural Resources 
Manager Misty Kaltreider provided information on the environmental concerns 
noted, stating that the property next to the recommended site is in the process of 
being cleaned up and therefore, there is existing monitoring information already 
available for the site. Ms. Kaltreider further stated the concentrations on the 
recommended property in the groundwater are relatively low compared to the 
neighboring Unical Property that is currently being cleaned up, a process that is 
being overseen by the Regional Water Quality Control Board. Ms. Kaltreider 
further stated the property has been tested multiple times and the gasoline 
constituent levels are undetectable. 
Page 9
Solano County

October 1, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Discussion was held. 
Supervisor Williams commented on the need for Dixon to be committed to 
making changes to the industrial area, noting she wants to make sure the Board 
isn’t accidentally creating a redlined district. 
In response to Supervisor Williams's comments, Supervisor Vasquez stated 
Dixon is in the process of completing their General Plan Update and at this time 
would not be able to commit to anything; noting however, that the City of Dixon 
is looking at completing an additional high-density development project about a 
mile away, therefore this is a timely project for them. 
Mr. Bezek stated that he believes the City of Dixon is looking to change the 
recommended area from industrial to a mixed-use area of housing and retail. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board allocated up to $1.5 million from the current balance of the Solano 
County Housing Trust Fund for initial site preparation and engineering costs 
necessary to make the site “shovel ready” for development (4/5 vote required). 
So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional items from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Brown requested an update on the work being completed by
the Family Justice Center.
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 
12:07P.M. Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be 
October 22, 2024 at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, 
Fairfield, California.
________________________________
MITCH H. MASHBURN, Chair
Solano County Board of Supervisors
BILL EMLEN, Clerk
Solano County Board of Supervisors
By ______________________________
Alicia Draves, Chief Deputy Clerk

Solano County

chunks.item_title: Consider adoption of a resolution authorizing the purchase and acquisition of
chunks.text:
Consider adoption of a resolution authorizing the purchase and acquisition of 
the former Parkrose Gardens assisted living site, located at 1095 E. Tabor 
Ave., Fairfield, CA Solano County APN: 0037-040-150, for a total purchase 
price of $6,250,000, plus administrative fees and estimated closing costs (4/5 
vote required); Consider approval of an Appropriation Transfer Request (ATR)
reallocating $7,324,440 in existing appropriations and up to $3,600,000 in 
interest revenue of federal American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Coronavirus 
State and Local Fiscal Recovery Fund (SLFRF) to fund the purchase and 
necessary renovations of the facility (4/5 vote required); Consider delegating 
authority to the County Administrator to execute any and all agreements, 
amendments, and documents, subject to County Counsel concurrence, to 
carry out the purchase and projects; and Consider delegating authority to the 
County Administrator to negotiate and execute a facility use agreement with 
Archway Recovery Services, Inc. for interim use of the property 
Page 6
Solano County

October 8, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
A - Resolution
B - Purchase Assignment
C - Interim Occupancy Agreement
Attachments:
Chair Mashburn recused himself from this item stating he has a conflict of 
interest due to owning a property at 1193 Blossom Avenue which is in proximity 
to the property under discussion. Chair Mashburn left the dais.
Assistant County Administrator Debbie Vaughn introduced the item and provided 
an overview of the location and details on the property.
Chief Deputy for Behavioral Health Emery Cowan provided an overview of the 
project proposal including current and future housing needs for citizens seeking 
treatment with Solano County Behavioral Health and the costs associated with 
the purchase.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the importance of 
purchasing the property, Ms. Cowan commented on the various strings that are 
attached with homeless and behavioral health funding, noting that having the 
ability to purchase this property outright is a unique opportunity that will provide a 
lot of flexibility for the County
Supervisor Brown commented in support of the recommended action, noting that 
the property is local which will allow families the ability to visit clients who are 
staying at the facility. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the project, noting it is a win for 
clients seeking treatment and housing and a win for the community.
In response to a question from Vice-Chair Hannigan regarding the how much of 
the total cost of the project is closing costs, Real Estate Agent Dale Eyeler stated 
an estimation of total closing costs is around $10,000. 
In response to a question from Vice-Chair Hannigan regarding the use of ARPA 
funding for the purchase of the building, Ms. Vaughn stated at this time, the 
allocation of the $7.3 million will redirect all remaining ARPA funds.
Vice-Chair Hannigan invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Lisa U’Ren speaking on behalf of NAMI Solano County commented in support
of the recommended action.
B) Minister Tony Adams speaking on behalf of Mount Calvary Baptist Church
commented on the current non-profit RFQ for remaining ARPA funding.
In response to comments made by Mr. Adams, Principal Management Analyst 
Megan Richards commented on the possibility of the Board having additional 
ARPA funding due to the potential reallocation of funds from previously approved 
Page 7
Solano County

October 8, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
projects that have not yet been placed under contract.
C) Patty Phillips speaking on behalf of NAMI Solano County commented in
support of the recommended action.
In response to Vice-Chair Hannigan's comments regarding placing a 20-25 year 
deed restriction on the property, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated staff 
can address the deed restriction to the property in a way that avoids binding 
future Boards.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board: 
1) adopted Resolution No. 2024-167, authorizing the purchase and acquisition
of the former Parkrose Gardens assisted living site, located at 1095 E. Tabor
Ave., Fairfield, CA Solano County APN: 0037-040-150, for a total purchase price
of $6,250,000, plus administrative fees and estimated closing costs; 2) approved
an Appropriation Transfer Request (ATR) reallocating $7,324,440 in existing
appropriations and up to $3,600,000 in interest revenue of federal American
Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Coronavirus State and Local Fiscal Recovery Fund
(SLFRF) to fund the purchase and necessary renovations of the facility; 3)
delegated authority to the County Administrator to execute any and all
agreements, amendments, and documents, subject to County Counsel
concurrence, to carry out the purchase and projects; 4) delegated authority to
the County Administrator to negotiate and execute a facility use agreement
with Archway Recovery Services, Inc. for interim use of the property; and 5)
directed staff to review possible actions to place a deed restriction on the
property to ensure it is retained as a housing facility for behavioral health
services. So ordered by a 4-0 vote with Chair Mashburn recused.
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-167
16

chunks.item_title: Adopt and present a resolution recognizing October 20-26, 2024 as National
chunks.text:
Adopt and present a resolution recognizing October 20-26, 2024 as National 
Childhood Lead Poisoning Prevention Week in Solano County; and Receive 
an update on the Lead-based Paint Abatement Program 
A - Resolution
B - Lead-based Paint Abatement Workplan
C - LPA Flow Chart
Attachments:
Chair Mashburn returned to the meeting.
Environmental Health Manager Trey Strickland introduced the item. 
Health Officer Dr. Bela Matyas provided an overview of the harm that lead 
poisoning can cause in a child's system. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the tracking of 
children who are going through treatment for lead poisoning, Dr. Matyas stated 
they track the child through the conclusion of treatment and interventions.
Mr. Strickland provided an overview of Solano County’s Lead-based Paint 
Abatement Program.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the length of time it 
Page 8
Solano County

October 8, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
has taken to get the program underway, Director of Resource Management 
James Bezek, stated it is a lack of qualified contractors and a lack of 
homeowners who wish to take advantage of the program. 
Chair Mashburn requested staff include in the GIS Mapping, schools that were 
built before 1978 and also licensed in-home daycare facilities within the County.
A discussion period was held regarding abatement programs in schools and 
daycares, with Mr. Bezek noting that many schools would have been repainted 
already which is considered lead-based paint containment, and with Dr. Matyas 
stating staff has already reached out to both daycare centers and real estate 
agents to provide focused prevention education instructions for homeowners and 
daycare operators. 
In response to comments made by Board Members regarding barriers to getting 
projects completed, a discussion period was held regarding efforts that are taking 
place to bring in contractors willing to do the projects and outreach efforts being 
made by the department. 
Supervisor Williams recommended working with the schools to add hyperlinks to 
the Lead Abatement Program providing another form of outreach. 
In response to comments from Chair Mashburn regarding multi-family units, Dr. 
Matyas stated staff is working on finding ways to work with the rental community; 
however, the County’s options are limited because rentals create a gap in areas 
where the County can identify and control notifications during the transfer 
process. 
A discussion period was held regarding potential relocations of families while 
remediation happens with Mr. Bezek stating if an applicant is unable to stay with 
family or friends, the program will cover the relocation costs. 
A discussion period was held regarding how the program moves forward when 
there is no longer funding available. 
Supervisor Brown recommended staff create a video to be placed on a website 
as well as provide written material. Mr. Bezek stated he would reach out to 
Matthew Davis regarding this possibility. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.

chunks.item_title: Receive an update on the County’s Water Resources Program and activities,
chunks.text:
Receive an update on the County’s Water Resources Program and activities, 
including 
related 
processes 
with 
the 
Delta 
Tunnel 
project, 
ecosystem 
restoration projects in the Cache Slough Region, groundwater sustainability, 
development of the integrated One Water Framework, and other related 
activities 
A - Water Program Update
B - Tunnel Impacts Map
C - Delta Conveyance Project Schedule
D - Habitat Project Summary and Map
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Water and Natural Resources Program Manager Misty Kaltreider provided an 
overview of the Delta Tunnel project, Bay Delta Project, Cache Slough 
Restoration Projects, a One Water Framework Status Update and the Solano 
Bayshore Resiliency Project. 
Chair Mashburn commented on potential impacts to the Delta and Solano County 
in particular as a result of the Delta Conveyance Project. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding the amount of 
water that will be diverted if the Delta Tunnel Project is completed, Chair 
Mashburn stated at full capacity, the tunnel will take a third of the Sacramento 
River flows at the intake.
A discussion period was held regarding the Delta Tunnel Project.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the impacts to agriculture as a result of the 
Delta Tunnel Project and the State's recommended mitigation plans. 
In response to comments from Supervisor Hannigan recommending the County 
put together a plan to educate and advocate for Solano County with current and 
future legislators, Chair Mashburn stated staff has already begun that process.
Supervisor Brown commented on the need to have this presentation provided at 
the Solano Water Agency meeting.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the recommendations made by 
Supervisor Hannigan and commented on meetings she has held with the local 
vintners and farmers in the Suisun Valley. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
Accepted

chunks.item_title: Conduct
chunks.text:
Conduct 
a 
facilitated 
Board 
Priority 
Workshop; 
Receive 
an 
update 
on 
department workplans and continuing efforts related to Board priorities with a 
focus 
on 
economic 
development 
and 
agriculture 
preservation 
and 
development; and Consider providing further direction on the next steps in 
implementing Board priorities
A - Board Priority Status Update
Attachments:
The Board conducted a facilitated Board Priority Workshop to receive an update on 
department workplans and continuing efforts related to Board priorities with a focus 
on economic development and agriculture preservation and development.
County Administrator Bill Emlen introduced 
Director of Resource Management James Bezek provided an overview of steps to 
be taken for the next General Plan update which will include identifying potential 
areas of economic development, provided a brief overview of the development of a 
Utility Master Plan, and provided an overview of steps being taken to continue to 
protect Travis Air Force Base.
Budget Officer Emily Combs provided an overview of the County’s financial goals 
and revenue limitations and opportunities.
Discussion facilitator Chris Beynon introduced himself and provided a brief 
overview of how the priority setting session will go forward. 
A discussion and question and answer period was held by the Board on Economic 
Development priorities E-1 through E-6. 
Supervisor Hannigan commented on the need to focus on being strategic about 
development in the unincorporated areas of the County, creating County owned 
utility system, finding a mechanism to fund the Parks District, and marketing 
Solano County open spaces and parks. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the need to focus on development in already 
Page 12
Solano County

October 8, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
established facilities that are currently vacant in the unincorporated areas, 
Supervisor Williams commented on the need to focus on engaging the Solano 
Economic Development Corporation, the creation of a SWOT Analysis, engaging 
stakeholders in the County, and looking at new and emerging agricultural 
technologies. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need to focus on the balance between 
development in the unincorporated area, particularly around the highway 
interchanges, and protection of agricultural lands. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need to focus on economic development in the 
unincorporated areas of the County and the creation of a countywide infrastructure 
study, the hiring of an Economic Development Director, and updating Travis AFB’s 
infrastructure. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this matter 
and the following comments were received:
A) Former Supervisor Duane Kromm commented in support of renewing the
orderly growth initiative.
B) Marilyn Farley commented on adding consideration for climate change when
looking at agricultural and economic development for the County.
A discussion and question and answer period was held by the Board on Agricultural 
Preservation and Development priorities A-1 through A-3.
Agricultural Commissioner Ed King provided an overview of the Sustainable 
Agricultural Lands Conservation (SALC) Program and the County’s Right-to Farm 
Ordinance. 
Mr. Emlen provided a brief status update on the Solano 360 project.
Supervisor Hannigan commented on the need to focus on ensure housing 
development is avoided in areas that are safe for families with regard to 
environments, pollution, walkability, and not creating food deserts. 
Supervisor Williams commented on the need to include stakeholder such as 
vintners and growers as part of the process when developing updates to the 
General Plan, and the creations of lanes on the highways for agricultural equipment
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need to focus on ensuring the County 
keeps the Right-to-Farm near areas of residential development and protecting 
agricultural processing facilities.
Chair Mashburn commented on the need to focus on impacts to agriculture with 
the development of highways, noting there needs to be protection for the 
agricultural community and the benefits of the agriculture, codifying these elements 
Page 13
Solano County

October 8, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
in the EIR process. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this matter 
and the following comments were received:
A) Former Supervisor Duane Kromm commented on the need for a buffer zone
between cities and agriculture, noting the buffer zone should be on the city side of
the property lines
Mr. Emlen provided closing comments. 
Following the discussion, the Board requested staff return with an action plan and 
summary report from the consultant.
Received
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 4:27 P.M.
Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be October 22,
2024 at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, Fairfield, California.

This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.

Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

chunks.item_title: Receive an update on obligation status for projects utilizing Solano County
chunks.text:
Receive an update on obligation status for projects utilizing Solano County 
American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Coronavirus State and Local Fiscal 
Recovery 
Funds 
(SLFRF); 
Consider 
reallocation 
options 
for 
unobligated 
funding, including the results of the Request for Qualifications from non-profit 
agencies 
and 
other 
potential 
projects; 
Consider 
providing 
direction 
on 
$3,500,000 of unobligated funding that has become available for reallocation 
and other funding that may become available before the obligation deadline of 
December 31, 2024; and Delegate authority to the County Administrator to 
sign any agreements related to the ARPA reallocations 
A - Unobligated ARPA Funds
B - Reallocation Scenarios
C - Results of ARPA RFQ
D - City of Suisun City Request for ARPA Funding
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Megan Richards introduced the item and provided 
status updates on projects that are not yet currently obligated and options the 
Board can take to reallocate ARPA funding.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding if there is the 
possibility of a partial funding award for the upgrades of facilities to use for natural 
disaster response, Ms. Richards stated, yes, partial funding can be allocated and 
staff would then scale the upgrades to match the funding. Supervisor Hannigan 
further asked if the City of Suisun City (Suisun City) had provided funding for the 
Senior Center project, Ms. Richards stated Suisun City has indicated they will 
allocate $300,000 in contingency funding to the project if the Board provides the 
full requested allocation. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A)
Joe 
Joyce 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
using 
funding 
for 
emergency
preparedness facility upgrades and in support of the request for ARPA
funding for the Suisun City Senior Center upgrade project.
B)
Donna LeBlanc commented in support of the Suisun City request for
Page 8
Solano County

October 22, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ARPA funding for upgrades to the Senior Center to serve as a community
hub. 
C) Chief Executive Officer for the Solano Fair Association Tom Keaney
commented in support of using funding for emergency preparedness facility
upgrades.
D) Minister Tony Adams speaking on behalf of Mount Calvary Baptist
Church commented on their submitted ARPA Request for Qualifications
(RFQ) for Nonprofits, requesting the Board reconsider their application.
E)
President and CEO of the Food Bank of Contra Costa and Solano Caitlyn
Sly commented in support of the Board allocating funding to the RFQ for
Nonprofits.
Supervisor Williams requested the Board support the request of Suisun City for 
ARPA funding for the rehabilitation of the Suisun City Senior Center.
In 
response 
to 
a 
question 
from 
Supervisor 
Hannigan 
regarding 
ARPA 
requirements for revenue replacement, Ms. Richards stated if the Board 
approves 
fully 
funding 
the 
County’s 
revenue 
loss 
under 
the 
Revenue 
Replacement ARPA category, they may want to consider using it as a general 
fund offset to avoid potential issues with obligation deadlines. 
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the following allocations: 1) 
Revenue Replacement in the amount of $1,714,006; 2) RFQ for Nonprofit 
Agencies in the amount of $500,000; 3) Radio Interoperability in the amount of 
$285,994; 4) Early Learning Center Community Resource Building in the amount 
of $500,000; and 5) Emergency Relief from Natural Disasters in the amount of 
$500,000.
Supervisor Brown made a recommendation to allocate $1,000,000 to the RFQ for 
Nonprofit Agencies, by awarding the full amount of the funding to the Food Bank 
of Contra Costa and Solano, who would then administer grants to the local 
non-profits. 
In response to Supervisor Brown’s comments, Ms. Sly stated the Food Bank of 
Contra Costa and Solano would be willing administer grants to the local 
nonprofits. 
Supervisor Brown commented in support of the following allocations: 1) Revenue 
Replacement in the amount of $500,000; 2) RFQ for Nonprofit Agencies in the 
amount of $1,000,000; 3) Radio Interoperability in the amount of $1,000,000; and 
4) Emergency Relief from Natural Disasters in the amount of $1,000,000.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the following allocations: 1) 
Revenue Replacement in the amount of $567,324; 2) RFQ for Nonprofit Agencies 
in the amount of $500,000; 3) Suisun City request in the amount of $1,932,676; 
and 4) Emergency Relief from Natural Disasters in the amount of $500,000.
Page 9
Solano County

October 22, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the following allocations: 1) 
Revenue Replacement in the amount of $1,714,006; 2) Radio Interoperability in 
the amount of $785,994; and 3) Emergency Relief from Natural Disasters in the 
amount of $1,000,000.
Chair Mashburn commented in support of the following allocations: 1) Revenue 
Replacement in the amount of $1,500,000; 2) RFQ for Nonprofit Agencies in the 
amount of $1,000,000; 3) Radio Interoperability in the amount of $250,000; 4) 
Early Learning Center Community Resource Building in the amount of $250,000; 
and 5) Emergency Relief from Natural Disasters in the amount of $500,000.
Discussion was held regarding the Suisun City request for ARPA funding for the 
Senior Center project. 
City manager of Suisun City Bret Prebula commented on the City’s request for 
ARPA funding for the Senior Center project, noting he felt it was not transparent 
to request a partial award, when he is uncertain if the Suisun City will be able to 
fund the rest. Mr. Prebula further stated the remodel will result in a building that 
can provide Suisun City with the ability to partner with other agencies and will 
provide a facility that should last for the next 30 years. 
Supervisor Hannigan asked Chair Mashburn if he would be willing to make a 
frien

chunks.item_title: Consider introducing an ordinance adding Article III to Chapter 2.2 of the
chunks.text:
Consider introducing an ordinance adding Article III to Chapter 2.2 of the 
Solano County Code concerning Agricultural Lands and Operations to define 
and implement an agricultural mitigation program; the proposed ordinance is 
exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant to 
CEQA Guidelines §§15162, 15307, and 15308
A - Agricultural Mitigation Ordinance
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Principal Planner Matthew Walsh provided an overview of the purpose of the 
proposed Agricultural Mitigation Program. 
Mr. Walsh stated Section 2.2-350 (6), establishing a credit program monitored 
and run by staff if an easement is larger than what is necessary, should be 
stricken from the ordinance as staff does not desire to implement this program at 
this time.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding why this program 
would not be included, Mr. Walsh stated staff did consider the program, but they 
are uncertain if the department has the resources, or if the County desires to be a 
mitigation bank.
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of leaving the section in the 
ordinance. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if the County can leave 
the section in the ordinance without acting on it, County Counsel Bernadette 
Curry stated, yes it can, noting the likelihood that this will happen is not great. 
Page 12
Solano County

October 22, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Williams requested staff include the details on section of CEQA 
guidelines cited in future agenda items.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Jim Leland commented in support of the recommended action, noting there
are a few issues that will need to be addressed.
B) Williams Brazelton commented in support of the recommended action, noting
there are a few issues that will need to be addressed.
C) Michael Fortney commented in opposition of the recommended action and
requested a delay in the adoption of the ordinance until the General Plan Update
takes place.
D) City Attorney for the City of Dixon Douglas White commented in opposition to
the recommended action and requested a delay in the adoption of the ordinance.
E) Lisa Howard commented in support of the recommended action, requesting
the Board ensure there is no bias between irrigated and non-irrigated land. Ms. 
Howard commented in opposition to in-lieu fees unless the County is willing to
charge a premium price for those fees.
F) Tracy Ellison speaking on behalf of the Solano Land Trust commented in
support of the recommended action, noting there are a few issues that will need to
be addressed and commenting on the need for a premium fee for in-lieu fees
paid.
Deputy County Counsel Holly Tokar stated staff completed a survey of other 
jurisdictions and while the majority of jurisdictions have ratios of 1:1 or 1.5:1, both 
the City of Woodland and the Yolo County have a ratio of up to 3:1. 
G) Aiden Mayhood commented in support of the recommended action, noting
however, that he believes that equal protection should be given to lands of the
same soil type regardless of whether they are irrigated or not.
H)
Marilyn 
Farley 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
the 
recommended 
action
recommending the County consider having an accredited land trust as the holder
of any conservation easements.
I) Ian Anderson commented in support of the recommended action, noting,
however, that in-lieu fees need to be at a premium price.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding the recommended 
ratios, Ms. Tokar stated the ratios of 1.5:1 are in the General Plan, but the 
General Plan also provides for a graduated mitigation method, which is partially 
what was used to come up with a higher ratio based on land quality. 
Page 13
Solano County

October 22, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
A discussion was held regarding in-lieu fees and conservation easements with no 
action taken. 
Supervisor Hannigan requested minutes for the Land Use Transportation 
Committee (LUTC) meetings be provided with future agenda items if the item has 
previously been heard at LUTC and requested the largest land owner in the 
County be noticed to ensure they are a part of the conversation. Supervisor 
Williams agreed with Supervisor Hannigan's request. 
Agricultural Commissioner Ed King provided definitions of the various types of 
farmland. 
Supervisor Hannigan voiced concerns about the recommended 3:1 ratio and how 
it will affect affordable housing. Supervisor Hannigan recommended a graduated 
ratio instead of a set 3:1 ratio. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of non-irrigated agricultural land 
holding the same significance as irrigated agricultural land, commented in 
support of the County using an accredited land trust for the conservation 
easements, and requested more clarification within the ordinance regarding 
in-lieu fees.
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the County creating a Department 
of Conservation and in support of the recommended action to include amending 
Section 2.2-330 (A) (1) by adding the words “up to” and Section 2.2-330 (A) (3) by 
changing the word “shall” to the word “may”. Supervisor Vasquez further 
recommended having several different County departments and agencies be part 
of the review process for future mitigations.
Chair Mashburn commented in support of the recommended action and in 
support of the recommended changes from Supervisor Vasquez. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding in-lieu payments, 
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated using the in-lieu option will be a last 
resort. Ms. Curry further stated 2.2-350(c) does provide a process for this to 
happen. 
Supervisor Williams stated she is not in favor of moving forward with the 
ordinance today, noting that the tweaks should be worked out first with the 
reco

chunks.text:
Adopt and present a resolution recognizing November 11, 2024, as 
Veterans Day and honoring all Solano County residents who have served

Vasquez)
A - Veterans Day Resolution
Attachments:
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

chunks.item_title: Adopt and present a resolution recognizing November 11, 2024, as Veterans
chunks.text:
Adopt and present a resolution recognizing November 11, 2024, as Veterans 
Day and honoring all Solano County residents who have served and are 
currently serving in the United States Armed Forces (Supervisor Vasquez)
A - Veterans Day Resolution
Attachments:
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
adopted and presented Resolution No. 2024-179, recognizing November 11, 
2024, as Veterans Day and honoring all Solano County residents who have 
served and are currently serving in the United States Armed Forces. So 
ordered by a 5-0. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-179
Page 1
Solano County

November 5, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on matters
not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board.
The following comments were received:
A) Michael Wright commented on various issues.
B) Dulce Bedolla commented on issues with unpermitted street vendors.
Director of Resource Management James Bezek provided an overview of steps 
being taken by the Department of Resource Management to stop unpermitted 
street vendors. 
Supervisor Vasquez recommended this topic be addressed at the City County 
Coordinating Committee meeting and commented on the lack of cooperation 
from the cities on code enforcement.
Mr. Bezek stated staff will be providing a presentation at the next Land Use 
Transportation Committee meeting as well. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated many jurisdictions are facing this problem. 
Mr. Emlen further stated the County can take steps to update its ordinances to 
address code enforcement. 
Chair Mashburn commented on actions that the County is taking for enforcement 
and stated there is a need for the cities and the County to coordinate efforts 
regarding this issue. Chair Mashburn encouraged members of the public to 
contact their cities and attend city council meetings to encourage cities to begin 
code enforcement. 
C) George Guynn, Jr. commented on various items.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff had no additions to or deletions 
from the Solano County Board of Supervisors' agenda for November 5, 2024. 
Mr. Emlen further requested the Board reconvene at 1:10 P.M. for the 1:30 
P.M. Closed Session for an initial briefing.
Chair Mashburn requested Agenda Item No. 14 and Agenda Item No. 16 be 
switched, to allow Agenda Item No. 16 to be heard first on the Regular 
Calendar.
