chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation from MES Concepts, LLC on an Inclusive Leadership
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation from MES Concepts, LLC on an Inclusive Leadership 
Program; Consider approval of a contract with MES Concepts, LLC for up to 
$136,700 to provide comprehensive inclusive 
leadership 
services 
over 
an 
initial 6-month period; Consider approval of participation of up to seven 
Solano 
Superior 
Court 
staff 
in 
the 
program; 
Consider 
changing 
the 
subcommittee 
name 
to 
“Committee 
for 
an 
Inclusive 
Workforce”; 
and 
Consider delegating authority to the County Administrator to execute the 
contract with MES Concepts, LLC
A - Subcommittee Minutes
B - Draft Contract
C - Presentation
Attachments:
Assistant County Administrator Debbie Vaughn introduced the item. 
Supervisor Hannigan provided a brief overview of the steps taken by the Social 
Equity Committee in the process of developing a plan to create a culture of 
inclusion for the County. 
Supervisor Williams commented on the significance of inclusion for the Board 
and the employees who work in the County, noting inclusion is important to 
ensure the employees know they are valued in the County. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented on concerns with regard to the recommended 
training, the creation of another committee, and the costs to the County. 
Supervisor Vasquez inquired if the Courts will be paying for a portion of the 
program. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez, Supervisor Hannigan stated 
the courts will not be participating financially because the number of employees 
participating from the courts is insignificant compared to the number of Solano 
County employees who are participating.
Supervisor Vasquez requested prior to approving the item, staff return with an 
additional presentation on the total impact and cost to the organization for the 
implementation of this program including the creation of a new committee.
A discussion period was held. 
Consultant Mary Stutts provided an overview of the MES Concepts, culture of 
inclusion framework and program goals.
Page 6
Solano County

November 5, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Brown commented on the need to implement internship programs 
and funding education programs. Supervisor Brown inquired if staff has worked 
with the unions to discuss the potential impacts to the employees workload. 
In response to Supervisor Brown’s comments, Ms. Stutts stated Supervisor 
Brown is commenting on hiring a diverse workforce, but this program is to teach 
the current workforce to train leaders how to become more inclusive. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the potential significant impact both financially 
and for staff time that will be committed to addressing a cultural change within the 
organization. Chair Mashburn further stated he would like to see additional 
information that addresses the authority of the proposed advisory committee, 
noting an advisory committee should not have the authority to enact changes. 
Chair Mashburn recommended bifurcating the recommended action to approve 
the contract, the learning tour, workshop,and to change the name of the 
committee, while delaying the approval of the creation of the advisory committee.
A discussion period was held. 
In response to Chair Mashburn’s question regarding cost, Ms. Vaughn stated for 
1100 employees to receive the recommended training, there will be an additional 
cost of roughly $150,000. Ms. Vaughn further stated the Board could choose to 
bifurcate the motion to include approval of the contract, workshops, listening tour, 
and committee name change, noting creation of the committee could be 
addressed at a separate time. 
A discussion was held by the Board regarding Solano County’s current workforce 
demographics and representation in management. The Board further discussed 
Solano County’s culture and current recruiting and promoting practices and how 
the recommended program will impact both.
Supervisor Hannigan stated she is not in favor of bifurcating the motion and made 
a motion to approve the item as recommended in the staff report. 
Supervisor Williams seconded the motion. 
Chair Mashburn offered an substitute motion to approve the recommended 
contract, complete the learning tour and workshops, change the name of the 
committee, approve participation of up to seven Solano Superior Court staff in the 
program, and directed staff to return to the Board for further discussion and 
direction prior to the creation of the advisory committee. 
Supervisor Vasquez seconded the substitute motion.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A)
George Guynn, Jr. commented on the cost of the program to the
taxpayers.
Page 7
Solano County

November 5, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
On motion of Chair Mashburn, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the Board: 1) 
approved of a contract with MES Concepts, LLC for up to $136,700 to provide 
comprehensive inclusive leadership services over an initial 6-month period; 2) 
approved participation of up to seven Solano Superior Court staff in the 
program; 3) changed the subcommittee name to “Committee for an Inclusive 
Workforce”; 4) directed staff to return to the Board prior to the formation of the 
employee committee with an overview of the full range of costs to the County 
regarding ongoing work of the committee; and 5) delegated authority to the 
County Administrator to execute the contract with MES Concepts, LLC. So 
ordered by a 5-0 vote.
15

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider a request to extend the timeline
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider a request to extend the timeline 
to file the Small Lot Final Map for Major Subdivision Application No. S-21-01 
(Wagner) for an additional 10 years, which proposes to divide 27 existing 
parcels into 322 separate residential parcels and multiple additional parcels 
for right-of-way, parks and open space, Village Green, Community Service 
uses, and stormwater detention areas, near the intersection of Green Valley 
Road and Mason Road north of the City of Fairfield within the Middle Green 
Valley Specific Plan area in unincorporated Solano County; Consider adopting 
a resolution approving the requested time extension; The original project 
approval was found to be exempt from additional environmental review as 
provided in CEQA Guidelines §15168 (c) with no additional CEQA compliance 
required
A - New Final Small Lot Map Resolution
B - Exhibit A Original Resolution/Conditions of Approval
C - Request for Extension
D - Presentation
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Principal Planner Mathew Walsh provided an overview of the request for a time 
extension for the Middle Green Valley Subdivision S-21-01 to file a small lot 
subdivision map.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the time extension, 
Mr. Walsh stated the extension is to supply time for the developer to meet 
requirements which include infrastructure and environmental concerns linked to 
the Environmental Impact Review that need to be addressed prior to approving 
the small lot subdivision map.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding if it is normal for it 
to take an additional 10 years, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated there is a 
need for additional time because the applicants are working with the City of 
Fairfield to address issues with the General Plan, while concurrently there is 
ongoing litigation. Ms. Curry noted a major hurdle the developer is facing is an 
option that was approved by the Board pertaining to water services which has 
been challenged.
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated this project has many steps that have 
been held up due to both the ongoing litigation and a significant amount of 
Page 8
Solano County

November 5, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
engineering that is required for this project.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the project’s uniqueness, noting there is a 
public benefit to the project. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Willliams regarding if the extended 
timeline will change the uniqueness of the project, Mr. Bezek stated the novel 
aspect of this project is the amount of area that has been put in conservation, 
noting the developers created a mechanism to develop housing and still honor 
agriculture. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public to
address the Board on this matter and the following comments were received:
A) Charity Wagner commented in support of the recommended action on the
project.
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Chair Mashburn, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2024-182, approving the extension of Small Lot 
Tentative Subdivision Map S-21-01 within the Middle Green Valley Specific 
Plan Area. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-182
14

chunks.item_title: Consider introducing an ordinance to add Chapter
chunks.text:
Consider introducing an ordinance to add Chapter 
13.5, Water Efficient 
Landscapes, to the Solano County Code to adopt the State’s Model Water 
Efficient Landscape Ordinance, California Code of Regulations, Title 
23, 
Division 2, Chapter 2.7, consistent with State law; the proposed ordinance is 
exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) under CEQA 
Guidelines §§ 15061(b)(3), 15307, and 15308 
A - WELO Ordinance
B - WELO Application - Full Package
C - WELO Application - Alt Compliance Package
Attachments:
Planning Program Manager Allan Calder introduced the item.
Environmental Health Specialist Elizabeth Whitford provided an overview of the 
recommended Solano County Model Water Efficient Landscape ordinance.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding why the County is 
considered to be out of compliance, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the 
State of California (State) adopted legislation that required local jurisdictions to 
adopt either the State’s model ordinance or to adopt an ordinance that is equally 
effective. 
A discussion was held regarding what would trigger a review or enforcement of 
the recommended ordinance and what exemptions are included in the ordinance 
with Mr. Bezek stating if there is an existing landscaping system and the applicant 
Page 9
Solano County

November 5, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
expands the landscaping greater than 2500 sq feet, a review would be triggered 
per the ordinance; however, if it is less than that threshold, it would not apply. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if there is an exemption 
for agriculture, Ms. Whitford stated the law does differentiate between a garden 
and actual agriculture. 
In response to Board discussion, County Administrator Bill Emlen stated the 
reason staff waited to bring this item forward is because it is difficult to apply this 
type of ordinance to county development. 
Consultant Kathy Pease stated a typical single-family residential landscaping 
would only come under this law when there is a major subdivision proposing 
landscaping, which would trigger a review from Planning. 
Director of Resource Management James Bezek stated when a developer brings 
a plan forward they will most likely already have the best practices in place which 
will meet these requirements already. 
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board: 1) read the proposed ordinance by title only and waive further reading 
by majority vote; 2) determined that the proposed ordinance is exempt from 
the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant to CEQA Guidelines §
§15061(b)(3), 15307 and 15308; and 3) introduced an ordinance to add Chapter 
13.5 Water Efficient Landscapes, to the Solano County Code to adopt the 
State’s Model Water Efficient Landscape Ordinance, California Code of 
Regulations, Title 23, Division 2, Chapter 2.7, consistent with State law. So 
ordered by a 5-0 vote.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional items from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:

of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of David Fisher
B) Supervisor Williams requested that this meeting of the Solano County
Board of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Webster Rosboro and Julia
Lockwood Busher.

chunks.item_title: Receive
chunks.text:
Receive 
a 
report 
from 
Lisette 
Estrella-Henderson, 
Solano 
County 
Superintendent of Schools, Solano County Office of Education regarding the 
“State of the Schools related to the Williams Case Settlement audit” for the 
2024-2025 school year, specifically schools identified for visitation
A - Williams Settlement Report Letter, 2024-2025
B - State of the Schools, Williams Settlement Report
Attachments:
Solano County Superintendent of Schoools Lisette Estrella-Henderson 
introduced the item and provided an overview of the Williams Case 
Settlement Audit for the 2024/25 school year.
Dr. Tracey Rogers provided an overview of the results for the individual 
school visits.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding if the Williams 
Case Settlement Audit tracks truancies and absences, Ms. 
Estrella-Henderson stated truancies and absences are not a part of the 
Williams Case Settlement Audit. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding internet access 
on campuses and it's ability to function properly when numerous devices are 
being used, Ms. Estrella-Henderson stated the question of working internet is 
not asked on the Facility Inspection Tool. 
Page 5
Solano County

November 12, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding three schools 
with non-applicable information in the 2024-25 Visitation Results Summary 
Unanswered Complaints in Relation fo the Uniform Complaint Procedure, Dr. 
Rogers stated charter schools are not required to have a uniform complaint 
process and therefore not monitored.
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding access to funding 
for school infrastructure maintenance and if the Williams Case Settlement 
Audit opens eligibility for schools to access funding and alleviate those 
maintenance concerns, Ms. Estrella-Henderson stated it's the school 
district's responsibility to address issues that are out of compliance especially 
emergency repairs.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
Received
15

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation by the Department of Resource Management on the
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation by the Department of Resource Management on the 
NextEra Battery Energy Storage System AB 205 “Opt-In” application which 
allows certain developers to apply for a permit directly through the California 
Energy Commission (CEC); Provide direction as to whether the Board wants 
to request a Host Community Agreement in the County’s response to the 
CEC in lieu of the required Community Benefits Agreement Plan; and Provide 
feedback on NextEra Energy Resources’ proposed Community Benefits Plan 
Outline and staff recommended community benefit projects
A - Proposed Host Community Benefits
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item and 
stated a correction needed to be made on page 2 of Attachment A, clarifying 
the paragraph detailing the NextEra Proposal is information related to the 
case study and not the NextEra Proposal.
Planning Manager Allan Calder provided some background on the Solano 
County Moratorium approved by the Board on February 27, 2024, the State 
"Opt-In" Process and the NextEra Energy Resources proposed Corby 
project. Mr. Calder stated in addition to the Corby Battery Energy Storage 
System (BESS) proposal, an additional proposal has been received for the 
PG&E campus in the unincorporated. Mr. Calder further stated because the 
proposal uses more than 300-megawatt hours, the applicant was able to 
apply via the AB 205 Opt-In Process. 
Mr. Calder provided an update on NextEra's AB 205 Application Status stating 
the application was submitted on November 4, 2024 and a completeness 
determination by the Energy Commission (CEC) would need to be made by 
December 4, 2024. Mr. Calder stated the County received the application and 
would need to respond within the next 20 days. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding whether the 
County emphasized to the CEC the significance of prime agricultural land, Mr. 
Page 6
Solano County

November 12, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Calder stated it was emphasized. Mr. Calder further stated the current 
agricultural mitigation ordinance looks to mitigate the loss of both prime and 
non-prime agricultural lands; however, the current application was submitted 
before the ordinance takes effect.
In response to an additional question from Supervisor Williams regarding the 
Good Neighbor Policy, Deputy County Counsel Holly Tokar stated the CEC 
held one pre-application meeting with the County, City of Vacaville and 
various state agencies. NextEra also held a meeting with County staff to 
touch on briefly on community benefits. Ms. Tokar stated the Good Neighbor 
Policy can now take effect since the application was submitted; however, the 
applicant would still need to go through the CEQA process and host two 
community meetings.
Mr. Calder defined the Community Benefits Agreement (CBA) and the Host 
Community Agreement (HCA) stating the CBA is between the developer and 
community-based organization and/or non-profit specifying the offered 
benefits in exchange for the community's support of the project and is a 
required component of the AB 205 process, while the HCA is an agreement 
between the developer and host jurisdiction to offset and address adverse 
effects on the host jurisdiction. 
Mr. Calder provided a brief overview the Medway Grid project in 
Massachusetts, a comparable project to the Corby project, stating the 
project's worth is about $43,464,019 over the life of the project.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding how the project’s 
profits would affect the County, Associate Planner Eric Hagstrom stated in 
regards to the Medway Project, though there were several stipulations for the 
use of funds, a large chunk of the money was in a payment in lieu of taxes.
Mr. Bezek stated the values were meant to show a relationship between the 
250-megawatt Medway Project and the 300-megawatt Corby Project and
what could be potentially negotiated.
Chair Mashburn stated it would be the Board’s job to determine the price and 
utilization of the land.
Mr. Bezek stated the state has identified there is a need in order to provide the 
continuity of services, but placement is critical, so staff is seeking assistance 
and direction with that process.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding the lifespan of 
such projects and the potential dollar amount that could be generated from 
these types of projects, Mr. Calder stated there is a 20-30 year lifespan and 
the project could roughly generate $52 million. 
A discussion period was held regarding the potential profitability of the project
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding what happens 
to the facility after the 20-30 year lifespan, Mr. Calder stated a huge part of the 
Page 7
Solano County

November 12, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
agricultural mitigation ordinance is the decommissioning aspect and how to 
return the land back to its original production.
In response to an additional from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the potential 
impacts to surrounding areas should something occur on the site, Mr. Calder 
stated unfortunately permitting happens through the state and is not governed 
by local regulations.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding a flagging 
system that can alert staff when prime agricultural land is being purchased 
and if staff has identified alternate locations in the unincorporated that could 
be offered instead of prime agricultural land. Mr. Calder stated there is no 
current flagging mechanism in place to prevent the purchase of prime 
agricultural land nor trade for the highest quality agricultural land. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen commented on AB 205 stating legislation 
such as this really undercuts the County and local objectives. 
Mr. Bezek stated the goal throughout the ordinance process is to identify the 
best practices in regard to land use and to provide a better-informed pla

Approve the acceptance of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency 
Prevention (OJJDP) FY24 Arts Programs for Justice-Involved Youth Grant 
in the amount of $50,000 for the period of October 1, 2024 through June 
30, 2025 to develop and implement a high-quality, therapeutic arts 
programming; Delegate authority to the County Administrator, pending 
County Counsel concurrence, to execute the FY24 Arts Programs for 
Justice-Involved Youth grant agreement and any subsequent amendments, 
up to an aggregate of $74,999 per fiscal year; Authorize the Chief 
Probation Officer to make grant amendments which are administrative or 
technical in nature; and Approve an Appropriations Transfer Request 
recognizing $50,000 in unanticipated revenue offset by grant 
appropriations (4/5 vote required)
A - OJJDP Arts Program Solicitation
B - Solano County Program Description
C - Solano County Program Budget
Attachments:
Sheriff's Office:
13

chunks.item_title: Adopt a resolution approving participation in the 2024 Homeland Security
chunks.text:
Adopt a resolution approving participation in the 2024 Homeland Security 
Grant Program (HSGP) for the period September 1, 2024 through May 31, 
2027, affirming the grant expenditure plan and authorizing the Sheriff, 
Undersheriff, Director of Administrative Services, or Emergency Services 
Manager to take any actions necessary to obtain and administer this grant, 
and pending County Counsel concurrence, sign all grant related documents 
and any service contracts and subsequent amendments itemized in the 
grant expenditure plan; Approve $135,298 for Solano Operational Area 
joint-agency response teams and non-county agencies for training and to 
purchase equipment and protective gear; Approve fixed asset purchases 
totaling $247,098 for an automatic sandbag machine, an access control 
camera system, portable cellular cameras, light amplification/night vision 
devices, and interoperable communications equipment; and Approve an 
Appropriation Transfer Request recognizing $448,956 in unanticipated 
grant revenue offset with grant expenditures (4/5 vote required)
A - 2024 HSGP Grant Resolution
B - 2024 HSGP Expenditure Plan
Attachments:

Solano County
Printed on 11/27/2024

chunks.item_title: 1. CONFERENCE WITH LEGAL COUNSEL - EXISTING LITIGATION
chunks.text:
1. CONFERENCE WITH LEGAL COUNSEL - EXISTING LITIGATION 
(Pursuant to Government Code § 54956.9(a)) - John Doe v. County of 
Solano et al. (United States District Court, Eastern District of California, 
Case No.: 2:23-cv-00180 DJC AC)
2. CONFERENCE WITH LEGAL COUNSEL - ANTICIPATED LITIGATION 
(Pursuant to Government Code § 54956.9(d)(2) - Significant Exposure to 
Litigation (one case)
3. CONFERENCE WITH LABOR NEGOTIATORS (Pursuant to 
Government Code § 54957.6): Solano County representatives: Director of 
Human Resources Niger Edwards, County Administrator Bill Emlen, 
Assistant County Administrator Debbie Vaughn and Assistant County 
Administrator Ian Goldberg. Employee organizations: Teamsters, Local 
150 for Unit 1 (Attorneys); SEIU Local 1021 for Unit 2 (Nurses), Unit 5 
(Health and Welfare Employees), Unit 7 (Regulatory, Technical and 
General Services Employees), Unit 8 (General Services Supervisors), Unit 
9 (Clerical Employees) and Units 82, 87, 89, and 90 (Extra Help 
Employees); Solano County Deputy Sheriff's Association for Unit 3 (Law 
Enforcement Employees) and Unit 4 (Law Enforcement Supervisors); 
Public Employees Union, Local One for Unit 6 (Health and Welfare 
Supervisors) and Unit 16 (Mid-Management Employees); Stationary 
Engineers, Local 39 for Unit 10 (Skilled Craft and Service Maintenance 
Employees); Union of American Physicians and Dentists for Unit 11 
(Physicians, Dentists and Psychiatrists); Solano County Probation Peace 
Officer Association for Unit 12 (Probation Employees) and Unit 15 
(Probation Supervisors); Solano County Sheriff's Custody Association for 
Unit 13 (Correctional Officers); Teamsters, Local 856 for Unit 14 
(Correctional Supervisors); Solano County Law Enforcement Management 
Association for Unit 17 (Law Enforcement Management) and Unit 18 
(Sheriff's Office Management); Professional and Technical Engineers, 
Local 21 for Unit 19 (Executive and Senior Management); Unit 60 
Legislative Group; Unit 61 (unrepresented Executive Management 
Employees), Unit 62 (unrepresented Senior Management Employees) and 
Unit 30 (Confidential Employees)
RECONVENE

chunks.item_title: Adopt and present a resolution proclaiming the week of December 1-7, 2024,
chunks.text:
Adopt and present a resolution proclaiming the week of December 1-7, 2024, 
as Centenarian Week in Solano County, and Receive a video presentation
A - 2024 Centenarian Resolution
Attachments:
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Chair Mashburn, the Board 
adopted and presented Resolution No. 2024-193, proclaiming the week of 
December 1-7, 2024, as Centenarian Week in Solano County. So ordered by a 
5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-193
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on 
matters not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of 
the Board. The following comments were received:
A) Scott Brown commented on the seizure of and alleged damage to his
personal property by County staff.
B) Mike Whitley commented on a request for the Board to create a quiet zone
down Elmira Road.
C) George Guynn, Jr. commented on various issues.
Page 2
Solano County

December 3, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
D) Director of General Services Megan Greve introduced the new fleet
manager Louis O'Choa.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of 
Supervisors' agenda for December 3, 2024.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for December 
3, 2024 as submitted. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items 
listed on the Consent Calendar. The following comments were received:
A) George Guynn, Jr. commented in opposition to Consent Calendar Item
No. 7, noting there are many issues with public electric vehicle chargers.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
approved the following Consent Calendar items by 5-0 vote:

chunks.item_title: Receive and approve the Solano County Public Works Five Year Capital
chunks.text:
Receive and approve the Solano County Public Works Five Year Capital 
Improvement Plan for FY2024/25 through FY2029/30 from the Department of 
Resource Management; and Consider adopting a resolution approving the 
proposed project list for FY2025/26 in accordance with the State of California 
Road Repair and Accountability Act of 2017 requirements
A - Capital Improvement Plan 2025
B - SB 1 Resolution FY2025-26
C - Exhibit A SB1 Projects List
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item. 
Engineering Manager Mathew Tuggle provided an overview of the 5-year 
Capital Improvement Plan.
In response to a question from Supervisor Hannigan regarding the cost of the 
phase 1 sidewalk improvements, Mr. Tuggle stated the cost varies depending 
on the amount of sidewalk being installed, noting the Thomas Avenue 
sidewalk improvements cost between $40,000 and $50,000.
Page 9
Solano County

December 3, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the ways in which the County has 
utilized the SB1 Funding to protect the County's roads. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding issues with 
potholes on Cordelia Road, Mr. Tuggle stated Cordelia Road has special 
circumstances because it alternates between being in the unincorporated 
areas of the County and two different cities, noting that County staff needs to 
collaborate with the cities to complete repairs. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding expansion of the 
license plate readers, Mr. Bezek stated it is a grant funded program and 
County staff is working on obtaining more funding.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board: 1) approved the Solano County Public Works Five Year Capital 
Improvement Plan for FY2024/25 through FY2029/30 from the Department of 
Resource Management; and 2) adopted Resolution No. 2024-202, approving the 
proposed project list for FY2025/26 in accordance with the State of California 
Road Repair and Accountability Act of 2017 requirements. So ordered by a 5-0 
vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-202
28

ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.

discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing; and Consider adopting a resolution 
approving General Plan Amendment (G-24-01) to update the Public Health 
and Safety Chapter of the General Plan to address recent State 
requirements for General Plans, including information relating to 
evacuation routes, minimum road widths and clearances around structures, 
mapping of known seismic hazards, current flooding and fire risk 
conditions, hazard mapping, flooding and fire hazard-related policies, a 
climate change vulnerability assessment, and comprehensively addressing 
the short-term and long-term threats posed by climate change; the project 
is exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant 
to §15061(B)(3) of the CEQA Guidelines

ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of 
Supervisors' agenda for December 10, 2024. County Administrator Bill Emlen 
provided a reminder that there will be a 2 P.M. Land Use item on the agenda. 
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for December 
10, 2024 as submitted. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items 
listed on the Consent Calendar. The following comments were received:
A) Solano County Fair Association CEO Tom Keaney commented in support
of Consent Calendar Item No. 12.
B) Joseph Joyce commented in support of Consent Calendar Item No. 12.
C) George Guynn, Jr. commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 29.
Chair Mashburn commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 18 and 
recognized Urlita Coronel-Mangune on her retirement from Solano County.
Supervisor Vasquez offered congratulations to employees whose retirements 
are listed on the Consent Calendar. 
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board approved the following Consent Calendar items by 5-0 vote:

chunks.item_title: Receive an update from the Solano Economic Development Corporation on
chunks.text:
Receive an update from the Solano Economic Development Corporation on 
2024 activities and accomplishments 
A - Solano EDC Presentation Links
Attachments:
President and CEO for the Solano Economic Development Corporation 
(EDC) Chris Rico provided the Board with an overview of the Solano EDC 
2024 activities and accomplishments.
Supervisor Brown requested Mr. Rico begin providing monthly updates 
regarding non-profit capacity building that is being completed by the EDC with 
the use of funding awarded to the EDC by Solano County. 
Discussion was held regarding the lack of philanthropy foundation funding in 
Solano County.
Supervisor Williams requested Mr. Rico look into what changes need to be 
made to encourage more philanthropy in Solano County. 
Supervisor Hannigan commented in support of the Solano Biz-Grow 
Revolving Loan Program and commented on the need for more philanthropy 
foundation funding being brought to Solano County.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
Received

chunks.text:
Receive an update from staff and the County’s federal and State Legislative 
Advocates on matters of interest to the County that were discussed at the 
December 2, 2024 Legislative Committee meeting; and Consider approval of 
Solano County’s Proposed 2025 Federal Legislative Platform and Proposed 
2025 State Legislative Platform
Page 11
Solano County

December 10, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
A - Red Lined, CY2025 Federal Platform
B - Clean Version, CY2025 Federal Platform
C - Red Lined CY2025 State Platform
D - Clean Version, CY2025 State Platform
E - Recap of 2024 Legislative Session
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Matthew Davis introduced the item. 
Federal 
legislative 
advocate 
Hassan 
Sarsour 
provided 
an 
update 
on 
information on federal legislation of interest to the County.
State legislative advocate Karen Lange provided an update on information on 
state legislation of interest to the County.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding potential budget 
cuts at the State level, Ms. Lange stated at this time, it is unknown where cuts 
might take place. Ms. Lange further stated she believes the State will not 
make large cuts from only one or two budgets, but will most likely spread it 
out over multiple budget units. 
Supervisor Hannigan commented on the importance of having representation 
in Sacramento and thanked Ms. Lange for the work she has completed on 
behalf of Solano County.
Mr. Davis provided a brief overview of the creation process and importance of 
the 2025 State and Federal Legislative Platforms.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board approved Solano County’s Proposed 2025 Federal Legislative Platform 
and Proposed 2025 State Legislative Platform. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.

chunks.text:

protection district impact fees for the Cordelia, Dixon, Suisun, and Vacaville 
Fire Protection Districts; and Approve a resolution adopting the fire protection 
impact fees effective February 
9, 2025 for each of the respective fire 
protection districts and authorizing the levying of the fees on the respective 
jurisdictions

Principal Management Analyst Anne Putney introduced the item and provided 
a brief overview of the proposed 2024 Fire Impact Fees increase. 
Page 12
Solano County

December 10, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if the Fire 
Impact Fees and the Municipal Service Review (MSR) completed by LAFCO 
are coordinated, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated in terms of the 
MSR, areas of growth are a part of what the MSR looks at which would be 
covered during the Fire Impact Fees update. Ms. Curry further stated the 
consultant working on the 2025 Fire Impact Fee study should be working with 
LAFCO.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding why there is an 
additional cost for mobile homes, Ms. Putney stated the costs are taken 
directly from the California Construction Cost Index and she would need to 
look over the information to provide an answer. Ms. Putney further stated she 
will provide that information to Supervisor Williams following the meeting. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public 
to address the Board on this matter and the following comments were 
received:

Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.

Board adopted Resolution No. 2024-215. adopting the fire protection impact 
fees effective February 9, 2025 for each of the respective fire protection districts 
and authorizing the levying of the fees on the respective jurisdictions. So 
ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)

chunks.text:
Receive a presentation and affirm the submission on the CalAIM Initiative 
including the Sheriff’s Office Implementation Plan and Budget required by the 
California Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) to provide 90-Day 
Pre-Release Medi-Cal services to Solano County’s justice-involved persons 
within the County jails; Delegate authority to the County Administrator to 
approve 
the 
Implementation 
Plan 
and 
Budget 
including 
any 
subsequent 
Page 13
Solano County

December 10, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
technical adjustments or amendments; Adopt a resolution amending the List 
of Numbers and Classification of Positions to add 1.0 FTE Project Manager 
(Limited-Term) in the Inmate Programming Division of the Sheriff’s Office; 
and 
Approve 
two 
Appropriation 
Transfer 
Requests 
totaling 
$572,564 
recognizing unanticipated revenue offset by grant related expenditures in both 
the Sheriff’s Office budget and the CalAIM PATH-JI Round 3 budget (4/5 vote 
required) 
A - PATH JI Round 3 Implementation Plan
B - PATH JI Round 3 Budget
C - CalAIM PATH-JI R3 Presentation
D - Position Resolution
Attachments:
Program Services Manager Renee Smith provided an overview of the CalAIM 
Justice-Involved Initiative program.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding what it means to 
"draw down" MediCal, Ms. Smith stated to "draw down" MediCal means to bill 
for services and receive funding for those services provided by the jail which 
is something the jail has never been able to do before. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the lack of 
funding under reentry planning and coordination, Ms. Smith stated there was 
no need for funding in this section because this work is already being 
completed by in-house providers whose work will be shifted to this grant.
Chair Mashburn thanked staff for their work on obtaining the grant funding, 
and commented in support of the program, noting it is the first time the 
County will be able to utilize MediCal funding for services provided in the jail.
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the program, noting it will help 
improve the lives and health of those individuals who are in the system.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Hannigan, the 
Board: 1) affirmed the submission of the CalAIM Initiative including the 
Sheriff’s Office Implementation Plan and Budget required by the California 
Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) to provide 90-Day Pre-Release 
Medi-Cal services to Solano County’s justice-involved persons within the 
County jails; 2) delegated authority to the County Administrator to approve the 
Implementation Plan and Budget including any subsequent technical 
adjustments or amendments; 3) adopted Resolution No. 2024-215, amending 
the List of Numbers and Classification of Positions to add 1.0 FTE Project 
Manager (Limited-Term) in the Inmate Programming Division of the Sheriff’s 
Office; and 4) approved two Appropriation Transfer Requests totaling $572,564 
recognizing unanticipated revenue offset by grant related expenditures in both 
the Sheriff’s Office budget and the CalAIM PATH-JI Round 3 budget (4/5 vote 
required). So ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-215

FY2023/24
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.

Aguilar-Vasquez provided an overview of the Solano County Housing Authority 
FY2023/24 activities.

additional funding for housing to be built, enabling more vouchers to be used,

chunks.item_title: Consider
chunks.text:
Consider 
the 
appointment 
of 
a 
Solano 
County 
representative 
to 
the 
Metropolitan Transportation Commission to fill the remainder of a 4-year term 
from February 1, 2025 through February 9, 2027, to be selected from the 
Solano County City Selection Committee's nomination of Mitch Mashburn, 
Pippin Dew, or Trevor Macenski
A - Resignation Letter - J. Spering
Attachments:
Chief Deputy Clerk of the Board Alicia Draves introduced the item and 
provided a brief overview of the City Selection Committee nomination process 
for the Solano County representative to the Metropolitan Transportation 
Commission (MTC).
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the potential 
conflict of appointing a member from the City of Benicia, County Counsel 
Bernadette Curry stated the Solano County Transit (SolTrans) Joint Powers 
Authority is made up of two members from the City of Vallejo and two 
members from the City of Benicia, as well as the MTC representative. Ms. 
Curry further stated that in order to avoid over-representation for either city, if 
the appointed MTC representative is a city council member from either city or 
a supervisor who represents either city, then the MTC representative is 
appointed by the Solano Transportation Authority Board.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding posting 
requirements for vacancy notices and posting on the Solano County website, 
Ms. Draves stated all vacancy notices for the Board of Supervisors are 
posted per the Maddy Act on the County's website, under the Board of 
Page 15
Solano County

December 10, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisors' Boards and Commissions page. Ms. Draves further stated, this 
particular vacancy is not a vacancy of the Board of Supervisors, but is a 
vacancy for the Solano County City Selection Committee; therefore, the 
vacancy notice was posted on the City Selection Committee's webpage 
which can be found on the Solano County website. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding Maddy Act 
requirements, Ms. Draves stated the Maddy Act is a portion of the 
Government Code that pertains directly to the posting of vacancy notices to 
ensure the appointment process is transparent. Ms. Draves further stated 
vacancy notices are posted individually online and as a list in the lobby 
window of the county administration center. Ms. Draves further stated there is 
an additional list posted both in the lobby window of the county administration 
center and at the County's libraries that contains all expected upcoming 
vacancies for the following year that are as a result of a term ending. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) City of Suisun City Mayor Alma Hernandez commented on the City
Selection Committee process of selecting individuals for the
recommendation, noting that there was discussion and a motion made to
delay the vote; however, it was defeated. Therefore, the City Selection
Committee nominated three individuals. Mayor Hernandez further
commented on the importance of the role of this position.
B) Pippen Dew provided the Board with an overview of her past work
experience in relation to her nomination.
C) Benicia City Council Member Trevor Macenski provided the Board with an
overview of his past work experience in relation to his nomination.
D) Chair Mitch Mashburn provided the Board with an overview of his past
work experience in relation to his nomination.
Supervisor Vasquez nominated Chair Mitch Mashburn for the position.
Supervisor Hannigan nominated Pippen Dew for the position.
Supervisor Williams nominated Trevor Macenski for the position.
Supervisor Brown seconded Supervisor Vasquez's nomination of Chair Mitch 
Mashburn.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board 
appointed Board of Supervisors Member Mitch Mashburn to the Metropolitan 
Transportation Commission to fill the remainder of a 4-year term from February 
1, 2025 through February 9, 2027. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Page 16
Solano County

December 10, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Hannigan commented on her time on the Board and wished
everyone a happy holidays.
B) Supervisor Williams thanked Supervisor Hannigan for her work over the
years and wished everyone a Merry Christmas and Happy New Year.

chunks.item_title: Conduct
chunks.text:
Conduct 
a 
noticed 
public 
hearing; 
and 
Consider 
adopting 
a 
resolution 
approving General Plan Amendment (G-24-01) to update the Public Health 
and Safety Chapter of the General Plan to address recent State requirements 
for 
General 
Plans, 
including 
information 
relating 
to 
evacuation 
routes, 
minimum road widths and clearances around structures, mapping of known 
seismic hazards, current flooding and fire risk conditions, hazard mapping, 
flooding 
and 
fire 
hazard-related 
policies, 
a 
climate 
change 
vulnerability 
assessment, and comprehensively addressing the short-term and long-term 
threats posed by climate change; the project is exempt from the California 
Page 17
Solano County

December 10, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant to §15061(B)(3) of the CEQA 
Guidelines
A - BOS Resolution
B - Links to Attachments B through H
Attachments:
Planning Program Manager Allan Calder introduced the item.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding FEMA funding to 
mitigate the potential of a landslide on Lopes Road, Mr. Walsh stated if the 
update for the Public Health and Safety is approved, a resolution will be 
executed, which will make the County competitive for future grants, although 
he can't specify if it will be a FEMA grant in particular. 
Consultant Eli Krispi provided an overview of the work completed on the 
General Plan Public Health and Safety Chapter update.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding how to look at 
the enhanced focus on wildland-urban interface area and coordinating with 
the cities that have open spaces next to unincorporated areas of Solano 
County, Mr. Krispi stated this is a multi-jurisdictional program even though this 
chapter in particular only deals with the unincorporated areas. Mr. Krispi 
further stated this update is part of a larger program where the cities and the 
County work together to update their Housing Elements and Safety Elements 
at the same time to ensure all are looking at the same issues.
In response to comments from Supervisor Brown regarding FEMA, Mr. 
Bezek, stated this Health and Safety Plan update qualifies the County for 
FEMA disaster relief funds which are prioritized for communities that have an 
updated hazard mitigation plan. Mr. Bezek further stated this update also 
qualifies the County for California Disaster Assistance Act funds, which 
covers both repair and replacement of lost infrastructure and improvements 
as well as providing funding for hazard mitigation activities.
Supervisor Brown stated she has concerns regarding exits routes in the case 
of a natural disaster within her district. Supervisor Brown further stated she 
also has concerns regarding fire safety issues within her district. Supervisor 
Brown stated the County needs additional funding for these type of hazard 
mitigation needs.
In response to Supervisor Brown's comments, Mr. Calder stated the best 
practice for implementation of these types of policies would be to tie them to 
Capital Improvement Plan spending.
A discussion period was held. 
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments 
from the public.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need for additional funding to provide 
for infrastructure improvements for both the County and the cities for potential 
damages as a result of climate change. 
Page 18
Solano County

December 10, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
A discussion period was held regarding potential tax uses.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the 
implementation of the plan being tied to the Capital Improvement Plan, Mr. 
Calder stated implementation could be tied to the Capital Improvement Plan 
and/or the Planning Work Plan so that decisions over the next years would 
relate to the General Plan. Mr. Calder further stated staff is also evaluating the 
creation of an implementation workbook, which is a summary document of 
the General Plan, so that when decisions are made, they can relate directly 
back to the General Plan. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Mr. Calder's comments. 
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2024-216, approving General Plan Amendment 
Application G-24-01 to update the Public Health and Safety Chapter of the 
General Plan to address recent State requirements for General Plans, 
including information relating to evacuation routes, minimum road widths and 
clearances around structures, mapping of known seismic hazards, current 
flooding and fire risk conditions, hazard mapping, flooding and fire 
hazard-related policies, a climate change vulnerability assessment, and 
comprehensively addressing the short-term and long-term threats posed by 
climate change. So ordered by a 4-0 vote with Supervisor Hannigan absent. 
(see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-216
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 2:39 
P.M. Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be
January 7, 2025 at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, Fairfield,
California.

Solano County Board of Supervisors

and December 2024 Winter Storms

B - Resolution
Attachments:

chunks.item_title: Adopt
chunks.text:
Adopt 
a 
resolution 
ratifying 
and 
continuing 
a 
Proclamation 
of 
Local 
Emergency due to damages to levee infrastructure caused by King Tides and 
December 2024 Winter Storms 
A - Proclamation of Local Emergency
B - Resolution
Attachments:
Emergency Services Manager Robyn Rains presented the item and 
gave a brief summary of the storm damage affecting several reclamation 
districts.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding levee 
maintenance, Ms. Rains stated levees are classified as special districts, 
each with its own board responsible for monitoring, managing, and 
repairing any identified issues.
Suisun Resource Conservation District Executive Director Steven 
Chappell stated the Resource Conservation District includes 13 
reclamation districts, which are local government agencies responsible 
for levee maintenance. Mr. Chappell further stated the Resource 
Conservation District holds the necessary permits, including a regional 
general permit for the marsh area, which covers routine levee 
maintenance and storm damage repairs.
Supervisor Williams commented on preparing for the impacts of climate 
change.
In response to Supervisor Hannigan's question about how the 
reclamation districts will prepare for climate change and the future 
condition of the levees, Mr. Chappell stated the limitation in the marsh is 
that the levee's footprint can only be expanded so much before it 
becomes a mitigation project rather than just maintenance. Mr. Chappell 
further stated the current permits allow for maintenance of existing 
structures and keeping pace with sea-level rise.
A brief discussion period was held regarding planning and preparations 
for climate change.
Page 2
Solano County

December 27, 2024
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ADJOURN:
In response to an additional question from Supervisor Hannigan on 
whether the materials used for storm damage control are environmentally 
friendly, Mr. Chappell stated the visqueen plastic sheeting used to protect 
the damaged areas is removed after repairs are completed, and most of 
the burlap sandbags are biodegradable.
In response to Supervisor Williams' question about how long the districts 
will have to wait for funds to make repairs, Ms. Rains stated the signed 
proclamation has been submitted to the Governor for review and to 
declare an emergency; however, approval for funding is not guaranteed.
Supervisor Williams requested staff keep the Board informed throughout 
this process and thanked staff for their work.
In response to Chair Mashburn's question about preparations for the 
upcoming King Tide and concerns about potential damage to other 
levees, Ms. Rains stated there is no reliable forecast for that specific 
three-day event. Mr. Chappell stated several factors affect the severity of 
the King Tide. Mr. Chappell further stated that individuals who have 
experienced flood damage are currently using sandbags and visqueen to 
redirect the water and prevent additional damage.
Chair Mashburn remarked on the importance of safety and the dangers 
associated with these events.
On motion of Supervisor Hannigan, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board adopted Resolution 2024-217, ratifying and continuing a Proclamation of 
Local Emergency due to damages to levee infrastructure caused by King Tides 
and December 2024 Winter Storms. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. (See Resolution 
Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2024-217
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 10:26 
A.M. Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be
January 7, 2025 at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, Fairfield,
California.
________________________________
MITCH H. MASHBURN, Chair
Solano County Board of Supervisors
BILL EMLEN, Clerk
Solano County Board of Supervisors

Veronica Lake, Deputy Clerk

Solano County

Annual Report including activities and accomplishments towards the goals of

including activities and accomplishments towards the County's goals of 
stewardship and the health and well-being of Solano County's citizens. Chair 
Mashburn further provided an overview of the County's fiscal goals and

chunks.item_title: Consider the following:
chunks.text:
Consider the following:
A.
Nomination and election of Chair
B.
Nomination and election of Vice-Chair
C.
Nomination and election of Chair Pro Tem
D.
Seating selection at the dais
Page 2
Solano County

January 7, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
E.
Presentation to outgoing Chair
F.
Remarks by Supervisors
Supervisor Vasquez made a motion to elect Supervisor Mashburn as Chair 
and Supervisor Brown as Vice Chair. Supervisor Brown seconded the 
motion. 
Supervisor Williams made an alternate motion to elect Supervisor Brown as 
Chair, Supervisor Williams to be Vice Chair, and Supervisor James to be 
Chair Pro Tem. The motion failed due to lack of a second. 
Supervisor Brown thanked Supervisor Williams for the nomination, stating 
however, she does not wish to be Chair at this time. 
Supervisor Williams stated she made the recommendation because she felt 
it would be a good opportunity for Supervisor Brown to step into a leadership 
role. Supervisor Williams commented on her desire to move to a procedure 
that allows for a rotation of the position of Chair and Vice-Chair. 
Supervisor Williams commented on the need for more inclusivity in the 
positions of Chair and Vice Chair.
Supervisor Williams made an alternate motion to elect herself as Vice Chair 
and Supervisor James as Chair Pro Tem. The motion failed due to lack of a 
second.
Supervisor Brown stated she does wish to be Vice Chair, she does not wish 
to be Chair at this time. A discussion period was held.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the 
Board elected Supervisor Mashburn as the Chair for 2025 and 
Supervisor Brown as the Vice Chair for 2025. So ordered by a vote of 
3-2 with Supervisor James and Supervisor Williams voting no.
Supervisor Vasquez made a motion to delete the position of Chair Pro Tem 
and amend the Board's Rules of Procedures to reflect the deletion, noting 
during his tenure on the Board, the position has only been used one time. 
Supervisor Vasquez further stated if there is a situation where both the Chair 
and the Vice Chair are unable to attend the meeting, the Board can decide 
who will be the Chair Pro Tem for that single meeting. The motion failed due 
to lack of a second. 
Supervisor Williams commented in opposition to the removal of the Chair Pro 
Tem Position. Supervisor Williams made a motion to maintain the position of 
Chair Pro Tem. Supervisor James seconded the motion noting that this 
position provides new supervisors with a learning tool for being a Chair in the 
future. 
Supervisor Vasquez stated since his motion did not have a second, it fails; 
Page 3
Solano County

January 7, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
therefore the position automatically remains. 
Supervisor Williams nominated herself for the position of Chair Pro Tem. 
Supervisor James seconded the motion. 
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor James, the 
Board elected Supervisor Williams as the Chair Pro Tem for 2025.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) George Guynn, Jr. commented on the reorganization of the Board, noting
it is the public's benefit to have an individual with experience in the position of
Chair.
Chair Mashburn invited Board Members to make remarks. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the expected budget shortfall for the 
State of California and how those shortfalls will impact the County's budget. 
Supervisor Vasquez requested staff work on creating a workshop for the 
Board members that will provide information on those impacts to the County's 
budget. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff will work on a presentation for the 
Board, noting it is good to be proactive. 
Accepted
PRESENTATIONS
4

chunks.item_title: Consider Board of Supervisors’ appointments to various boards,
chunks.text:
Consider Board of Supervisors’ appointments to various boards, 
commissions and committees for 2025
A - 2024 BOS Appointments
Attachments:
Supervisor Vasquez voiced concerns that certain committees are not 
Page 7
Solano County

January 7, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
necessarily following the Brown Act including the Solano Economic 
Development Committee and the Travis Community Consortium and 
indicated he feels the Board Members should not be participating in the 
committees unless they are following the Brown Act. Supervisor Vasquez 
recommended that all agendas for committees the Board Members are 
appointed to should send their agenda's to the Clerk of the Board for 
distribution to all five Board Members. Supervisor Vasquez further 
recommended that the Board consider elimination of the standing 
committees, noting that he feels the full Board should be receiving any 
presentation of information, to ensure all are fully informed prior to having to 
make a decision. Supervisor Vasquez further stated his request is about 
transparency for the public. 
Supervisor Williams recommended requiring Board Members to report on 
actions of the boards, committees, commissions they are appointed to. 
Chair Mashburn commented in support of Supervisor Vasquez's 
recommendation for the elimination of the standing committees. 
A discussion period was held. 
Discussion was held by the Board Members on their requested committee 
appointments
Supervisor Vasquez requested that staff work to send a letter to all the 
boards, committees, and commissions that the Board is appointed to 
requesting agendas be emailed to the Clerk.
Chair Mashburn requested if there was a consensus of the Board to dissolve 
the standing committees of the Board. All five Board Members stated they are 
in agreement with the recommendation. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff will help facilitate the request to 
the agencies so that all Board Members will receive agendas from the 
agencies that the Board Members are appointed to.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, second by Supervisor Brown, the Board: 1) 
approved the following amendments to the Board of Supervisors' appointments 
list: the addition of Supervisor James to the following committees: Association 
of Bay Area Governments (ABAG) Executive Board as the alternate 
representative, the ABAG General Assembly as the alternate representative, 
California State Association of Counties (CSAC) Board of Directors as the 
alternate representative, Napa/Solano Area Agency on Aging Oversight Board 
as the alternate representative, Northern California Counties Tribal Matters 
Consortium as the primary representative, Yolo-Solano Air Quality 
Management District as the alternate representative, Child Abuse Prevention 
Council as the primary representative, Community Action Partnership (CAP) 
Solano JPA Board as the alternate representative, Juvenile Justice 
Coordinating Council as the primary representative, the Solano Economic 
Development Corporation as the alternate representative, and Vallejo Flood 
and Wastewater District as the primary representative; the addition of 
Supervisor Brown to the following committees: Bay Area Air Quality 
Page 8
Solano County

January 7, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Management District as the primary representative and First 5 Solano Children 
and Families Commission as the primary representative; the addition of 
Supervisor Williams to the following committees: CSAC as the primary 
representative, Rural County Representatives of California as the primary 
representative, Environmental Services Joint Powers Authority as the primary 
representative, Golden State Finance Authority as the primary representative, 
Golden State Connect Authority as the primary representative, Solano 
Economic Development Corporation as the primary representative; and Solano 
Consolidated Oversight Board as the primary representative; and the addition 
of Supervisor Mashburn to the following committees: Northern California Tribal 
Matters Consortium as the primary representative, and Solano Consolidated 
Oversight Board as the alternate representative. All other appointments 
remained unchanged; 2) directed County Counsel to send letters to the Solano 
EDC and the Travis Consortium regarding potential Brown Act violations; and 
3) ordered the dissolution of the following standing committees: Legislative
Committee, Military and Veterans Affairs Committee, Committee for an
Inclusive Workforce, Solano 360 Implementation Committee/Solano Fair
Association, Land Use and Transportation Committee, Lakes Water System,
GWS, and Public Art Committee. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional items from the public. 
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor James thanked the residents of District 1 for the opportunity to
serve as the Supervisor for District 1, noting she is honored to serve on a
nonpartisan board and is committed to working on the initiatives that will
continue to move Solano County forward. Supervisor James further stated
she is committed to being strategic and intentional in building partnerships
within the County and the region. Supervisor James thanked Supervisor
Williams for helping her through the journey of becoming the District 1
Supervisor and commented on the historic moment of being one of six black
women to be at this level of government, and on the joy of her boys being
able to see reflective leadership within Solano County.
B) Supervisor Williams welcomed Supervisor James to the Board and stated
she is looking forward to the collaboration that will happen between the Board
Members. Supervisor Williams acknowledged Former Supervisor Ruth
Forney, the first appointed black woman to the Solano County Board of
Supervisors and commented on the h

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed Public Hearing to consider adoption of an ordinance for
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed Public Hearing to consider adoption of an ordinance for 
Zone Text Amendment No. ZT-24-02 to amend Chapter 28 of the Solano 
County Code to revise and update sections pertaining to interpretation of the 
chapter, 
minimum 
architectural 
standards 
for 
dwellings, 
Residential-Traditional 
Community 
District-4 (R-TC-D-4) 
development 
standards, and roadside stand regulations in unincorporated Solano County; 
the project is exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA)
pursuant to §15061(B)(3) of the CEQA Guidelines
A - Draft Ordinance (Clean)
B - Draft Ordinance (Redline)
C - Public Notice
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Planning Program Manager Allan Calder provided an overview of proposed 
amendments to Chapter 28, adding definitions for the words "shall, will, are 
to, should, and may". 
In response to comments from Supervisor Brown regarding the clarification 
of the definitions, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated by adding the 
definitions to the Zoning Code (Code), staff is providing more clarity on 
regulations already in place. 
County Surveyor Chris Ferrucci provided an overview of the first 
Page 5
Solano County

January 14, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
recommended amendment to Chapter 28 related to clarifying how aliquot 
parts of land relate to the minimum lot area requirements. 
Supervisor Williams commented on the complexity of the County's land use 
issues and recommended that the Board hold a workshop to provide 
education on zoning and other land use issues. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff will look at options to provide a 
land use workshop.
Mr. Calder provided an overview of the proposed second through fourth 
updates to Chapter 28 related to minimum roof pitch, the correction of a 
typographical error in Table 28.32C, and updates to Article II of Section 
28.01 related to farm stands. 
In response to questions from Supervisor Williams related to alcohol sales at 
farm stands, Mr. Calder stated the sale of alcohol at a farm stand is 
prohibited, noting the current language prohibits the sale of winery products 
and the recommended language expands the rule to all alcohol, to remove 
any ambiguity for the public. 
Chair Mashburn commented on concerns related to the recommended 
percentages, noting that Solano County is part of an agricultural region and it 
might behoove the County to allow products to be sold at the farm stands 
from other counties within the agricultural region. Chair Mashburn further 
stated the limitations may reduce the ability of farm stand operators to earn 
an income, as there are times when stock is not being grown on the property 
for all farming operations. Chair Mashburn voiced concerns over the ability of 
Code Enforcement to enforce the recommended percentages. 
Deputy County Counsel Holly Tokar stated the recommendation from the 
Planning Commission was to allow for a 50/50 split between agricultural 
products grown within the County and those grown with the agricultural 
region.
Mr. Calder stated the department will be asking for a Farmbudsman position, 
noting the position would be a single point of contact which could be 
important for Resource Management and the agricultural community.
A lengthy discussion period was held. 
In response to comments from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the limitations 
listing out products puts on growers, Mr. Calder stated while the code does 
list certain products it also states "products including but not limited to" which 
provides interpretation for other products to be sold.
Supervisor Vasquez recommended adding the language "products that can 
legally be grown in the State of California".
Page 6
Solano County

January 14, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Williams commented on the need for clarification on 
requirements for the various regions, noting that the goal for the Suisun 
Valley is that a specific percentage of wine must be sold from within the 
region. Supervisor Williams recommended additional language regarding 
particular regions. 
A discussion period was held. 
Supervisor Vasquez recommended creating the position of an Economic 
Ombudsman which would follow specific projects and identify if the project 
meets the Board's priorities. 
Chair Mashburn requested staff research if the County has the ability to use 
regulation to create exclusivity in the sale of alcoholic products, given that 
the licensure for the sales and dispensation of alcohol are state regulated. 
Chair Mashburn further questioned if the County can tell growers what 
alcohol they can serve.
In response to Chair Mashburn's comments, Ms. Curry stated the County's 
authority is to adopt zoning regulations, and through zoning regulations, the 
Board can control the type and location of the sale of alcohol. 
In response to the proposed amendment to Section 28.01, Article II of 
Chapter 28, Chair Mashburn stated it should state "an agricultural product 
from the region" and should not be limited to 50%.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need to remove the wording "within 
Solano County, Owned or leased", noting that some property owners own 
land in multiple counties, and this limits their ability to sell a product that they 
grow in other areas of the region. 
In response to the comments, Mr. Bezek stated staff received feedback from 
the agricultural community before putting together the zoning code 
amendment, and the agricultural community indicated they wanted 
exclusivity to both the regions and the County.
A discussion period was held. 
In response to the discussion, Ms. Curry stated the Board can adopt the 
ordinance today, which will allow staff time to work with farm stand owners 
and the agricultural community to see if the distinction between in-county 
and out-of-county and/or the percentages have an actual impact. Ms. Curry 
further stated the intent of this legislation is to ensu

A - FJC - Solano Strategic Planning Report
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Tami Lukens introduced the item and 
provided a brief history of the creation of the Family Justice Center as it is 
today.
Executive Director Susun Kim provided an overview of the goals of the 
Family Justice Center and the vision for the future of the center. 
Regional Director of Client Services Reina Sandoval-Beverly provided an 
overview of programs offered at the center which includes telehealth, mental 
health, and legal services as well as supervised visitation and exchange 
programs. Ms. Sandoval-Beverly further provided information on two 
children's programs being offered by the center which are Camp Family 
Justice and the Sky Program.
County Administrator Bill Emlen thanked the Family Justice Center staff and 
Ms. Lukens for their hard work to bring the center to where it is today.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the changes that have been instituted in 
the Family Justice Center, and thanking the Justice Center staff for their 
hard work. 
Received

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation and conduct a public hearing on the necessity for
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation and conduct a public hearing on the necessity for 
acquiring 
right-of-way 
from 
APN 
0107-020-040 for 
the 
Stevenson 
Bridge 
Rehabilitation Project; and Consider adopting a Resolution of Necessity to 
acquire by eminent domain a portion of APN 0107-020-040 for construction 
and right-of-way purposes for the Stevenson Bridge Rehabilitation Project 
(4/5 vote required)
A - Resolution
B - Location Map
C - ROW - Exhibit A
D - Notices of Intent Letters
Attachments:
Engineering Manager Matt Tuggle introduced the item and provided an 
overview of the Stevenson Bridge Rehabilitation project. Mr. Tuggle further 
provided an overview of the issues related to obtaining right of way access 
from all property owners, noting while the County has been able to reach 
agreement with the owners of properties APN 037-17-10 and 038-16-14, 
they have been unable to come to agreement with the owners of the third 
property APN 0107-020-040.
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the 
public to address the Board on this matter and the following comments were 
received:
A) Rich Marovich commented in support of the Stevenson Bridge
Rehabilitation project, and recommended planting additional vegetation in
the uneconomic remnant piece that will be a result of the project to act as a
natural barrier against those who dump garbage in the area.
B) Property owner for APN 0107-020-040 Ed Borchard commented in
Page 13
Solano County

January 14, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
opposition to the project as it is recommended and recommended the 
building of a new bridge in its place. 
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the project and the 
recommended action noting this is an off-system bridge and the County was 
very lucky to obtain funding to complete the rehabilitation. Supervisor 
Vasquez further stated this bridge is critical because it is the only spot 
between Highway 5 and Pedrick Road for agricultural vehicles to cross. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board: 
1) found the public interest and necessity require the project; 2) the project is
planned or located in the manner that will be most compatible with the greatest
public good and the least private injury; 3) the property sought to be acquired
is necessary for the project; 4) that the offer required by section 7267.2 of the
Government Code has been made to the owner or owners of record; and 5)
adopted Resolution No. 2025-10, a Resolution of Necessity to acquire by
eminent domain a portion of APN 0107-020-040 for construction and
right-of-way purposes for the Stevenson Bridge Rehabilitation Project (4/5 vote
required). So ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-10
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 2:39 
P.M. Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be
January 28, 2025 at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street,
Fairfield, California.
________________________________

Solano County Board of Supervisors

In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding a request for

chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider adopting a resolution to approve 
Lot Line Adjustment application LLA-24-03 by Corey and Monica Williams and 
the Robby and Jessica Harris Family Trust to transfer two separate 24,950 sf 
portions of property between two adjacent lots; and rescind and replace Land 
Conservation contract No. 946, located along Mix Canyon Road, 4.5 miles 
northwest of the City of Vacaville, within the Watershed and Conservation “W” 
zoning district, APN’s 0102-120-010 and 0102-170-010; the project is exempt 
from the California Environmental Quality Act pursuant to CEQA Guidelines 
§15268 and §15317 relating to ministerial projects and the establishment of 
land conservation contracts
A - Resolution LLA-24-03 (Williams and Harris)
B - Lot Line Adjustment Maps
C - Land Conservation Contract 946 Ownership Map
D - Land Conservation Contract 946
E - Land Conservation Contract No. 1388
Minute Order
Adopted Resolution
PowerPoint Presentation
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Senior Planner Eric Wilberg provided an overview of a request to approve Lot Line 
Adjustment application LLA-24-03.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding if the properties will 
stay in the Williamson Act if this item is approved, Mr. Wilberg stated approval of 
the agreement does not remove the properties from the Williamson Act. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing inviting members of the public to
address the Board on this item. Hearing no comments, Chair Mashburn closed
the public hearing. 
Page 6
Solano County

Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2025-17, approving Lot Line Adjustment Application 
LLA-24-03, rescinding Land Conservation Contract No. 946, and approving 
replacement Land Conservation Contract No. 1388. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
