chunks.item_title: Conduct a workshop to receive an informational update on County-owned
chunks.text:
Conduct a workshop to receive an informational update on County-owned 
building assets, including an overview of locations, facility portfolio value and 
condition, annual capital facility improvement plan development, and potential 
significant capital improvement projects; and Consider providing direction to 
the General Services Department on upcoming capital projects and the 
development of the Capital Facilities Improvement Plan
Minute Order
PowerPoint Presentation
Attachments:
Director of General Services Megan Greve introduced the item.
Capitol Project Manager Mark Hummel provided an overview of the Capital 
Projects Management Division. 
Senior Management Analyst Jorjet Potier provided an overview of County 
building inventory. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if there are plans to 
address the aging Vallejo court holding facility, Mr. Hummel stated a study 
was conducted for an expansion of the facility; however, due to costs, the 
County did not move forward with the project. Mr. Hummel further stated there 
is not a current proposal in the Capital Facilities Improvement Plan for 
improvements to the facility. 
Chair Mashburn commented in favor of requesting the State of California 
(State) help to fund improvements for the facility.
Mr. Hummel provided an overview of prior planning efforts for the various 
County owned campuses. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding what the 
County intends to do with the animal care facility, County Administrator Bill 
Emlen stated he is aware that the Sheriff has had conversations with the 
cities regarding animal control, noting that some cities have inquired about the 
provision of additional services. Mr. Emlen further stated there is no request 
from the cities to pull animal control services back. 
In 
response 
to 
Mr. 
Emlen’s 
comments, 
Supervisor 
Vasquez 
stated 
a 
conversation needs to be had with the cities regarding potentially setting up a 
joint powers agreement to address animal control. 
Chair 
Mashburn 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
Supervisor 
Vasquez’s 
recommendation. 
Page 7
Solano County

January 28, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if the County still 
has plans to partner with the State on the plan to expand the current Office of 
Emergency 
Services/Dispatch 
building, 
Assistant 
County 
Administrator 
Ian 
Goldberg stated in terms of State coordination, he is uncertain, as staff has 
not had a conversation with the State regarding this project in some time. Mr. 
Goldberg further stated the plan is still a possibility and staff continues to work 
General Services on this issue. 
Mr. Goldberg further stated there are 
concerns regarding funding, noting once staff has completed the research 
they will bring the item back to the Board. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need for parking structures at various 
campuses.
Mr. Hummel and Ms. Potier provided an overview of the facilities condition 
assessment. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding concerns over 
water damage in the County’s CAC parking structure, Mr. Hummel stated 
staff has looked at the drainage issues, noting structurally the parking facility 
is not compromised; however, staff will take a look and circle back with the 
Board regarding any potential issues. 
Ms. Greve stated going forward General Services will be creating a plan to 
address the needs of all County owned parking areas. 
In response to a question from Supervisor James regarding if seismic retrofit 
is within the index for buildings and parking lots, Ms. Potier stated it does 
include seismic retrofitting. 
Chair Mashburn made comments regarding the need to keep up with 
maintenance, noting that deferred maintenance will in the end cost the County 
significantly more than doing the maintenance when it is needed. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Chair Mashburn’s comments 
noting it is her preference not to defer maintenance. 
A discussion period was held. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding where funding 
comes from for facilities improvements, Mr. Goldberg stated the amount of 
funding the County has is insufficient for the needs of the County, noting it is a 
constant battle during budget to decide which building repairs are completed. 
Mr. Goldberg provided an overview of the available capital facilities funds the 
County has, noting when possible staff continues to apply for grants. 
A discussion period was held regarding public facility fees. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need to review the public facility fees.
Page 8
Solano County

January 28, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Ms. Greve provided an overview of the development of the Annual 5-Year 
Capital Facilities Improvement Plan and an overview of the County’s funding 
sources. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding if a change in 
mandates from the federal government or the State will allow the use of the 
Public Facilities Fees, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated unfortunately, 
the County is unable to use the Public Facilities Fees to pay for programs, 
even if they are mandated and result in an increase in the need for County 
services, noting the increase is not attributable to the impact of that County 
building. Ms. Curry further stated the Public Facilities Fee is collected from 
new construction and the fee is based on the potential impacts of those new 
individuals living in the County.
A discussion period was held. 
Mr. Hummel provided an overview of in-process, upcoming and completed 
facilities projects.
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding the hazmat 
remediation project for 701 Texas Street, Mr. Hummel stated the bulk of the 
expenditures have been expended. Ms. Greve further stated once this part of 
the project has been finalized at the State level, staff will return to the Board 
and reques

1.
CONFERENCE WITH LEGAL COUNSEL - ANTICIPATED LITIGATION
(Pursuant to Government Code § 54956.9(d)(4)) - Initiation of litigation: one 
case
2.
PUBLIC 
EMPLOYEE 
PERFORMANCE 
EVALUATION 
(Pursuant 
to 
Government Code § 54957) Title: County Administrator
RECONVENE
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors reconvened at 
12:56 P.M. Chair Mashburn presided.
REPORT OF ACTION IN CLOSED SESSION (IF APPLICABLE)
Chair Mashburn stated on a 5-0 vote, the Board authorized County Counsel 
to initiate litigation with Contra Costa, San Joaquin and Yolo Counties in the 
validation action entitled “California Department of Water Resources v. All 
Persons Interested (Delta Conveyance Program Revenue Bonds), Sac. Sup. 
Ct. Case No. 25CV000704".
Page 12
Solano County

January 28, 2025
Board of Supervisors

February 4, 2025 at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, Fairfield,
California.

ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred 
to staff.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent 
Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

Salinas as the February 2025 "Employee of the Month"
Accepted
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on 
matters not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of 
the Board. The following comments were received:
A) Steve Olry announced the passing of George Guynn, Jr.
Page 1
Solano County

February 4, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
B) Director of Resource Management James Bezek provided an update on
current road conditions in Solano County.
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if there are 
sandbags available to the public, Mr. Bezek stated there are bags available. 
Chair Mashburn requested staff make the public aware of where they are able 
to obtain the sandbags.
County Administrator Bill Emlen commented on the impacts of the current 
weather system and the County's water supply.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the refinery fire in 
Martinez, CA, Mr. Bezek stated the fire is under control and the fire crews 
from Solano County were part of the response; however, there were no 
impacts to Solano County as far as they aware. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding potential 
flooding, Mr. Bezek noted that there are areas of isolated flooding at the sides 
of roads, noting there are no areas where flooding has breached the roads. 
Mr. Bezek further noted County road crews are monitoring the situation. 
Mr. Emlen alerted the Board that there are issues with the audio on the live 
stream. 
Chair Mashburn stated the Board will continue with the meeting, as a live 
stream is a benefit to the citizens; however, it is not a requirement for the 
Board to have a live stream to be able to continue the meeting. 
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of 
Supervisors' agenda for February 4, 2025.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Brown, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the Board 
approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for February 
4, 2025, as submitted. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items 
listed on the Consent Calendar. There was no public comment.
Supervisor Williams commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 6, 
recognizing the retirement of Correctional Officer Kelly Scarborough and 
offering her congratulations. Chair Mashburn commented on Ms. 
Scarborough's retirement offering his congratulations as well.
Chair Mashburn commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 5, recognizing 
the retirement of Deputy Public Defender Jeannette Garcia and offering his 
Page 2
Solano County

February 4, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
congratulations. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 2 requesting 
staff make a presentation on the Solano Emergency Medical Services 
Cooperative. Chair Mashburn commented in support of Supervisor Vasquez's 
request.
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated he is in agreement and staff will bring 
back a presentation.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
approved the following Consent Calendar items by 5-0 vote:

chunks.item_title: Consider acknowledging the notice of retirement from the Office of Solano
chunks.text:
Consider acknowledging the notice of retirement from the Office of Solano 
County Auditor-Controller by Acting Auditor-Controller Sheila Turgo effective 
February 28, 2025: and Consider appointing Chief Deputy Auditor-Controller 
Page 4
Solano County

February 4, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Janine Harris to fill the unexpired term of Auditor-Controller
A - Letter of Recommendation - Taynton
B - Sheila Turgo Retirement Letter
Attachments:
County Administrator Bill Emlen introduced the item.
Assistant County Administrator Ian Goldberg provided a brief overview of the 
process for filling the vacant position that will result with the retirement of Ms. 
Turgo and provided an overview of the recommended action to appoint Chief 
Deputy Auditor-Controller Janine Harris to the position of Auditor-Controller. 
Chair Mashburn thanked Ms. Harris for being willing to step into the role of 
Auditor-Controller, noting that this position is the watchdog for the County's 
citizens to ensure tax dollars are being spent appropriately.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
acknowledged the notice of retirement from the Office of Solano County 
Auditor-Controller by Acting Auditor-Controller Sheila Turgo effective February 
28, 2025. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
On motion of Chair Mashburn, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
appointed Chief Deputy Auditor-Controller Janine Harris to fill the unexpired 
term of Auditor Controller. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor James thanked the Sheriff's Department for their statements
that were released on Friday, January 31, 2025, regarding their continued
commitment to the safety of Solano County's citizens and ensuring that all
residents regardless of immigration status feel safe living in Solano County.
Ms. James further commented on the City of Vallejo Town Hall meeting
regarding public safety and stated she attended a mini-symposium on human
trafficking in Solano County. Supervisor James further commented on AB
303 noting she has started conversations with both Assemblywoman Lori
Wilson and Senator Christopher Cabaldo regarding AB 303.
B) Supervisor Vasquez commented on AB 303 noting the Board did receive
an email from the lobbyist outlining the process. Supervisor Vasquez further
stated while the Board is supportive of the concept of this bill, the citizens
need to be aware that as the legislation moves through the system there will
be many changes due to pressure to maintain the status quo. Supervisor
Vasquez noted the Board will need to wait and see if the Board can support
the final legislation. Supervisor Vasquez thanked Supervisor James for
reaching out to the County's State legislators and commented on the need for
the community to have a say on where battery storage facilities are located.
C) Supervisor Brown requested staff provide a presentation on battery
storage facilities to enable the Board make a decision on what they would like
to see in the legislation and provide a united front in the form of a letter to the
Page 5
Solano County

February 4, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
State legislators. 
D) Supervisor Williams commented on AB 303, noting RCRC supports the
legislation and will be meeting soon to discuss it further. Supervisor Williams
requested the County's lobbyist make a presentation to the Board regarding
AB 303. Supervisor Williams commented on the passing of George Guynn,
Jr.
E) Chair Mashburn commented on the passing George Guynn, Jr.
10

chunks.item_title: Adopt a resolution and plaque of appreciation recognizing Jeannette Garcia,
chunks.text:
Adopt a resolution and plaque of appreciation recognizing Jeannette Garcia, 
Deputy Public Defender, upon her retirement from Solano County Public 
Defender’s Office with over 26 years of dedicated public service to Solano 
County
A - Retirement Resolution
Attachments:
Chair Mashburn stated there was a retirement listed on the Consent Calendar 
and Ms. Garcia did not have a chance to submit her comments. Chair 
Mashburn requested that Board allow this item to be a presentation added as 
Item No. 10 and allow Ms. Garcia time to speak. 
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the Board has already voted and 
approved the adoption of the resolution and plaque of appreciation; therefore, 
the Board does not need to make another motion. Ms. Curry further stated 
she does recommend making the presentation an official item on the agenda 
as Item 10.
Ms. Garcia thanked the Board for taking time to recognize her retirement and 
commented on multiple issues she experienced during her employment with 
the County. 
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-18
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 9:51 
A.M. Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be
February 25, 2025, at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street,
Fairfield, California.

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation from the Workforce Development Board of Solano
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation from the Workforce Development Board of Solano 
County on the Draft Solano Local and North Bay Regional Workforce Plans; 
Conduct a public hearing on the Local and Regional Plans; and Officially open 
the 30-day public comment period
A - Draft North Bay Regional Workforce Plan
B - Draft Solano Local Workforce Plan
C - Presentation
Attachments:
President/Executive Director of the Workforce Development Board of Solano 
County Heather Henry provided an overview of the draft Solano Local and 
North Bay Regional Workforce Plans.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if there were 
other cities in addition to the City of Vacaville that participated in the 
Stakeholder Engagement meetings, Ms. Henry stated only the City of 
Vacaville attended the meetings, noting that her agency did speak with all of 
the economic development departments for the cities; however, the 
Stakeholder meeting were for very specific topics.
Supervisor Brown commented on the need for a four year degree program for 
nursing to be brought to Solano Community College.
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public 
to address the Board on this matter and the following comments were 
received:
A) Joseph Joyce commented on the need for employment services for
members of the public who are Senior Citizens.
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.
Received
28

chunks.item_title: Conduct a public hearing required by the Tax and Equity Fiscal Responsibility
chunks.text:
Conduct a public hearing required by the Tax and Equity Fiscal Responsibility 
Act of 1982 (TEFRA) and consider adopting a resolution approving the 
issuance of revenue bonds by the California Municipal Finance Authority 
(CMFA), in an amount not to exceed $42,000,000 for the purpose of financing 
and/or refinancing certain costs of the acquisition, construction, expansion, 
remodeling, 
renovation, 
furnishing, 
equipping 
and/or 
improvement 
of 
the 
health facilities, including real estate, owned and operated by NorthBay Group 
and/or NorthBay Corporation, located within Solano County
A - Resolution
B - Public Notice
Attachments:
Treasurer/Tax-Collector/County Clerk Charles Lomeli provided an overview of 
a request from Northbay Health for the issuance of revenue bonds by the 
California Municipal Finance Authority.
Page 8
Solano County

February 25, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding what the funding 
will be used for, Chief Financial Officer for Northbay Health Joe D'Angina 
provided an overview of the planned projects that will be paid for with the 
funding. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding if Northbay Health 
is financially stabilized, Mr. D'Angina stated Northbay Health is in a better 
place than they were in 2020/2021, noting there are contingencies in place 
should there be issues in the future and Northbay Health is unable to develop 
the property. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if Northbay Health 
had already purchased the property, making this a refinance, Mr. D'Angina 
stated the property was purchased earlier this year with the plan to refinance 
it with the funds raised by the bond sales.
Chair Mashburn stated Northbay Health is a nonprofit entity, noting he wanted 
to make it clear to the members of the public that should there become a 
need to sell the properties in question, any dollars above and beyond the 
actual cost goes back into the nonprofit and does not benefit the shareholders 
in any way.
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments 
from the public.
On motion of Supervisor Brown, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2025-28 approving the issuance of revenue bonds by 
the California Municipal Finance Authority (CMFA), in an amount not to exceed 
$42,000,000 for the purpose of financing and/or refinancing certain costs of the 
acquisition, construction, expansion, remodeling, renovation, furnishing, 
equipping and/or improvement of the health facilities, including real estate, 
owned and operated by NorthBay Group and/or NorthBay Corporation, located 
within Solano County. So ordered by a 4-0 vote with Supervisor Williams 
absent. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-28
29

chunks.item_title: Conduct a public hearing to review and consider adopting the updated Solano
chunks.text:
Conduct a public hearing to review and consider adopting the updated Solano 
County 5-Year Capital Facilities Improvement Plan for Fiscal Years 2024/25 
through 2028/29
A - CFIP Links FY2024-25_FY2028-29
B - FY2025-26 New CFIP Projects
C - FY2025-26 CFIP Project Status
Attachments:
Director of General Services Megan Greve introduced the item and provided 
an overview of the Capital Facilities Improvement Plan (CFIP) process.
Senior Management Analyst Jorjet Potier provided an overview of the online 
version of the CFIP.
Capital Projects Manager Mark Hummel provided an overview of completed 
Page 9
Solano County

February 25, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
projects and upcoming projects for FY2025/26.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding how to annex the 
area at the entrance of Hiddenbrook, which is currently in Napa County, 
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated this is an issue that would have to be 
dealt with through the State of California LAFCO, noting it is an unusual 
configuration and the County is aware of the issue. 
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments 
from the public. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
adopted the updated Solano County 5-Year Capital Facilities Improvement 
Plan for Fiscal Years (FY) 2024/25 through 2028/29. So ordered by a 4-0 vote 
with Supervisor Williams absent.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional items from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor James noted she has been assigned to the CSAC Child Care
Working Group and provided a brief overview of the various committees and
meetings she has attended over the last few weeks.
B) Supervisor Brown provided the Marin Clean Energy 2024 Impact Report.

Lot Line Adjustment application LLA-23-01 by Solano County Farmlands and 
Open Space Foundation (Solano Land Trust) and Ralph Lewis Azevedo and 
Shirley Ann Azevedo Revocable Trust et. al. to transfer 7.45 acres of land 
between two adjacent lots; Rescind Land Conservation contract Nos. 559, 
1014, a portion of 1078, and 1292; Approve replacement Land Conservation 
contract Nos. 1383, 1384, 1389, and 1390, located along Lynch Road, three 
miles northeast of the City of Vallejo, within the Exclusive Agriculture “A-20” 
zoning district, APN’s 0180-030-050 and 0180-040-040; the project is exempt 
from the California Environmental Quality Act pursuant to CEQA Guidelines 
§15268 and §15317 relating to ministerial projects and the establishment of 
land conservation contracts

provided an overview of a request to approve Lot Line Adjustment application

address the Board on this item. Hearing no comments, Chair Mashburn

On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board:

chunks.item_title: Receive the FY2024/25 Midyear Financial Report and consider taking action
chunks.text:
Receive the FY2024/25 Midyear Financial Report and consider taking action 
on the recommendations contained in the Report
A - Financial Variance Report FY2024/25
B - FY2024/25 MY Projections - General Fund
C - FY2024/25 MY Projections - Other Funds
D - FY2024/25 Midyear Projection - ISF & Enterprise
E - General Fund Year End Fund Balance Projection
F - FY2024/25 Midyear Appropriation Transfer Requests
G - Position Resolution
H - FY2025/26 Budget Preparation Assumptions
I - State and Federal Budget Update
Attachments:
County Administrator Bill Emlen introduced the item.
Budget Officer Emily Combs provided an overview of the Fiscal Year 2024/25 
Midyear Financial Report. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding what funding 
makes up the General Fund, Ms. Combs stated the funds come from the 
redevelopment 
agency 
and 
sales 
and 
property 
tax 
revenues. 
Assistant 
County Administrator Ian Goldberg stated the General Fund is the general 
county operating fund, noting it includes the revenues and expenditures for 
the general operating departments and houses the few flexible funds that the 
Board has discretion over. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding if the county was 
functioning on a structural deficit, Mr. Goldberg stated the county does 
operate at a deficit because the revenues generated do not match the 
expenditures on an annual basis. Mr. Goldberg further stated the carried-over 
fund balance in combination with reserves is what provides the ability for the 
county to adopt a balanced budget each year. Mr. Goldberg further stated this 
is the reason the county has a policy that it will not backfill for state and 
federal losses in funding. 
In response to Mr. Goldberg’s comments, Supervisor Brown stated it is 
incumbent on the county to look for ways to increase revenues. Supervisor 
Brown requested staff begin adding information to the Board’s staff reports 
that indicates which of the 5 strategic plans the item addresses. 
In response to Supervisor Brown’s comments, Mr. Emlen stated that as the 
Page 5
Solano County

March 11, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
county begins looking at the upcoming general plan update, discussions will 
be held regarding how land use translates to economic opportunities for the 
county. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Supervisor Brown’s comments 
and requested staff keep the Board aware of any possible upcoming federal 
cuts to HUD vouchers or Medicaid.
Chair Mashburn thanked Mr. Goldberg for stating the county has a policy that 
it will not backfill a loss of funding from the state or federal government and 
requested staff return to the Board with a list of potential vulnerable services 
should state or federal funding be reduced. 
Mr. Goldberg stated that staff will return to the Board with a discussion on this 
topic.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need for the county to be vigilant in 
their spending, noting that county services are the safety net for the citizens . 
Supervisor Vasquez thanked county staff for their hard work. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Chair Mashburn’s request. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the 
Board: 1) approved Appropriation Transfer Requests recognizing revenues and 
transfers in various departments, and approved adjustments to existing 
appropriations in various departments; 2) adopted Resolution No. 2025-42, 
amending the List of Numbers and Classifications of Positions within Solano 
County for a net increase of 1.0 positions; 3) approved fixed asset purchases in 
the amount of $1,586,500 for the Library, $1,275,586 for Probation, $75,500 for 
the Sheriff, $1,000 in the Sheriff Boating Safety Enforcement and Equipment 
(BSEE) Grant Fund, $30,000 for Health and Social Services (H&SS), and 
$178,000 for Fleet Management; 4) affirmed initial budget assumptions for 
FY2025/26; and 5) confirmed the FY2025/26 Budget Hearing dates from Monday 
June 23, 2025 through Tuesday June 24, 2025. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-42
11

chunks.item_title: Consider adopting updated General Fund General Reserve and Contingency
chunks.text:
Consider adopting updated General Fund General Reserve and Contingency 
Policies 
A - General Fund General Reserve and Contingency Policies
Attachments:
Assistant County Administrator Ian Goldberg introduced the item and provided 
an overview of the request to adopt an updated General Fund General 
Reserve and Contingency policy.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding current credit 
rating, Mr. Goldberg stated the county is AAA rated which is a direct result of 
the Board’s policies.
Page 6
Solano County

March 11, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the recommended action.
Chair Mashburn commented on the need for everyone to remember that the 
county’s reserves are in place to ensure the county can keep basic services 
running in times of severe economic distress. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding how the County 
will meet the revenue targets, Mr. Goldberg stated staff will be discussing this 
during every budget discussion going forward. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the difference 
between reserves and contingencies, Mr. Goldberg stated that reserves are 
funds that are only able to be accessed during the budget process, whereas 
the ability to utilize contingencies is more flexible and can be accessed at any 
time during the year. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
On motion of Supervisor James, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the Board 
adopted the updated General Fund General Reserve and Contingency Policies. 
So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
12

chunks.item_title: Consider adopting resolutions appointing the Board of Supervisors as the
chunks.text:
Consider adopting resolutions appointing the Board of Supervisors as the 
Board of Directors for the Suisun Fire Protection District, the Montezuma Fire 
Protection District, and the Vacaville Fire Protection District
A - Resolution appointing BOS as SFPD Board
B - Resolution appointing BOS as MFPD Board
C - Resolution appointing BOS as VFPD Board
Attachments:
Senior Management Analyst Nancy Nelson provided a brief history of past 
recommendations for consolidation of the various fire protection districts, and 
the recommendation to appoint the Board of Supervisors as the Board of 
Directors for the Suisun, Montezuma, and Vacaville Fire Protection Districts. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Chris Calvert, representing the Vacaville Fire Protection District Board of
Directors, commented in support of the recommended action to consolidate
the fire districts.
B)
Christine Reiter commented in support of the recommended action to
consolidate 
the 
fire 
district 
but 
voiced 
concerns 
over 
both 
Vacaville’s 
representation once the districts have been consolidated and the distribution
of services.
C)
Revalee Hemken commented in opposition to the consolidation of the
Vacaville Fire Protection District.
Page 7
Solano County

March 11, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
D)
David Stevens commented in support of the recommended action to
consolidate the fire protection districts.
E)
Gaul Culley commented in opposition to the recommended action to
consolidate the fire protection districts.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the recommended action and 
recommended the Board consider the creation of an advisory committee to 
ensure the districts are represented. 
Chair Mashburn commented in support of the recommended action and 
thanked the members that have served on the fire protection district boards. 
Chair Mashburn further stated it is the Board’s intent to make fire services 
better. 
Supervisor 
Vasquez 
thanked 
former 
Supervisor 
Jim 
Spering 
and 
the 
firefighter 
volunteers. 
Supervisor 
Vasquez 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
the 
recommended action, noting it is time to unify the districts. 
On motion of Chair Mashburn, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board: 1) 
adopted Resolution 2025-43, appointing the Board of Supervisors as the Board 
of Directors for the Suisun Fire Protection District; 2) adopted Resolution 
2025-44, appointing the Board of Supervisors as the Board of Directors for the 
Montezuma Fire Protection District; and 3) adopted Resolution 2025-45, 
appointing the Board of Supervisors as the Board of Directors for the Vacaville 
Fire Protection District. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-43 through Resolution No. 2025-45
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional items from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A)
Supervisor 
James 
commented 
on 
her 
attendance 
at 
the 
NACO
Conference and her meetings with Solano County’s federal representatives.
Supervisor James thanked the Sheriff’s department for their inclusion in the
Know Your Rights campaign at an event put on by the Latino Parent Network.
Supervisor James highlighted events that will be taking place at the Solano
County Fairgrounds and at the City of Vallejo.
B) Supervisor Brown commented on concerns over the lack of a toll booth for
traffic from Marin County that is coming into Solano County and requested an
update from the Metropolitan Transportation Commission on the toll booth
projects.
Page 8
Solano County

March 11, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Draft
In response to Supervisor Brown’s comments, Chair Mashburn stated he will
work to have a presentation before the Board and also commented on plan to
potentially move the toll booth to the other side of the Highway 121 
interchange. 
C)
Supervisor 
Williams 
commented 
on 
her 
attendance 
at 
the 
NACO
conference. Supervisor Williams further stated that she had attended her first
RCRC meeting and provided an update on what was discussed at the
meeting. Supervisor Williams thanked Paragon staff and county staff for their
help at the NACO Conference. Supervisor Williams requested that this
meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors be adjourned in memory
of Robert Sanchez .
D)
Chair Mashburn stated Tuesday March 25, 2025 is the service for
George Guynn, Jr. and requested that this meeting of the Solano County
Board of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Michael Reinath, Linda
Gifford, and Nicole Rawley.

chunks.item_title: Approve an amendment to the County Administrator Employment Agreement
chunks.text:
Approve an amendment to the County Administrator Employment Agreement 
extending the term for one year through March 31, 2026
A - Contract Amendment
Attachments:
Supervisor Williams stated she removed this item for the Board to discuss an 
amendment to the recommended contract term from one year to six months 
and to recommend both the creation of a succession plan for the CAO's 
office and the creation of a 360 employee evaluation program for the county.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding how the 
creation of a succession plan and a 360 employee evaluation program relates 
to the County Administrator's employment contract, Supervisor Williams 
stated she would like these programs incorporated in the County 
Administrator's work plan with the approval of a new contract. 
In response to Supervisor Williams's comments, Supervisor Vasquez stated 
those items are Board direction and not part of the specific contract. 
Chair Mashburn stated with exception of the ability to amend the contract 
terms for length of contract, Supervisor Williams's recommendations should 
be a discussion and possible direction from the Board, but should not be a 
part of the approval of the CAO Contract. 
Supervisor Brown commented in support of the recommended length of the 
contract of one year. Supervisor Brown further stated she does not support 
Supervisor Williams's additional recommendations, noting the recommended 
policy changes should be discussed at a later date by providing direction to 
staff or during Closed Session.
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated the county is already in the process of 
a recruitment and he believes that the recruitment process will be complete 
by no later than mid-summer, noting there is language within the contract that 
indicates that he will retire upon the completion of the recruitment. Mr. Emlen 
further stated the intent of this contract is to provide a smooth transition in 
leadership. 
Supervisor James stated she understands Supervisor Williams's concerns 
and desire for the creation of a succession plan and a 360 evaluation 
program for the county; however, she believe they are addressing those 
concerns through the recruitment process. 
Page 6
Solano County

March 25, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Williams stated she is not opposed to Mr. Emlen's involvement in 
the recruitment process; however, she would like assurances that staff will 
return with a policy discussion regarding putting these policies in place for the 
county, noting all leadership should have a succession plan and all 
employees should have a 360 evaluation. 
Supervisor Vasquez stated he believes these policy discussions should be 
held after the hiring of the new County Administrator, noting the discussion 
should come back through the Human Resources department. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board 
approved an amendment to the County Administrator Employment Agreement 
extending the term for one year through March 31, 2026. So ordered by a 4-1 
vote with Supervisor Williams voting no.
5

chunks.item_title: Consider
chunks.text:
Consider 
approval 
of 
the 
CY2025 budget 
for 
the 
Solano 
County 
Fair 
Association
A - 2025 Proposed Budget
Attachments:
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Executive Director of the Solano County Fair Thomas Keaney provided an
overview of updates to the Solano County Fairgrounds and potential events
coming to the Solano County Fairgrounds.
B) Joseph Joyce commented on upcoming events at the Solano County
Fairgrounds.
Supervisor Williams stated she requested this item be removed from 
Consent Calendar to request the Solano County Fair Executive Director 
return with a presentation to the Board of Supervisors regarding both the 
short and long term plans for the fairgrounds. 
In response to Supervisor Williams request for information, Mr. Keaney stated 
due to the condition of the records when he started, he ran the fairgrounds 
with no functional financial reports, noting for FY2024/25, the Solano County 
Fair was in the negative by $750,000. Mr. Keaney further stated part of those 
funds were expended as a conscious decision of the Solano County Fair 
Board to provide the citizens with a proper 75th anniversary celebration and a 
once in a lifetime event. Mr. Keaney further stated the Solano County Fair will 
end this calendar year with a net positive of $125,000. Mr. Keaney further 
stated the majority of county fairs lose money; however, the overall operations 
will cover that loss. 
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
approved the CY2025 budget for the Solano County Fair Association. So 
ordered by a 5-0 vote.
17

chunks.item_title: Receive a verbal update from Paragon Government Relations, the County’s
chunks.text:
Receive a verbal update from Paragon Government Relations, the County’s 
federal Legislative Advocates and Karen Lange, the County’s State Legislative 
Advocate on legislative matters of interest to the County including AB 259, AB
303, AB 470, AB 518, AB 874, SB 16, SB 239, SB 346, SB 496, and SB 707 
and consider providing staff with direction
Principal Management Analyst Matthew Davis introduced the item. 
Federal legislative advocate Rachel Mackey provided an update on 
information on federal legislation of interest to the County.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding previously 
approved federal contracts for funding, Ms. Mackey stated the funding in 
question is part of the Commodity Credit Corporation which has been a target 
of the current administration, noting it has been stated there is a belief that the 
previous administration has gone outside of the bounds of the funding stream 
to provide support to food banks and schools. Ms. Mackey further stated there 
are lawmakers who are concerned about the cancellation of the program.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding Social Security 
funding, Ms. MacKey stated this issue is receiving a lot of attention due to 
there being impacts for constituents on both sides of the aisle, which may 
result in increased pressure on law makers. Ms. Mackey requested the Board 
members provide individual stories of those citizens that are impacted by the 
potential loss of Social Security funding. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the possibility 
Page 9
Solano County

March 25, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
of the creation of a bipartisan bill to strengthen the Farm Bill, Ms. Mackey 
stated while there has not been much movement on the Farm Bill, it has been 
expressed that it is a key priority for leadership on each side of the aisle. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need for representatives from Paragon to 
ensure the County's concerns are being provided not only to the 
representatives of Solano County, but also to those on the other side of the 
aisle, noting that to effect change the county needs to engage the 
representatives that are a part of the party that is in power.
In response to Chair Mashburn's comments, federal legislative advocate 
Hasan Sarsour stated during the week of Chair Mashburn's visit to 
Washington DC, Paragon has secured a meeting with the White House 
Intergovernmental Affairs office as well as targeting a few Republican offices.
State legislative advocate Karen Lange provided an update on information on 
state legislation of interest to the County.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding potential cuts 
to funding for In Home Support Services, Ms. Lange stated she has not seen 
information regarding cuts to funding; however, she has heard discussion 
regarding the possibility of the creation of a statewide bargaining plan, noting 
there would be issues because some counties market conditions require 
higher wages.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if the state is 
considering no longer allowing homes to be built in fire hazard severity zones, 
Ms. Lange stated at this time California's legislators have not been able to 
come to a consensus on how to move forward with policies related to building 
in fire hazard severity zones.
AB 259 (Rubio) - Open Meetings, Local Agencies, Teleconferences.
Mr. Davis provided an overview of the proposed legislation. 
By consensus, the Board approved a letter of support for AB 259 
(Rubio) - Open Meetings, Local Agencies, Teleconferences.
AB 303 (Addis) - Battery Energy Storage Facilities
Mr. Davis provided an overview of the proposed legislation. 
Chair Mashburn requested an addition to the letter of support for AB 303 to 
require an applicant to receive approval from either the Fire Chief or District 
Representatives as opposed to simply requiring a meeting. 
Supervisor Vasquez voiced concerns over the possibility of having staff sign 
an agreement without Board approval. 
Supervisor Brown voiced concerns over who would be responsible for costs 
Page 10
Solano County

March 25, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
associated with clean up of damages from a potential fire at a battery energy 
storage facility. 
Supervisor Williams inquired if there has been thought given to having Solano 
County Resource Management staff speak with the legislators regarding 
battery storage facilities given all the work they have already completed on it. 
Ms. Lange stated Director of Resource Management James Bezek has in the 
past spoken with the author of AB 303 regarding this issue; however, there 
has been no formal discussion regarding AB 303 because they did not yet 
have Board direction and AB 303 has not gone before a committee as of yet. 
Mr. Bezek provided a brief overview of his discussion with the Chief of Staff 
for Assemblymember Addis. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding Solano County 
being 
an 
asthma-prone 
areas 
and 
if 
the 
legislators 
are 
looking 
at 
environmental justice with regard to potential impacts to air quality from a 
battery storage fire, Ms. Lange stated she is uncertain if the California Energy 
Commission is required to take into consideration potential issues that have 
not yet happened, but she encourages the county to add those concerns to 
any letters written to the legislators regarding this issue. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if as part of the 
process there is a requirement to consult with the air districts, Mr. Emlen 
stated he believes they are required to consult with the air districts. Ms. Lange 
stated she will look into this further. 
By consensus, the Board approved a letter of support for AB 303 
(Addis) 
- 
Battery 
Energy 
Storage 
Facilities 
to 
include 
the 
above
concerns.
AB 470 (McKinnor) - Telephone Corporations, Carriers of Last Resort

chunks.item_title: The Department of Resource Management recommends that the Board of
chunks.text:
The Department of Resource Management recommends that the Board of 
Supervisors receive a presentation from staff to initiate discussion on the 
County’s General Plan and the need, scope, extent and timeline of a potential 
update
Page 14
Solano County

March 25, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
A - Key Considerations and Findings
B - General Plan Update Memo
Attachments:
County Administrator Bill Emlen provided opening statements regarding the 
overall General Plan Process.
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Principal Planner Matt Walsh provided an overview of the elements of a General 
Plan, a brief history of Solano County’s past General Plans, updates to the 
General Plan that have taken place since the last adoption in 2008, and an 
overview of the objectives for the next General Plan update. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding what “circulation” 
means, Mr. Walsh stated it is related to transportation. 
Principal Planner Allan Calder provided an overview of possible actions the Board 
will need to consider for the next General Plan update. 
Supervisor Vasquez made comments surrounding the county’s ability to create 
meaningful development and regarding a proposed county-wide General Plan, to 
be completed by holding stakeholder meetings with Solano County’s cities and 
other agencies that deal with development in Solano County. Supervisor Vasquez 
further recommended having LAFCO hold a 2-3 day summit meeting to discuss 
county-wide goals for development.
Supervisor 
Williams 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
Supervisor 
Vasquez’s 
recommendation for a summit meeting with the cities, noting she understands 
the complexity of how important this is. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Mary Aiu commented on the need for the county to consider extending
controls on leapfrog development to protect agriculture.
B)
Nate Huntington commented in support of keeping the Orderly Growth
Initiative (Measure T) as part of the General Plan and recommended the county
treat California Forever as a developer and not a community stakeholder.
C) Daniel Levin commented the need for the county to consider the needs of the
City of Vallejo during this General Plan process and commented on the need to
look at infield development in the cities.
D) Jim Bartz commented on the upcoming General Plan process.
E) Michael Hayes commented on the need to look at the stabilization of the
population in the General Plan.
Page 15
Solano County

March 25, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
F) Elaine Cloutier commented on the need for city governments to work with the
county on the General Plan and requested the Board keep in mind the masses.
G) Bob Berman commented on the desire of the Orderly Growth Committee for
the Board to place a extension of Measure T on the ballot.
H) Cliff Howard commented on the need for additional agencies to be involved in
the General Plan process including the Farm Bureau and the PG&E.
I) Duane Kromm commented on the need to extend Measure T and on the timing
of placing it back on the ballot.
Chair Mashburn commented on the LAFCO process in relation to annexations 
and municipal service reviews completed by LAFCO. Chair Mashburn further 
recommended staff and the Board review each section of the current General 
Plan to decipher if actual changes are needed. Chair Mashburn commented in 
support of Supervisor Vasquez’s recommended summit meeting with the cities 
and utility providers. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the need to look at the school districts, Solano 
Community College, Touro University, and Cal Poly Maritime, noting that without 
an educated workforce the economy won't succeed. Supervisor Brown further 
commented on the need to review fire hazard zones and on potential county 
growth. 
Supervisor James commented on California Forever and the Ships Act and how 
it will effect Solano County. Supervisor James further commented on potential 
population growth and the need to be mindful of migration trends out of the Bay 
Area. Supervisor James further commented on the need to keep equity in mind 
with regards to the City of Vallejo by incorporating Vallejo into the General Plan 
process and making it a transportation hub. Supervisor James commented in 
support of holding meetings off site in various parts of the county. Supervisor 
James recommended First Five be a part of the General Plan conversation. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Supervisor Brown's comments 
regarding including members of the education community to the General Plan 
discussions and recommended including the Yocha Dehe Wintun Nation. 
Supervisor Williams further recommended the creation of a Citizen’s Advisory 
Committee and in support of holding meetings off site and in the evenings. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the extension of Measure T and in 
support of including the cities in the General Plan process. Supervisor Williams 
commented on including members of areas of the county that have strategic 
plans already in place. 
Chair Mashburn recommended staff work to create a Request for Information and 
then a Request for Proposals to hire a consultant to drive the process for the 
General Plan, noting what the Board wants to do with the inclusion of the cities.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need for the first summit meeting to be 
Page 16
Solano County

March 25, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
policy 
makers 
including 
the 
Solano 
Irrigation 
District 
and 
the 
Solano 
Transportation Authority, noting it should be those entities that create policy 
regarding transportation and growth before inviting the other recommended 
entities. 
Received

There were no additional items from the public.

chunks.item_title: Conduct a public hearing to consider increasing a motor vehicle registration
chunks.text:
Conduct a public hearing to consider increasing a motor vehicle registration 
fee from $1 to $2 and a commercial vehicle registration fee from $2 to $4 
pursuant to California Vehicle Code §9250.19 as authorized by Assembly Bill 
2393 (2014) to exclusively fund the fingerprint identification program; and 
Adopt a resolution imposing the fees, effective October 1, 2025, to be 
distributed to the California identification fund administered by the Sheriff’s 
Office
A - Original Resolution 97-300
B - Resolution
C - Notice of Public Hearing
Attachments:
Director of Admin Services Lisa Donahue introduced the item provided an 
overview of the fingerprint identification program and the requested vehicle 
registration fee increases. 
Identification Bureau Supervisor Aryn Watts provided an overview of the Cal-Id 
program. 
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments from
the public. 
Chair Mashburn shared a story regarding how important the Cal-ID program is to 
the safety of the public. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board: 
1) approved an increase of motor vehicle registration fees from $1 to $2 and
commercial vehicle registration fees from $2 to $4 pursuant to California
Vehicle Code §9250.19 as authorized by Assembly Bill 2393 (2014) to
exclusively fund the fingerprint identification program; and 2) adopted
Page 6
Solano County

April 8, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Resolution No. 2025-66, imposing the fees, effective October 1, 2025, to be 
distributed to the California identification fund administered by the Sheriff’s 
Office. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-66
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional items from the public. 
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports on
meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Brown requested that this meeting of the Solano County Board of
Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Adolofo Alcala Manuel. Supervisor
Brown further commented on an upcoming item on the City of Vallejo City
Council Agenda, to adopt a resolution approving funding for a contract with the
Solano County Sheriff’s Department for the provision of public safety officers,
noting she would like to know when the Board of Supervisors will be discussing
this item.
In response to Supervisor Brown’s question, Assistant County Administrator Ian
Goldberg stated once the City Council moves through their discussion, staff will
work to bring the item back to the Board in open session. Mr. Goldberg further
stated the County has not entered into a contract with the City of Vallejo at this
time, they have simply had an initial discussion through the Sheriff’s office. Mr. 
Goldberg further stated once an additional discussion with the City of Vallejo
happens where they indicate if they are interested in pursing a contract staff will
bring the item back to the Board. 
Supervisor Brown asked if there will be discussions regarding monetary
compensation regarding the amount of staff time that has been used should the
City of Vallejo want to pursue a contract, noting the law expires in 2026.
B) Chair Mashburn stated he needs to clarify a few points for public and request
the Board's approval for staff to bring forward an agenda item. Chair Mashburn
further stated it was published in several newspapers that he had participated in a
committee set up by Solano County’s Assembly representative with regard to the
concept of ship yard build in Collinsville. Chair Mashburn further stated he is not
on a committee reviewing the project, nor has he participated in any of the
meetings, noting in his current role it would not be appropriate. Chair Mashburn
further stated he won’t be participating in any meeting until this issue comes
before the Board. Chair Mashburn requested staff provide a presentation on April
22, 2025, that covers specifically what is and is not allowed in the General Plan
with regard to Collinsville and the properties in that area that are designated as
potentially available for the maritime industry. Chair Mashburn further requested
staff provide as part of that presentation anything that has been submitted related
to the proposal/project to ensure the Board has more than rumor or conjecture as
Page 7
Solano County

April 8, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
to what is going to occur in that site, and are then able to speak to their support or
non support for a proposal of this type. Chair Mashburn further noted this will
provide members of the public with information and the ability to provide their
input as well. Chair Mashburn further stated for the public’s information he wants
to make two things clear, the first being that the current General Plan may allow
for projects similar to what is being dicussed, and the second being that there is
no other governmental agency that has the jurisdiction to approve a project in
that particular region of the County. 
There was consensus of the Board to bring this item back on April 22, 2025. 
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 11:07 A.M.
Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be April, 22, 2025 at
9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, Fairfield, California.
________________________________
MITCH H. MASHBURN, Chair
Solano County Board of Supervisors
BILL EMLEN, Clerk
Solano County Board of Supervisors
By ______________________________
Alicia Draves, Chief Deputy Clerk
Page 8
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn stated any members of the public who wish to speak on Agenda 
Item No. 44 will need to submit their public comment card during the 2 P.M. 
session and invited members of the public to address the Board on matters not 
listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. The 
following comments were received:
A) Michael Hayes made a request for LAFCO to begin video archiving its
meetings.
B) Joseph Joyce commented on Solano County’s contribution to the Solano
County Fair Association.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of 
Supervisors' agenda for April 22, 2025.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for April 22, 
2025. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Supervisor James and Chair Mashburn commented on Consent Calendar 19, 
congratulating Custody Sergeant Neil Wakabayashi on his retirement from 
Solano County.
Supervisor Brown requested Consent Calendar Item No. 8 be pulled for further 
discussion.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items 
listed on the Consent Calendar. There was no public comment.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
approved the following Consent Calendar items with Consent Calendar Item 
No. 8 removed for further discussion and by 5-0 vote:

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing on the proposed FY2025/26 user fee
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing on the proposed FY2025/26 user fee 
schedules; and Consider adopting 19 revised fee schedules by separate 
resolutions amending the exhibits in Chapters 
2.4 and 11 of the Solano 
County Code, revising and establishing various fees, to become effective July 
1, 2025
A - Summary of Proposed FY2025-26 Fee Changes by Departments
B - Fee Schedules and Resolutions
C - Copy of Public Notice
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Anne Putney introduced the item and provided an 
overview of the recommended updates to the county’s user fees.
Page 12
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding increased fees in 
Environmental Health, Administrative Services Manager Sarah Pappakostas 
stated she believes Supervisor Williams was speaking about the boring fees, 
which were increased by at least double, noting that the actual cost is closer to 
four times what the County was currently charging. 
Engineering Manager Mathew Tuggle stated that the State of California mandates 
permits for boring. Mr. Tuggle further stated there was an increase in several 
fees, where the actual cost to provide the service is considerably more than what 
the department has requested, noting that over the years, changes in laws have 
increased the costs associated with the services. 
Director of Resource Management James Bezek stated the department ran a 
comparison with surrounding jurisdictions, and the recommended cost is in line 
with other counties. 
Supervisor Williams requested in the future, staff provide more information 
regarding what the impacts of future increases will be. 
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments from
the public.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2025-80 through Resolution No. 2025-98 revising fee 
schedules and amending the exhibits in Chapters 2.4 and 11 of the Solano 
County Code, revising and establishing various fees, to become effective July 
1, 2025. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-80 through Resolution No. 2025-98

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed Public Hearing to consider adoption of an ordinance for
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed Public Hearing to consider adoption of an ordinance for 
Zone Text Amendment ZT-25-01 to amend Chapter 28 of the Solano County 
Code to revise and update sections pertaining to Office of County Surveyor 
review, 
private 
road 
maintenance 
agreements, 
agricultural 
accessory 
buildings and farm stands in unincorporated Solano County; the project is 
exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant to 
§15061(b)(3) of CEQA Guidelines
A - Draft Ordinance (Clean)
B - Draft Ordinance (Redline)
C - Public Notice
D - Draft Solano County Road Improvement Standards relating to Private Roa
E - Civil Code Section 845
F - Draft Farm Stand Permitting Guide
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Planning Program Manager Allan Calder provided an overview of the proposed 
amendments to Chapter 28 of the Solano County Code. 
County Surveyor Chris Ferrucci provided an overview of the recommendation to 
Page 13
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
remove the requirement of private road maintenance agreements, returning the 
code to the same as current state law. 
Mr. Bezek further provided information on the reason for the request to remove 
the requirement for road maintenance agreements, noting that many projects that 
would otherwise be acceptable have not moved forward due to the lack of a road 
maintenance agreement. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding road maintenance 
agreements, Mr. Bezek stated there is a secondary mechanism for citizens to 
deal with disagreements, noting this will take the civil matters out of the hands of 
county staff. 
Supervisor Vasquez thanked staff for their efforts to clean up the code. 
Mr. Calder provided an overview of the changes to sections V through X of the 
proposed ordinance related to farm stands. 
A discussion period was held regarding the percentage rates of products sold at 
farm stands that must be grown or produced in Solano County.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of a consistent percentage of 25% 
throughout the county for the percentage requirement of goods grown or 
produced in Solano County to be sold at farm stands, noting she has concerns 
with fairness. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public to
address the Board on this matter and the following comments were received:
A)
Lisa Howard speaking on behalf of the Suisun Vintners and Growers
Association as well as Larry Balestra of Larry’s Produce, noting Mr. Balestra is
happy with the current requirement for locally grown and produced products of
25% for farm stands in his region. Ms. Howard further requested that the Board
consider removing the statement “does not apply” to the larger farm stands. Ms. 
Howard further requested that the Board consider language that includes
“produced onsite, offsite on land within Solano County, or in direct partnership,” 
noting this provides flexibility but will still ensure at least 25% of the product sold
is grown in Solano County.
B)
Cliff Howard speaking on behalf of the Solano County Farm Bureau
commented on additions to the ordinance related to the onsite growing
requirements, noting the Farm Bureau does not agree with the onsite/offsite
growing requirement that does not apply to farm stands larger than 2500 sq. ft.
Mr. Howard further stated it would be difficult for the Farm Bureau to support a
text amendment that does require produce or ag products to be grown in Solano
County. Mr. Howard further stated that there needs to be a different definition of
farm stands that sell a significant amount of product that is not grown in Solano
County.
Page 14
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
C) Gail Culley commented in support of the changes to the farm stand portion of
the code and had questions regarding clarification on the potential costs related
to road maintenance.
Mr. Bezek stated there are no fees related to road maintenance agreements, 
noting that any project that comes in going forward for subdivisions will need to 
submit a proper road maintenance agreement as per the new Road Standards 
and meet the requirements typical for subdivision applications. 
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing. 
Supervisor Williams restated her recommendation to have a countywide Solano 
grown product percentage requirement of 25% and encouraged the removal of 
exemptions for larger farm stands. Supervisor Williams further recommended 
that staff utilize subject matter experts when doing updates to the code. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if staff has been 
given sufficient direction to clarify the differences in the various farm stands, Mr. 
Calder stated to work in a 25% locally grown number into farm stands over 2,500 
square feet would be acceptable as long as it makes sense for the farmers and 
ranchers.
Mr. Bezek commented on the differences between the words local, Solano 
grown, and regional, noting the Board will need to come to a consensus on a 
term for staff to craft language for the ordinance. 
Mr. Bezek commented on the need for more work with regard to Section IV of the 
proposed ordinance, noting that the changes that are being recommended are 
not under the purview of the public hearing being held at this meeting. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need to add language to the ordinance 
regarding regionalism, recommending the addition of the language “in partnership 
with”, to reflect those growers that may grow product in a neighboring county 
while working with a Solano County grower, or a farmer from Solano County who 
leases land in a neighboring county because the particular crop they desire to 
grow, can not be produced in Solano County. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need for two different ordinances, stating he 
would like to see a clear delineation between the definitions of farm stand and 
local market.
Supervisor W

chunks.item_title: Receive a background report on the Collinsville Water Dependent Industrial
chunks.text:
Receive a background report on the Collinsville Water Dependent Industrial 
(WDI) area including brief history, allowable uses under the General Plan, and 
applicable 
policies 
and 
zoning; 
Encourage 
the 
property 
owners/project 
proponents of the shipbuilding concept in the Collinsville area to directly 
engage with the County on details of the proposal and necessary steps to 
achieve General Plan compliance; and Provide direction to staff on next steps 
Page 17
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
including 
directly 
addressing 
cities 
regarding 
the 
County’s 
jurisdictional 
responsibilities in the Collinsville area 
A - General Plan Designation Description
B - Collinsville General Plan Special Study Area
Attachments:
Chair Mashburn stated the presentation is being brought forward at the request of 
the Board, noting that it provides the Board and the public with the opportunity to 
hear exactly what is in the General Plan and exactly what is and is not designated 
as approved land uses in the region.
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item and 
provided information on the Collinsville Special Study Area.
Water and Natural Resources Program Manager Misty Kaltreider provided 
information on the Water Dependent Industrial Areas.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Dwight Calloway commented on potential security issues, and in support of
the potential of a shipyard in Collinsville
B) Eunice Mallery commented in opposition to the County working with California
Forever on a potential shipbuilding project in Solano County.
C) Joel Barrilleaux commented in opposition to the County working with California
Forever on a potential shipbuilding project in Solano County.
D) Michael Hayes commented in opposition to a potential shipbuilding project in
Solano County.
E) Jim Bartz commented in opposition to a potential shipbuilding project in Solano
County
F) Jan Bartz commented in opposition to a potential shipbuilding project in Solano
County.
G) Terry Tucker commented in opposition to the County working with California
Forever on a potential shipbuilding project in Solano County.
H) Margaret Anderson commented on the potential impacts of a shipbuilding
project in Solano County.
I) Marilyn Farley commented on the potential impacts of a shipbuilding project in
Solano County
Supervisor Vasquez stated this item is simply a presentation of what is possible 
under the current General Plan. Supervisor Vasquez further stated from his 
perspective, this issue should be taken up during the the General Plan review. 
Page 18
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
J) Former Supervisor Duane Kromm commented on the need for the public to
hear data points related to the depth of the shipping channels in the Collinsville
area and information regarding how much dredging will be required to
accommodate the type of ships they are planning to build.
Supervisor Vasquez stated the first step in this process should be a countywide 
summit, so the cities can state what their future development plans are for the 
next 10-20 years, noting that at some point, this discussion needs to be heard by 
the Board and the public. Supervisor Vasquez further stated that at this time, this 
is no pending application for a project. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Supervisor Vasquez’s comments, 
noting she would like more information on potential funding for any projects. 
Supervisor Williams further commented on the need for California Forever to 
work with the county on any potential proposal. Supervisor Williams further stated 
the county should be working with Congressman Garamendi, who is focused 
more heavily on Mare Island, and further noted that she would like the cities to 
allow the county to work through this process. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the need for everyone to wait and see how this 
situation pans out, noting that the Executive Order does not have funding 
attached to it. 
Supervisor James commented on the need to distinguish the difference between 
the Ships Act and the Executive Order.
In response to Supervisor James’s comments, Mr. Bezek stated the Executive 
Order identified goals to bring back maritime opportunities that can align with the 
Collinsville area and the General Plan. Mr. Bezek further stated that there has 
been no analysis as to what that could mean to Solano County because there 
has not been a project brought forward. Mr. Bezek further stated the Ships Act is 
a bipartisan effort that is still in process with goals that are similar to the 
Executive Order but more focused at the national level. Mr. Bezek further stated 
that California Forever has held virtual town halls to describe what they would like 
to see in the Collinsville area, which created a lot of excitement within the cities 
and the media. 
Chair Mashburn stated the County has a landowner that has had some 
controversy surrounding it and there is stigma attached to that name for good or 
bad. Chair Mashburn further stated prior to California Forever owning the land it 
was owned by others, noting that regardless of who owns the land, they will still 
be required to bring any project forward and go through a specific process with 
many regulatory agencies to make the project happen. Chair Mashburn noted that 
once that is complete, they would have to bring the proposal to the county for 
review. Chair Mashburn further stated that this is a valid use of the land per the 
county’s current General Plan. Chair Mashburn further stated he fully supports 
the concept of there being some type of shipbuilding industry or manufacturing 
brought to the Solano County region; however, there is a need to separate the 
Page 19
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
excitement of the cities over the possibilities from the process,

ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.
